Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Collective Outcome 1: Durable Solutions for IDPs
Outcome: By 2025, 80 per cent of IDPs and returnees will have achieved a durable solution in harmony and with full respect of the rights of communities hosting or receiving them.
Output: Displacement-affected populations have access to adequate and decent housing as well as equal access to basic services, including health, education and WASH, protection services
Sub-Output: Project 5.1.2.3.1: Provide unconditional resource transfers to food insecure IDPs in Libya
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Government of Austria; Government of Denmark; Government of Germany; Government of Malta; Government of Poland; Government of Sweden; Government of Switzerland; Government of the United Kingdom; Italian Agency for Development Cooperation ; Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Private Donors; Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation; United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: Libya Ministry of Social Affairs; Non Governmental Organizations
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Internally Displaced Persons
2023 Narrative: WFP reached 94,924 displaced IDPs and 3,218 food-insecure returnees in Libya in 2023 through general food assistance (GFA) and cash-based transfers (CBTs) in the form of value vouchers through pre-paid cards. In the immediate aftermath of Storm Daniel in September, WFP ramped up its emergency food assistance reaching more than 126,000 flood-affected people with a total of 1,045 mt of in-kind assistance and USD 424,619 in CBT value voucher through pre-paid cards through its partner LibAid in 33 locations across the northeastern region of the country from September to December. At the outset of the emergency, a rapid conflict sensitivity risk assessment focused on the flood response was conducted to better inform decision-making and identify risk mitigation measures for the extended crisis.
2024 Narrative: Overall, WFP assisted 221,260 men and women across Libya, of which 52 percent were women and girls. Of these, 39 percent were Sudanese refugees reached with life-saving food and nutrition assistance and 12,860 were internally displaced persons (IDPs). In 2025 under the Libya country strategic plan (CSP) outcome 1 (crisis response), WFP assisted a total of 175,834 food-insecure people through life-saving in-kind general food assistance (GFA) and cash-based transfers (CBTs) in the form of value vouchers through pre-paid cards. Under the 2024 Libya Flood Flash Appeal which concluded in July 2024 [1], WFP reached 44,355 flood-affected people across eight flood-affected cities in the eastern part of Libya (Derna, Benghazi, Tobruk, Al Bayada, Al Ghubbah, Al Sahel, Al Abyar, Ajdabiya) through cash-based transfers and with a total of 490 mt of in-kind food assistance.  By the end of 2024, WFP had provided in-kind food assistance to 81,721 Sudanese refugees and cash assistance to 3,600 Libyan host community members across 11 locations in Libya. WFP's response included malnutrition prevention activities, providing lipid-based nutritional supplements to 3,180 children under five and date bars to 1,396 Sudanese pregnant and breastfeeding women.
2025 Narrative: Actiivty (general food assistance) to continue throughout 2025. Pipeline break expected June 2025.

2023 Narrative: In June, WFP's emergency response in Libya included support to migrants and persons of concern intercepted in Alassa, on the Libyan border with Tunisia. Through an operational task force including (International Organization for Migration (IOM), United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) coordinated with the Libyan Coast Guard, WFP provided in-kind food assistance to 1,740 persons of concern.
2024 Narrative: Continued efforts towards prioritizing WFP‚Äôs emergency response in Libya, included bi-monthly support to migrants and refugees in Alassa, on the Libyan border with Tunisia. An operational task force led by the International Organization for Migration (IOM), including UNHCR and UNICEF continued to coordinate with the Libyan Coast Guard and other relevant government counterparts. On a no-regrets basis, WFP provided in-kind food assistance to 1,975 refugees
2025 Narrative: Activity (general food assistance) stopped for bi-monthly in-kind food assistance in 2024 to migrants.

Plan name: UNSDCF 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: Planet
Outcome: By 2026, all people in Zimbabwe, especially the most vulnerable and marginalized, benefit from greater environmental stability and robust food systems in support of healthy lives and equitable, sustainable and resilient livelihoods.
Output: Output 2.2: People especially the vulnerable and marginalized including women, girls, adolescents and youth are empowered to cope with climate change and build resilience for household food, and nutrition and water security demonstrating optimal attitudes, knowledge and attitudes.
Sub-Output: ERVHIZ: Rural households‚Äô resilience to food crises and climate change: Local communities‚Äô access to WASH services improved. UNICEF
Description:
Water supply with piped water systems, borehole drilling and repair broken boreholes to supply water for drinking and agricultural needs - prioritizing optimization of existing water systems, which include upgrading/rehabilitation of Piped Water Systems and hand pump fitted boreholes, with borehole drilling where necessary and feasible
Drinking Water Safety and Security Planning (DWSSP), including strengthening water quality monitoring systems
Strengthening community systems for Operation and Maintenance (O&M) of drinking water systems. 
Establishment/resuscitation of Sanitation Action Groups (SAGs), Community Health Clubs (CHCs) and School Health Clubs (SHCs)
Construction of household latrines for vulnerable households, combined with training of latrine builders
Demand Led Sanitation to achieve Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities
Roll out integrated social and behaviour change communication focusing on hygiene, sanitation, nutrition and diet related promotion targeting young children living in the targeted 40,000 people through care groups and community level structures.

2021 Narrative: FAO and partners have organised a field visit to youth artisans and beneficiary farmers. A total of 2 420 farmers (1500 male and 920 female) participated in the exchange visit. As a result of this exchange visit, five farmers ordered and purchased five metal silos with a grain holding capacity of one ton. Promotional activities were conducted in Amhara and SNNPR by organising demonstration and displays in market areas. The promotion was organised for selected farmers who are able to share the experience of metal silo and hermetic bag to other farmers. 240 farmers participated in visiting the demonstration in market areas and Farmer Training centres. The displays in the market areas created an interest in farmers to create a dialogue with youth artisans‚Äô farmers on the use of metal silo. As a result of the capacity building and awareness raising events, 5,597 beneficiary farmers purchased metal silos by their own resources. With the use of these metal silos the farmers saved 55970 tons of grain. Those farmers who benefited from the project have shifted their storage from the traditional to the effective and efficient metal silos and hermetic bags after realizing the benefits. In addition, the metal silo technology has been successfully scaled up to 2,416 non-beneficiary farmers.

2024 Narrative: Provided institutional capacity building support in promoting and supporting development of good post-harvest management for grains in Ethiopia. The objective is reducing Food Losses through improved Post harvest Management practices in Ethiopia. FAO provided technical support to MoA to develop post-harvest management strategy, which is endorsed by the MoA. As a result of the strategy, post-harvest management is incorporated into the Agricultural Technical and Vocational Training (ATVT) curriculum.

2021 Narrative: Enhanced humanitarian and development coordination in Agriculture sector. The project enhanced coordination between the federal and regional levels. A survey undertaken to assess the effectiveness of the coordination mechanisms revealed that 73 of the respondents indicated that technical guidelines and standards produced by the DRM-Agriculture Task Force (ATF) we very useful. The respondents also noted that the information shared by the DRM-ATF enhanced the quality of programming and also supported the implementation of anticipatory actions. The respondents requested that DRM-AFT technical guidelines be made readily available. A number of new programmes and investments on DRM were initiated in 2020. Some examples include the European Union-funded Support Decentralization of DRM in Ethiopia; the FCDO-USAID funded Building Resilience in Ethiopia (BRE) programme. The Anticipatory Action initiative by UN OCHA is a good investment in DRM that actualizes early warning early action linkages, building on evidence from the IPC as well as seasonal weather forecasts. Following the project intervention, the Anticipatory Action pilot also adopted the use of IPC thresholds among the criteria for decision_x0002_making. OCHA had also prioritized agriculture in its suite of anticipatory action interventions

2024 Narrative: For logistical reasons from PNASE, was unable to complete the activity of supplying agricultural products to the 47 schools benefiting around 6,600 students, but the conditions are in place for it to be resumed in January 2025.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Inclusive Growth
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - Economic Growth & Employment
Output: Output 1.1.1 - Relevant MDA and selected LGAs have strengthened capacities to review and implement evidence-based economic policies and plans to be business-enabling, environmentally sustainable and gender responsive
Sub-Output: 1.1.1.1 - Capacity building for monitoring and analyzing food and agriculture policies
Description:
TA to strengthen capacities of  Agriculture Sector Line Ministries (ASLM), agencies and institutions  to monitor and analyze food and agriculture policies._x000D_
_x000D_
An enabling policy environment is a key element for agricultural development, food security and poverty reduction in developing countries. However, government policy analysts and decision makers often lack the capacity to generate reliable evidence of the impact of their policies on value chain actors, from farmers to consumers. Therefore, government policies and the effects they generate are often inconsistent with overarching food security and agricultural development goals. FAO through MAFAP successfully collaborated with government institutions and research organizations, to create policy-monitoring systems and carry out a consistent set of policy and public expenditure analyses across a wide range of agricultural value chains. MAFAP is building on the partnerships and evidence created to support the governments to reform food and agricultural policies that are currently constraining agricultural development, especially for smallholders._x000D_
_x000D_
FAO through the MAFAP supports the Government to identify, articulate and assess options for reforming food and agricultural policies. The programme has four objectives:_x000D_
-	Collect, assemble and use targeted and policy relevant data, including prices, market access costs and public expenditure in support of the food and agricultural sector, as well as policy _x000D_
        decisions._x000D_
-	Consolidate and strengthen national policy monitoring systems to measure policy effects and identify current policy ‚Äòproblems‚Äô that affect the competitiveness of agricultural producers._x000D_
-	Articulate policy options and assess respective ex-post and ex-ante analysis to support suitable government reforms._x000D_
-	Engage national stakeholders and development partners in policy dialogue, as part of a more inclusive policy reform process.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: German Federal Ministry of Health
Implementation partners: MALF; zMoANRLF
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

2021 Narrative:
38 labour saving devices composing of 19 tractors and 19 assorted coos & rice milling machines, rice decorticators, threshers etc provided to 38 communities in the Western Division, Lower River , Central River, North Bank  and Upper River Regions of The Gambia to support boost agricultural productivity, reduce post harvest lost and increase food security.

Additionally, 25 cows, 2 bulls (Brown Swiss breeds), 10 does and 2 bucks (Saanen breeds) are procured for 10 communities in  Lower River , Central River, North Bank  and Upper River Regions of The Gambia to support Diary milk production for value addition.

Furthermore, the West African Livestock Innovation Center (WALIC) Headquarter at Bijilo has been supported with the fencing of a 5 hectare perimeter fence for animal pasture feeding; a refurbishment of their Animal Shed and construction of a Calving and Sick Bay to support the introduction of exotic animal breeding, milk production and value addition.
2022 Narrative: 38 Labour Saving Devices (LSDs) composing of 19 tractors and 19 assorted coos  rice milling machines, rice decorticators, threshers distributed to 38 communities in the Western Division, Lower River, Central River, North Bank and Upper River Regions of The Gambia benefitting 21,200 people (17,408 male  3,792 female) to support boost agricultural productivity, reduce post-harvest lost and increase food security.

Sub-Output: People affected by shocks (Tier 1) have access to nutritious food, cash to meet their essential needs
Description: Through this SOU, WFP is expected to provide support to the most vulnerable population affected by seasonal or protracted shocks in both rural and urban areas. The assistance modality involves cash or in-kind support so that households are able to meet their urgent needs. The Beneficiaries are expected to benefit from the Social and Behavioral change Communication to improve their diets.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Gambia Ministry of Health

Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.1.2 Targeted children, Pregnant and Lactating Women, and Girls particularly in rural and urban disaster and conflict prone areas receive adequate nutrition and health services

LNOB groups targeted: Children ; Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.); Minorities
2024 Narrative: To respond to people affected by shocks and to ensure they have access to adequate food and health services. In 2024, WFP supported fifty households equivalent to 400 people including 204 female and 196 male with family members living with HIV through Cash Based Transfer (CBT) to enhance access to nutritious food. To ensure privacy and psychological comfort, distributions were held at familiar anti-retroviral treatment and prevention of mother-to-child transmission facilities. This flexible approach achieved 100 percent coverage for mobile money transfers and direct cash distributions. Mobile money was prioritised for its efficiency and potential to foster financial inclusion among vulnerable groups, while direct cash distribution was used for beneficiaries unable to meet documentation and mobile requirements. This approach underscored WFP‚Äôs sensitivity commitment to inclusivity and dignity, ensuring that the unique needs of its beneficiaries were met. The intervention shows a signifcant impact on the consumption of the supported people as the proportion of assisted households with poor and borderline consumption decreased, while the share of households with acceptable consumption increased to 80.5 percent in 2024, compared to 57 percent at the baseline. The positive impact of the cash distribution is evident as over half of the beneficiaries met their food needs without resorting to negative coping strategies

Focal users: Kweku Buadee; Benjamin Adjei; Jefferson Attipoe
2023 Narrative: The capacities of Agricultural Extension Agents were enhanced on home gardening techniques to support the production and utilization of nutrient-rich crops in 15 beneficiary districts. A total of 482 home gardens were established across the 15 districts, while seeds, seedlings, and garden materials (such as nails and wire mesh) were supplied to the beneficiary households.
2024 Narrative: 90 Agricultural Extension Agents have been equipped with management techniques to reduce crop losses and improve storage. A total of 12,272 smallholder farmers (comprising 42% females and 58% males) were equipped with essential knowledge of Good Agronomic Practices (GAPs) and resources to improve crop productivity, enhance soil health, and promote sustainable farming practices for the sustainable cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum, enabling the cultivation of 5,782 hectares. Support for 200 women-led Fonio value chain actors and 45 soybean producers has provided beneficiaries with training in Good Agricultural Practices, post-harvest handling, and value-added processing, boosting efficiency in productivity and income opportunities. To combat antimicrobial resistance, a Farmer Field School model has trained 211 farm actors in responsible antimicrobial use and sustainable practices, fostering peer-to-peer learning and innovation.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Inclusive Growth
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - Economic Growth & Employment
Output: Output 1.1.2 - Relevant institutions have enhanced capacities to provide gender-responsive, market-oriented, quality programmes, products and services
Sub-Output: 1.1.2.13 - Reversing land degradation trands and increasing food security in degraded ecosystems of semi-arid areas of Tanzania
Description:
Project development objective is to reverse land degradation trends through sustainable land and water management and ecosystems based adaptation. The LDFS is structured into three inter-related components: Component 1 will set the enabling conditions for sustainable land and water management at landscape level sustaining ecosystem services and enhancing food security. It will strengthen institutional capacity at the village, inter-village and district levels and establish inter-village committees with the goal of developing landscape level inter-village participatory resources and livelihood diagnostics and land use planning processes to foster an integrated and holistic management of natural resources. Component 2 will support the implementation of sustainable land and water management priorities, conservation of habitats for biodiversity, conservation farming practices, and income-generating activities agreed within said plans. Component 3 will focus on monitoring and assessing the progress in sustaining ecosystem services, household resilience and food security based on assessment results. Component 3 will also support incorporating lessons learned in local and district level natural resources governance systems and contributing to the continuous improvement of the landscape level approach to natural resources management, supporting integration of best practices in policy making at the district, regional and national levels._x000D_
_x000D_
Budgeting is done on annual basis at national level.  At the start of the fiscal year, beneficiaries districts (Kondoa, Magu, Micheweni, Mkalama, Nzega) submit their annual work plan and budget and the coordination unit transfer the funds to each district according to their needs.
Agencies: International Fund for Agricultural Development
Contributing partners: The Global Environment Facility
Implementation partners: VPO
SDG Targets: 15.3 By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Inclusive Growth
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - Economic Growth & Employment
Output: Output 1.1.2 - Relevant institutions have enhanced capacities to provide gender-responsive, market-oriented, quality programmes, products and services
Sub-Output: 1.1.2.22 - Strengthening Plant Health Services in Tanzania for enhanced Food Safety
Description:
More than 67% of the population in Tanzania is employed in agriculture. The agricultural sector accounts for 30.1% of the GDP and generates 50% of the export earnings. In 2018 Tanzania exported agricultural products to Europe for approximately EUR 259 million. Smallholder farmers produce the majority of agricultural products for export and national consumption, directly contributing to national wealth and food security. An audit carried out by DG SANTE in 2017 highlighted various weaknesses in the National Plant Health Services, in particular in the surveillance system, communication and procedures and the insufficient knowledge of requirements and standards for export. _x000D_
The action is included in the 11th EDF National Indicative Programme for Tanzania, under the Sustainable Agriculture focal sector. It is in line with the EU's Jobs and Growth Compact for Tanzania , the People, Planet and Prosperity components of the European Consensus on Development  and the UN Agenda 2030 (SDG 2, Zero Hunger; 1, Zero Poverty; 12, Consumption and Production patterns; and 17, Partnership to achieve the goal). _x000D_
_x000D_
The overall objective of the action is to increase access to safe and quality agricultural produce for national and international markets.  In order to achieve this goal, the action will focus on the following objectives:_x000D_
Specific Objective 1 The national system of official controls for the import and export of agricultural products is strengthened. _x000D_
Specific Objective 2 The National Plant Health Services make use of a reliable surveillance and plant protection system.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: European Union; Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Government of United Republic of Tanzania
Implementation partners: Ministry of Agriculture - Mainland
SDG Targets: 1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries,2.b Correct and prevent trade restrictions and distortions in world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures with equivalent effect, in accordance with the mandate of the Doha Development Round.,2.c Adopt measures to ensure the proper functioning of food commodity markets and their derivatives and facilitate timely access to market information, including on food reserves, in order to help limit extreme food price volatility.

Sub-Output: 1.1.3.45 - Support to Host Communities with focus on Food and Economic Security through Agriculture
Description: In order to align with Government priorities around the Agricultural Sector Development Plan II (ASDP 2) and other current interventions in the Kigoma region, the Kigoma Joint Programme Agriculture theme (Outcome 6) adopts the partnership approach to address issues pertaining to smallholders farmers. FAO interventions under the programme, focus on improving agricultural productivity through promoting Climate Smart Agriculture, creating access to knowledge on Good Agricultural Practices, access to high quality inputs that are adapted to local conditions such as climate conditions and pest and disease pressure, to increase the productivity of identified crops (Maize, Cassava and Beans). FAO continues to play a critical role in providing technical support through advocating for the implementation of the Tanzania Agriculture and Climate Resilience Plan (ACRP) and Climate Smart Agriculture Programme to mitigate risks, set priorities for action and investment and build a foundation for resilience in the agriculture sector especially for vulnerable communities. This reiterates the government‚Äôs commitment to make the agricultural sector climate-smart by 2030. A comprehensive training package on Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) emphasizing on Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) for crop production will entail on/off farm practices that address environmental, economic and social sustainability aspects along the supply chain, which results to safe and quality food and non-food products. This will enable farmers to become resilient to climate shock. Emphasis will also be placed on nutrition-sensitive agriculture to address the double burden of malnutrition in the region.The CSA guideline will be used as an instructive tool for informing extension staff and farmers on mainstreaming climate change adaptation and mitigation co-beneficial objectives within agriculture development. More particularly, it will provide guidance on CSA practices and technologies best suited for Kigoma region and the agro-climatic zone. It will also target district development planners and extension agents to plan and budget for agricultural development, and to facilitate community level planning; and extension agents to sensitize, mobilize and train smallholder farmers to adopt agricultural practices considered climate-smart. Additionally, FAO will train smallholder farmers on improved beekeeping practices as an important livelihood strategy for income generating with very high potential for improving income, especially for communities living close to forests and woodlands. Beekeeping development also has a potential of contributing to self-employment, enhancing agricultural production, promoting and the conservation of the environment.FAO interventions will focus on the following outputs for the next four years: - Strengthening group cohesion and building producer organizations through Farmer Field Schools (FFS) and Junior Farmer Field Learning Schools (JFFLS)- Training on good agriculture practices and Climate Smart Agriculture practices for selected commodities including maize, beans, cassava and livestock production- Procurement and distribution of agricultural inputs (seeds and fertilizer, herbicides/pesticides, vaccines) and tools.- Disseminate information about different and appropriate varieties of maize, beans and cassava and livestock through various channels including community radios, school JFFLS and FFS programmes.- Promote and train Beekeeping as a viable enterprise (incl. dissemination of information via community radio)- Develop and implement integrated landscape management plans in the project area/ agricultural zone
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; The Tanzania One Fund
Implementation partners: Kakonko DC; Kasulu DC; Kasulu TC; Kibondo DC; Kigoma RAS; LGAs; MATI Mubondo; MOA; MicroLoan Foundation; PO-RALG
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - By 2024, Sierra Leone benefits from a more productive, commercialized and sustainable agriculture, improved food and nutrition security, and increased resilience to climate change and other shocks
Output: Output 1.1.3 - Access to diversified, nutritious and safe food is increased, and adequate dietary intake improved
Sub-Output: 1.1.3.5 - Provision of nutritious food for targeted children 6-23 months and PLW for stunting prevention
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: African Development Bank; Government of France; Government of Germany; Government of Ireland; Government of Japan; Government of Sierra Leone; Irish Department of Foreign Affairs
Implementation partners: MoHS
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,3.2 By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 2 Zero Hunger; 3 Good Health and Well-being
Geography: Sierra Leone; Kambia; Pujehun; Moyamba; Northern; Southern
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2018-2024
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1- Economic Transformation: By 2024, people in Rwanda enjoy an improved quality of life sustained by a modern economy that is globally competitive, knowledge-based and environmentally sustainable
Outcome: OUTCOME 1: BY 2024, PEOPLE IN RWANDA BENEFIT FROM MORE INCLUSIVE, COMPETITIVE, AND SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC GROWTH THAT GENERATES DECENT WORK AND PROMOTES QUALITY LIVELIHOODS FOR ALL
Output: Output 1.1.3 - National institutions, private sector and communities are equipped with the technical capacity, skills, and knowledge to develop and implement evidence based, inclusive policies and programmes for increased sustainable, climate conscious  industrialization and continental trade competitiveness
Sub-Output: 1.1.3.9 - In partnership with GS1 Global and GLEIF support the uptake in Rwanda of product and entity unique identification systems to improve competitiveness against imports of local providers, expand complaince with food traceability, payment, e-commerce, banking, import country customs and logistics standards.
Agencies: International Trade Centre
Contributing partners: International Trade Centre
Implementation partners: PSF; Rwanda Ministry of Trade and Industry
SDG Targets: 9.2 Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry's share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.,9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.,9.4 By 2030, upgrade infrastructure and retrofit industries to make them sustainable, with increased resource-use efficiency and greater adoption of clean and environmentally sound technologies and industrial processes, with all countries taking action in accordance with their respective capabilities.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2025-2030)
Strategic priority: Food Systems, Natural Resource Management and Climate Change
Outcome: People in Sierra Leone, especially the most vulnerable, are food and nutrition secure, benefit from effective natural resource management, are resilient to the effects of climate change, and equipped to prevent and respond to disasters.

Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights

2023 Narrative: WFP provided technical support on food safety and quality for up to 3 community milling and blending concerns, predominantly women‚Äôs groups, in the three northern regions and financial and technical support for two industrial fortified flour producers in Brong Ahafo and Ashanti regions. WFP has contributed to improve livelihoods of 24,049 smallholder farmers and aggregators in 8 regions (Upper East, Upper West, North East, Savannah, Northern, Bono East, Ashanti and Volta) with income generating activities through cash- based transfer, trainings and equipment provision.

Strategic priority: Support inclusive economic growth and transformation
Outcome: Outcome 1: Inclusive, Resilient, Sustainable Economic Growth and Transformation
Output: Strengthened institutional and stakeholder capacities and regulatory frameworks for integrating climate change, environmental considerations and economic diversification, including natural resources management, food systems, value chains, enhanced trade, the blue, green and circular economy, private sector development, digitalization, decent employment and livelihoods.
Sub-Output: Food systems actors have improved knowledge, skills and tools, and access to financial services and other support services (inputs, mechanisation, irrigation, information) and structured markets to improve their livelihoods, nutrition, and incomes in a climate-smart manner.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Mastercard Foundation; Private company; United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Association of Ghana Industries; Ghana Commodity Exchange; Ghana Enterprises Agency; Ghana Insurance Pool (GAIP); Ghana Ministry of Food & Agriculture; Ghana Private Sector; National Food Buffer stock company Ghana; Peasant Farmers Association Ghana; Regional Agriculture Departments Ghana
SDG Targets: 5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

Geography: Volta; Oti; Ashanti; Northern; North East; Savannah; Ahafo; Upper West; Bono East; Bono; Upper East; Ghana; Eastern
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls; Persons With Disabilities; Youth; Peasants & Rural Workers
2024 Narrative: In 2024, WFP supported 30,000 smallholder farmers in Ghana by enhancing their capabilities in Good Agricultural Practices (GAP), post-harvest handling, storage, and financial management. Training programs were designed to uplift farmers and aggregators, enabling them to produce high-quality agricultural products that meet market demands. WFP supported 3 women-led food processors who received capital to strengthen SHF linkages, upgrade equipment, and ensure market access. A Post-Harvest Innovation Competition was imitated to support 3,000 farmers, with 400 applications under review. 2,000 youth farmers were onboarded onto the Ghana Commodity Exchange to access equipment and markets. 2,100 maize farmers in Bono, Ashanti, and Upper East benefited from ABInBev market access and post-harvest equipment.

2024 Narrative: WFP completed an initial agreement with the Ministry of Food and Agriculture (MoFA) to provide technical capacity for a project promoting Climate-Smart Agriculture (CSA) and agroforestry to 10,000 small holder farmers. The Emergency Support to Rural Livelihoods and Food Systems (ESRF) initiative was a notable effort, where WFP provided crucial support to over 4,000 women and youth microprocessors affected by a prolonged dry spell across multiple districts.This initiative not only facilitated access to climate risk-financing but also enhanced productivity through the distribution of processing equipment and cash-based transfers.

Sub-Output: SoilFER-VACS Framework - Enhancing Integrated Soil-Crop Management for Sustainable Food Systems in Africa
Description: The objectives of the Project are designed to address low soil fertility and productivity challenges by improving decision-making for crops, fertilizers and soil management practices at various scales, thereby increasing yields and improving food security, particularly for smallholders. The project focuses on producing detailed maps of soil health and fertility status to enable strategic national-level decisions on policies. It also aims to strengthen institutional capacities in soil analysis and data interpretation and establishing a decision support framework, and facilitate decision-making for crop selection, fertilizer use, and SSM practices to optimize agricultural productivity at the local level.

Contributing partners: Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs

2023 Narrative: Smallholder farmers in selected districts (East Gonja district, Savanna Region) have gained knowledge on Good Agronomic Practices (GAPs) in soyabean production and also introduced to improved technologies including seeds, inoculant and the post-harvest handling of the produce.
2024 Narrative: Through FAOs interventions in partnership with the Ministry of Food and Agriculture and Department of Agriculture, beneficiary farmers of the soybean development project (GCP/GHA/039/JPN) achieved an 87% increase in crop yield, raising productivity from 0.8 t/ha to 1.5 t/ha in targeted areas. This remarkable improvement was driven by the adoption of sustainable production practices and the application of climate-smart agricultural techniques, leading to higher output, improved food security, and increased farmer incomes.

2022 Narrative: FAO connected 3,775 beneficiaries (38 percent women) enrolled in the Productive Social Action Programme (PASP) with agriculture and rural development activities through integrated interventions, using a combined mechanism of unconditional cash transfer and subsidy for agricultural inputs using electronic voucher.
2023 Narrative: Vulnerable and marginalized people empowered for the transition to access contributory Social Protection (SP) schemes:700 people resumed production, increased knowledge on good agricultural practices, market access, nutrition, credit and savings, through FAO support (inputs and capacity building). The beneficiaries are from the districts of Gur√∫e (Zamb√©zia Province) and Rib√°ue (Nampula Province) and are part of the government social protection program referred to as Productive Social Action Program (PASP).Capacity of Government and communities was strengthened to promote best practices on nutrition and increase access to healthy diets. Ôªø296 people (farmers, teachers, students and government technicians) increased knowledge on nutrition and healthy diets. 300 communities had access to vegetable seeds resulting in 9,000 women farmers establishing home gardens. 100 schools had access to seeds and approximately 10,000 students were involved in school gardens. A training manual on nutrition was revised to better train facilitators on nutrition. A cereal album on nutrition and home garden was developed. In the coming years, FAO will continue to strengthen capacity of stakeholders on nutrition and healthy diets.

Description: UNICEF leverage on the Ministry of Gender and Social Protection safety nets programme to ensure that some of the cash transfers are used to buy more and better-quality food. This helps ensure that families are knowledgeable and can maintain an adequate level of food consumption, which is essential for good health. UNICEF supports the National Food Fortification Alliance to conduct regular assessments of wheat flour, vegetable oil, and cooking salt on the local market are fortified with the needed nutrients as a mitigating approach to addressing the high level of micronutrient deficiencies(malnutrition) amongst the Liberian population, especially pregnant women and children. The county and district WASH Profiles and development plan activities were completed in February 2024 for six selected counties. The County WASH Development Plan aims to support the government's WASH goals by providing a strategic framework for equitable, safe, affordable, and sustainable water supply and sanitation services for all Liberians. The plan's overall objective is to reduce the risk of fecal-oral diseases and exposure to WASH-related diseases.

Supported food security, livelihoods and market survey. 3-Enhanced food safety and food disease surveillance through National capacity building of built Environmental Health Technicians (EHTs) from 3 selected counties (Montserrado, Bong, and Grand Bassa) Built the capacities (skills and competencies) of 40 frontline service providers and 58 community dwellers on essential nutrition actions (ENAs) through the establishment of Baby Friendly Hospital Initiatives (BFHI )facilities and mother-support groups to improve maternal and child nutrition practices.
2023 Narrative: World Health OrganizationSupported the development of the WASH road map and the International Food Safety Authority Network (INFOSAN) road map, commemorated World Food Safety Day, and celebrated World Breastfeeding Week.UNICEF: The WASH Joint Sector Review (JSR), supported by UNICEF, has been successfully completed, and the report is in the process of being printed. Prior to the JSR, the Sector Performance Report was also compiled and is undergoing printing. Conversations centered around the integration of climate-resilient development within WASH sector plans during the JSR, contributing insights to shape the forthcoming Water Supply and Sanitation Policy (WSSP) for 2023‚Äì2027. According to the joint monitoring report by UNICEF and WHO, the percentage of people who had access to at least basic drinking water remained at 76% in 2023. This signifies that the population coverage for basic water supply stands at 65% in rural areas and 85% in urban areas.World Food ProgrammeThrough this intervention, 20 school teachers in Bong and Montserrado enhanced their capacity in provision alternative learning for out of school women. Two hundred (200) rural women received one month training in literacy and numeracy and four months training in vegetable production which developed their skills for alternative livelihoods, increased their reduced their vulnerability to food insecurity.
2024 Narrative: WHO supported of the training of 56‚Ä¨ Environmental and Occupational Health Technicians at national and subnational levels in the use of WHO WASH-FIT Tool in readiness for the assessment and use of the tool to collect WASH-related data from 93 health facilities in the 15 Counties. WHO supported the national food safety authorities to develop case definitions for the 26 foodborne diseases. Terms of Reference for the International Food Safety Authorities Network Focal Point in Liberia, including line ministries, agencies and commissions (MACs), developed with support from WHO to foster coordination and communication on foodborne disease outbreaks and risks to reduce the burden of foodborne illness. WHO supported the National WASH Commission to conduct the 2024-2025 Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation (and Drinking Water GLAAS) for Liberia, and validated and submitted the report.   WHO supported of the training of 56 Environmental and Occupational Health Technicians on the use of WHO WASH-FIT Tool that facilitated the collection of WASH related data from 93 health facilities across the 15 counties. To enhance foodborne disease surveillance, WHO supported the national food safety authorities in developing case definitions for the 26 foodborne diseases. Terms of reference (TOR) for the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) Focal Point in Liberia, including line ministries, agencies and commissions (MACs) developed with support from WHO to foster coordination and communication on foodborne disease outbreaks and risks to reduce the burden of foodborne illness.    Provided technical and financial support to the National WASH Commission to conduct the 2024/2025 Cycle of the Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking Water (GLAAS) Country Survey, with report validated and submitted. Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: ADPs; CSOs; State Govts
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: WFP provided conditional food and cash support for beneficiaries to provide labor to create community and household assets that promotes sustainable livelihoods. This activity contributed to increase agriculture production, markets transactions, and incomes of the vulnerable households.
2022 Narrative: UNWFP - Most of the funds received were directed towards CBT activities to provide vital support to the conditional assistance for beneficiaries who carried out agricultural, hydroponics, Livestock, etc in Borno and Yobe States of the Northeast. Success story:There was a significant achievement under the reporting period for hydroponic fodder production in Borno State ‚Äì a record higher percentage fodder production at 87% (190,000 Kg) in 2022 as opposed to 13% (29,000 Kg) production for 2021. This success further translates to an increased birth rate amongst the animals at 68% in 2022 compared to 31% for previous years which meant production of more milk to complement household nutrition especially for children. Furthermore, over NGN 3 million was realized from sales of shoats. The multiplier effect of this innovation has led to adoption by both IDPs, host communities with a lot of interest from government and other stakeholders in Borno state.

2021 Narrative:
FAO
37,098 farming Households befited from improved food security support involving access to livelihood support including crop inputs, livestock kits and fresh food to support farmers during lean season. The support was provided between January and December of 2021 across LGAs in Borno, Adamawa and Yobe  states through partnership between the FAO and State governments through their ADPs and with NGOs in the delivery of the project activities. The target beneficiaries were vulnerable members of host community, IDPs and returnees and included men and women households. Assessment of impact on crop input beneficiaries indicates improvement in food security outcomes of the beneficiary households. Farmers were able to produce food that will last for an average of 6 months and significantly improved food consumption score (FCS). 94 percent of the sampled beneficiaries have acceptable FCS.
2022 Narrative: FAOLivelihoods assistance through emergency approach offered to over 8,546 households through distribution of fresh food vouchers,  distribution of agricultural inputs for wet and dry season production, livestock restocking and vegetable gardening. These activities were tied to capacity building activity through the establishment  of five Farmer Field Schools across each enterprise.

2023 Narrative: Post registration monitoring and surveillance of plant antimicrobials and farmers views on its use and efficacy in five regions (Eastern, Central, Ashanti, Bono, Ahafo) of Ghana and study findings disseminated with an engagement value chain actors. The findings informed the structural and content design of the biosecurity Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and training manuals, which enabled the introduction of Farmer Field School (FFS) programmes to decentralized Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR)/One Health stakeholders (facilitators) for their involvement and commitment. The FFS participants have been equipped with knowledge and skills to be able to use the developed tools to collect Antimicrobial Use (AMU), economic, and farm biosecurity data throughout their broiler production cycles.

2023 Narrative: Food Security and Nutrition Monitoring Systems have improved in 120 districts across 16 regions with WFP's support contributing projects and programmes planing, and implementing and policies decision making. WFP supported the National Development Planning Commission convene key government ministries, agencies and academia to undertake the ‚ÄòFill the Nutrient Gap‚Äô (FNG) study, a nutrition situation analysis which identified barriers and enhancers to consumption of nutritious diets in Ghana. The report is enhancing advocacy for nutrition especially on measures to improve affordability of nutritious diets.The pilot LEAP reassessment which received WFP support has been completed; findings will be shared to inform an expansion of the pilot.

2024 Narrative: UNDP supported the formation of eight women-led cooperatives in Karamoja region, as enhanced market access and bargaining power for over 300 agro-producers (340 [93%] Female, 24[7%] Male) who were trained in value chain management and climate-resilient practices; contributing to development of functional value chains for cereals, oilseed, and legumes for example sunflower (474.3 acres), green gram (203 acres), sorghum (84.6 acres), maize (72 acres), sesame (1 acre); and cashew nuts (8 acres) planted (843 acres) through their built capacity in sustainable agricultural practices.

2024 Narrative: WFP, in collaboration with the Government of Ghana, supports national assessments and mapping to identify food-insecure and vulnerable populations, improving targeting and access to social protection services. Data collection focuses on pregnant and breastfeeding women, children, people with disabilities, and PLHIV to ensure equitable support. GIS-based mapping and real-time tracking enhance decision-making for school feeding, LEAP, and PLHIV support, ensuring better-targeted interventions. Findings inform policy reforms and resource allocation, strengthening nutrition-sensitive interventions and the national social protection framework. These efforts align Ghana‚Äôs social protection programs with real-time needs, improving efficiency, coverage, and impact.

Outcome: Outcome 1: Productive agricultural drives sustainable industrialisation, improves livelihoods and ensures a hunger- and malnutrition free nation
Output: Government and non-State actors have greater capabilities to improve sustainable production and consumption of nutritious foods
Sub-Output: Promote Nutrition Education and Capacity building  on nutrition sensitive food systems for state and not state actors.
Description:
a.Enhance the capacity of MoFA, GHS staff and other stakeholders in nutrition education.	
b.Enhance the capacity of stakeholders partucular Agricultural Extension Agents(AEAs)  and selected vulnerable households in producing nutrient rich crops particularly Orange-fleshed Sweet Potatoes and other vegetables.	
c.Review of universities‚Äô existing curriculum and identification of the best strategies to incorporate training on nutrition-sensitive food systems (which classes, at which level, how many hours of training, etc.), in line with official procedures. 	
"e. Enhance capacity of selected SMEs working in the Agri-food Sector using nutrition-sensitive food system and value chain approaches to deliver safe nutritious diets.	"	
f. Design school meal nutrition guidelines and standards using an iterative and multi-stakeholder process, learning from FAO¬¥s experience with FBDGs	
i.Carry out a multi-dimensional (individual, organizational and enabling environment) capacity needs assessment and set capacity targets regarding NGS technical aspects, complementary measures and right to food
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Association of Ghana Industries; Ghana Enterprises Agency; Ghana Health Service; Ghana Metropolitan, Municipal, and District Assemblies; Ghana Ministries of fisheries and aquaculture development; Ghana Ministry of Food & Agriculture; Ghana School Feeding Programme
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Other (including coordination); Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Support Functions
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: Throughout the project, radio messages and workshops were used to raise public awareness on the importance of consuming nutrient-rich food. A total of 1 100 people from a range of communities were sensitized on the consumption of healthy diets and their impact on good health and nutrition, as well as the usage of indigenous nutrient-rich food.The consumption of nutrient-rich food such as the orange-fleshed sweet potato (OFSP) and other locally identified crops. The OFSP was identified as a key crop for this project, as it contains a high concentration of carotene, which has the potential to improve the nutrition of women, children, and other vulnerable groups. Its high iron content also makes it effective in the treatment of iron deficiency anaemia.The project also supported measures to increase the production of nutrient-rich food and ensure its consumption

2024 Narrative: UNICEFKey Achievements: UNICEF made efforts to promote the integration of resilient national and sub-national food systems with social services through strategic partnerships, technical support, and capacity enhancement. UNICEF collaborated with government and local partners to support the rollout of nutrition-sensitive frameworks such as the Nutrition-Sensitive Social Protection (NSSP) Operational Framework. This framework linked social services like the Social Cash Transfer Programme (SCTP) to nutrition interventions, ensuring that vulnerable households, particularly those with children under two, benefited from integrated support. Technical assistance was provided to enhance the capacity of local actors and service providers to implement nutrition-sensitive interventions, including food diversification initiatives. Over 90,360 households were supported in establishing backyard gardens and poultry projects, improving food security and dietary diversity.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) 2022-2026
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY AREA¬† 2: ECONOMIC DIVERSIFICATION AND SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2026, more people, particularly women and youths, participate in and benefit from a more diversified, inclusive, and sustainable economic growth based on increased production, productivity, and greater value-added chains.
Output: Output 2.1: Legal frameworks targeting productive capacity, competitiveness, infrastructure, trade and investment, information and communications are strengthened and are gender sensitive, and new digital technologies are inclusive and more accessible;
Sub-Output: Inclusive Agri-food Value Chain Development Programme - PROCAVA
Description: The Programme goal is to contribute to poverty reduction, improved food and nutrition security and resilient livelihoods for inclusive rural transformation. PROCAVA will reach 180,500 beneficiary households (at least 50% women and 30% youth), mostly economically active rural poor who are already involved in production of five targeted value chains namely Horticulture, Cassava, Legumes, Red Meat and poultry. The Programme development objective is to increase the net incomes from Climate-Resilient Agri-Food value chains by rural women, men and youth.
Agencies: International Fund for Agricultural Development
Contributing partners: African Development Bank; Government of Mozambique; International Fund for Agricultural Development
Implementation partners: Mozambique Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
Geography: Tete; Zambezia; Nampula; Mozambique; Sofala; Niassa; Manica; Maputo; Inhambane; Gaza; Cabo Delgado
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Data Collection and Analysis; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Internally Displaced Persons; Youth; Women & Girls; Persons With Disabilities; Persons affected by chronic/long-term health conditions (e.g., HIV/AIDS, leprosy, diabetes, autoimmune disease, etc.); Older Persons
2022 Narrative: Overall, PROCAVA has reached 16,361 HH and 81,805 people, consisting of 4,988 males, 11,373 females, 3,864 youth and approximately 801 persons with disabilities are currently engaged in project activities. The following are the main achievements in the 4 Programme Components:Component 1: Production Improvement and Market Linkage Subcomponent 1.1.1: Production and Productivity Improvement of Selected Commodities ‚Äì Cassava, Horticulture and Legumes This sub-component focuses on Horticulture (tomato, cabbage, carrot, cucumber, peppers, onion, garlic, green beans), Irish and sweet potatoes, Cassava, Legumes (soya beans, common beans, cowpeas, pigeon peas, groundnuts) and sesame. The Programme achieved visible results in seed multiplication and certification (in some cases), training of extension officers, crop promoters, and smallholder farmers, using techniques which include demonstration plots, as well as availing starter kits to smallholder farmers. Seed production. i. Cassava: The following plots where installed at IIAM research stations: around 10.4ha in Umbeluzi (2 plots, 2.5ha), Ch√≥kw√® (3 plots, 5.5ha) and Nhacoongo (2 plots, 2.4ha) and additional 63.5 ha (Gaza 40.9 ha and Inhambane 22.6 ha) from 50 seed multipliers in both provinces. ii. Horticulture: a total of 178 000 horticulture seedlings of cabbage and peppers were produced corresponding to an area of 18 ha in Lichinga and Ch√≥kw√®. iii. Legumes 10.8 ha of basic and pre-basic legume seed multiplication units were installed in Nampula (2.0ha), Mutuali (4.0ha), Lichinga (2.3 ha) and Nhacoongo (2.5 ha). About 56.25ha (Gaza 12.55ha and Inhambane 43.70ha) has been established for cowpea certified seed production from which it was harvested about 4 ton. The cowpea production was affected by drought in the critical stage of flowering causing significant reduction of the yield. About 75.9ha of common bean certified seed and 3 ha for sesame seed has been established in Niassa. Out of this, about 68.3 tons (20% of 339,3 tons target) seed of common bean has been harvested by seed multipliers and contact farmers in 2022. Training and capacity building. Around 345 crop promoters, crop inspectors and seed producers were trained in good agricultural practices, seed production, seed inspection, seed certification, and seed business plan, and market linkages. About 58 out of 512 field extension officers (11%) were trained in value chain development (common bean, cowpea, sesame vegetables, and Irish potato), and cross cutting issues.Agricultural inputs. 1000 start-up kits (for smallholder famers) were distributed covering and area of 300 hectares of cassava and 200 hectares of horticulture in Gaza province. Farm mechanization kits. Eighty kits of draught Animal including carts and implements were distributed for 40 FOs in Gaza and Inhambane provinces, each kit composed by 3 animals (2 bulls and 1 cow) and 1 cart and 1 plough. Subcomponent 1.1.2: Production and Productivity Improvement of Selected Livestock. Training and Capacitation of Animal Health Agents (AHAs) and Community Vaccinators (CoVs). 443 out of 485 (91%) community vaccinators, and 255 of 372 (69%) AHAs were trained. The community vaccinators and AHAs were equipped with protective clothing, vaccination kits and basic veterinary kit. Mechanization of farming operations. The Programme has purchased and distributed 80 mechanization kits (3 draught animals - 2 oxen and 1 cow, 1 cart and 1 plough) to smallholder farmers in the Cassava Value Chain target areas in Gaza (22 kits) and Inhambane (58 kits). A total of 40 FOs, with 1 000 HHs, benefited from these kits. Capacitation of IIAM to produce Newcastle disease (NCD) vaccines. The Programme entered into na agreement with IIAM for the production of 42 million doses of NCD vaccines. Technical specifications for NCD vaccine production laboratory equipment have been developed and tender documents are being prepared. Subcomponent 1.2: Market Linkage Investments Two Market Linkage officers, one for Niassa and the other for the Southern region has been hired. Their main role is to early identify market opportunities and proceed with actions to connect production with bigger and sustainable markets.The Programme acquired Post-harvest handling and packaging kits, and the distribution of the kits is ongoing. The kits are composed by: 150,000 POTATO packaging, 60,000 CASSAVA packaging, 50,000 BEANs packaging, 25,000 ONION packaging, 87,300 Hermetic silo bags, 2,000 Vegetable crates, and 325 Pallets. In addition, are in procurement process for the acquisition 18 processing kits, being 8 cassava processing kits and 10 Beans threshers. Construction and equipping of Mapai Slaughterhouse is being finalized.Component 2: Market-Related Climate Resilient Subcomponent 2.1: Water-Related Infrastructure The main outputs under Component 2.1 are: i) Hectares of farmland under water-related infrastructure constructed or rehabilitated; ii) Multipurpose water infrastructure constructed or rehabilitated, and iii) Water related infrastructure with environmental compliance. Ongoing the finalization of 228 ha of irrigation schemes in Ch√≥kw√® (90ha) and Guij√° (138ha) districts carried over from the PROSUL. About 50ha (at Gandlaze scheme) have been completed and are operational. The ongoing activity is installation of two pumps. Design for 516 ha of irrigation. Ongoing the process to recruit a consultant to review and update technical designs for rehabilitation and improvement of 516 ha of irrigation schemes. The distribution of the 516 ha per province and districts is as follows: Moamba (355 hectares), in Maputo Province and Ch√≥kw√® (50 ha) and Guij√° (111 hectares) in Gaza Province. The proposed schemes for review are expected to target 860 horticulture smallholder producers. Planning for 786 ha of irrigation under PROCAVA phase1. Ongoing the process to recruit a consultant to undertake irrigation technical designs for the remaining 786 hectares to reach the target of 1500 hectares under PROCAVA phase 1.Subcomponent 2.2: Market-Led Infrastructure Finalised prototypes for a total of 134 demonstration improved poultry shelters to be constructed in Maputo (8), Gaza(50), Inhambane (43), Niassa (33).  Ongoing the process to recruit the constructor.The cassava wholesale market located in Madendere (Gaza Province) is benefiting from improvement (construction of shade). In addition, the Programme completed environmental management guidelines for 3 retail markets in Inhambane and 6 livestock marketing facilities in Gaza (3), Inhambane (1), Maputo (1) and Niassa (1).Agro-processing facilities. PROCAVA finalized installation of equipment for 3 cassava processing facilities for Cassava, 2 in Zavala district and 01 in Inharrime district. Procurement and installation of other agro-processing equipment is ongoing.Component 3. Institutional and Policy Strengthening and Implementation Support Installed Niassa provincial delegation of FAR, FP, with PROCAVA support. The Government has requested IFAD to support the establishment of the remaining delegations. In order to operationalize this process, FAR, FP must develop a proposal with the overall expected cost estimates for the establishment and operationalization of the new delegations. As to ensure the readiness for expanding the Programme to the central and Northern regions,in line with PDR, the Programme must strategically start the establishment of the additional regional units in Manica for the central Provinces and Nampula for the northern region. As to ensure strengthening of the Public Extension Network the Programme allocated 15 vehicles (4x4) single cabine to 15 SDAEs in Niassa Province. The programme Implementation Manual was revised, approved by MADER and IFAD. Organization and staffing. The programme has completed the recruitment of additional staff for PROCAVA (NPMU, RPMU South and PPMU Niassa). The Programme strengthened the PMT by recruiting a new Finance, National Procurement Assistant; Financial Management Systems Administrator; Regional Procurement Officer; Regional Procurement Assistant; Regional Programme Management Assistant; two Technology Transfer Officers (Regional and Provincial) and two Market Linkage Officers (Regional and Provincial). The recruitment of the National Technology Transfer Specialist was not successful. Updated the MOU with IIAM for implementation of extension-research linking interventions including multiplication of seeds, implementation of technology demonstrations, vaccine production and training. The signing of collaboration agreements between FAR, FP Delegations and IIAM experimental units is ongoing. Signed an MoU with INAM for the provision of climate information and due activities are ongoing, as well as with DNDT for implementation of land tenure interventions and NRMPs development. PROCAVA is supporting the development of keys trategic policy instruments,namely the new PEDSA ‚Äì Agriculture Strategic Plan and PNISA ‚Äì Investment plan; the ongoing Land Law reform consultation process and the support for the Integrated Agrarian Survey (IAI). The Programme is osupporting the establishment of the Limpopo Agribusiness Special Zone‚ÄìZEEA-L. This new entity was approved by the Council of Ministers in 2021 with the main objective of providing incentives for the transformation of the agro ecological potential of the region and make the implanted structural investments viable in order to reach the maximization of economic efficiency and social well-being. ZEEA-L will cover 6 PROCAVA districts in Gaza province and need financial support to develop its first Master Plan which will guide the all development process of the area. The Programme will support the establishment of Provincial INIR delegations in the Southern provinces, considering the volume of ongoing irrigation development activities and the plans for promoting solar powered irrigation technologies. INIR will present a proposal including the estimated costs for consideration.Component 4. Disaster risk reduction and managementSub-component 4.1 - Provision of nutrition dense inputs packages for farmers, the RPSF-PROCAVA supported production of foundation seed (497,000 cassava stems, 900Kg of common beans, 2,950Kg of cowpea and 1,460kg of sesame); production of certified seeds (5,884,910 cassava stems and 31,000kg of common beans); acquisition and allocation of 7,344 starting kits; 80 kits of draught animals (100% of the planned target); 01 kit of irrigation equipment for the Moamba Block I irrigation scheme (200ha) (100% of the planned target); 20 kits for hygiene practices for the prevention of COVID-19 (200% of planned target) and 30 cooking demonstration kits for nutrition education in rural areas (100% of planned target); 1,240 landim goats (72.9% of the planned target); 2,211 chickens (24.57% of the planned). The interventions under subcomponent 4.1 contributed to increased availability of seed and other agricultural inputs, increased productivity, production and improved food security and nutrition.Sub-component 4.2 - Facilitated access to markets and post-harvest technologies, the RPSF-PROCAVA supported training of 262 Contact Farmers (94.58% of the planned target); training of 317 Animal Health Agents (85.22% of the planned target) and 444 Community Vaccinators (91.55% of the planned target).Sub-component 4.3 ‚Äì Access to financial services, the RPSF-PROCAVA supported development of the Matching Grants Manual and update of the agribusiness manual. Both tools will be adopted for training local service providers (contact farmers, animal health agents and community vaccinators) and farmer organizations to improve business skills and assist them in linking to financial institutions.Sub-component 4.4 - Delivering agriculture-related information through digital services, the RPSF-PROCAVA supported elaboration and/or update of 16 training manuals; training of 112 extension officers together with local service providers; training of 201 extension officers on nutrition and food processing who in turn were responsible for cascading the training for 2.384 rural families. The RPSF-PROCAVA also supported the acquisition and allocation of 27 motorcycles and 7 vehicles single cabin allocated to various districts of the Programme area.

2024 Narrative: UNICEF has collaborated with the Ugandan government to accelerate stunting reduction using a systems approach that integrates food systems, healthcare, and education. The organization has mobilized public financing for nutrition, leading to the government‚Äôs allocation of 2% of the Discretionary Development Equalization Grant (DDEG) for nutrition governance. Additionally, UNICEF has supported the National Nutrition Forum, which has repositioned nutrition as a key priority for economic development. These efforts have strengthened local capacity to address stunting and enhanced multi-sectoral coordination for sustainable nutrition interventions.

Description: Under this intervention, FAO supports government of Tanzania in the global efforts to combat AMR in the food and agriculture sectors using One Health (OH) approach. The Global tripartite partnership between World Health Organization (WHO), FAO and  World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) leads the process in combating AMR in the human, animal, food , agriculture and Environment sectors.  The WHO‚Äôs /FAO‚Äôs action plan on AMR focuses mainly on four areas, these include i) promoting awareness and understanding of AMR, ii) Strengthening surveillance and monitoring of antimicrobial use (AMU) and AMR, iii) Strengthening governance and iv) promoting good practices and prudent use of antimicrobial in the food and agriculture sectors.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Government of the United Kingdom

2023 Narrative: The complementary livelihoods interventions were implemented across selected LGAs in Borno and Yobe state with the objective of contributing towards restoring livelihoods and food security of affected communities living in conflict affected locations in the BAY states through gradual introduction of early recovery livelihoods activities to support youth and women to build their skills and increase self-reliance. In 2023, WFP supported a total of 4,665households across 6 LGAs on various income generating activities. Activities such as distribution of early maturing and drought resistant crop varieties were distributed to households that have access to farmland in Yobe while for sustainability of interventions, Village savings and loan association to foster financial inclusion and literacy for youth and women were established.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF: Poor diets and practices during an infants‚Äô first 1,000 days of life remain key drivers of high rates of malnutrition. Despite a steady increase over the past two decades, the Demographic Health Survey (DHS) 2023-24 shows that breastfeeding rates have stagnated at 29% since 2018. Consequently, Nigeria is off-track to achieve the SDG target of 50% by 2025 and 70% by 2030. Similarly, complementary feeding practices remain suboptimal; only 1 in 10 children (12%, according to preliminary DHS data, currently being validated) receive a minimally diverse diet, highlighting the need to accelerate and scale-up efforts to promote breastfeeding. Consequently, a National Social and Behaviour Change (SBC) strategy was finalized, launched and disseminated.FAO reached 20000 households with micro gardening inputs including vegetable seeds, fertiliser and training through FFS and Nutrition. 4500 benefitted from goat restocking intervention where each household received either 4 goats or poultry

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK (2020-2025)
Strategic priority: Pillar 2: Sustainable Economic Development
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2024, Liberia has sustained, diversified and inclusive economic growth driven by investments in agriculture, food security and job creation and is resilient to climate change and natural disasters.
Output: OUTPUT 2.1: By 2024, targeted national institutions have the capacity to develop evidence-based cross-sectoral gender-responsive policy framework and accountability mechanisms that promote sustainable livelihoods, food security and resilience to climate change
Sub-Output: Conduct gender responsive gap analyses, assessments, surveys, PHC, research studies at national and sub-national levels for informed policy advocacy and decision-making on WASH, Climate resilience, Food and nutrition security, political, social and economic empowerment of communities and stakeholders
Description:
In 2025, UN Women is providing a total of $57,000 USD (Activity ID: 2.1.2) to support several key initiatives in Liberia aimed at advancing gender equality and women's empowerment. These activities align with Activity ID: 2.1.2: Conduct gender responsive gap analyses, assessments, surveys, PHC, research studies at national and sub-national levels for informed policy advocacy and decision-making on WASH, Climate resilience, Food and nutrition security, political, social and economic empowerment of communities and stakeholders.

The specific areas of support include:

1.) Development of a new gender and climate change action plan (ccGAP) to coincide with Liberia's Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) 3.0: Two consultancies are funded for this purpose, with $15,000 USD provided by UN Women Regional Office and $5,000 USD by UN Women Liberia (Sweden's contribution).

2.) Technical support for NDC 3.0 preparation and validation events: $10,000 USD is allocated by UN Women Regional Office for these crucial activities.

3.) Desk review consultancy to inform a project on Women in Cross-Border Trade (WICBT): $7,000 USD from UN Women Regional Office will support a review of the AfCFTA regional project proposal and the Ministry of Commerce and Industry's strategic plan.

4.) Assessment of women's unpaid care work: $5,000 USD from UN Women Liberia (Sweden's contribution) will enable a thorough assessment conducted in collaboration with the Ministry of Gender, Children, and Social Protection to understand the scope and impact of unpaid care responsibilities on women's lives.

5.) Documentation of experiences of vulnerable young women and women living with HIV/AIDS: $15,000 USD from UN Women Liberia (Sweden's contribution) will support the documentation of their perspectives on UN Women's economic empowerment efforts.

This comprehensive support from UN Women aims to contribute significantly to gender-responsive policy advocacy and decision-making across various sectors in Liberia.

WFP: 
WFP is providing technical and financial support for the comprehensive food security and nutrition assessment. WFP has contributed $30,000 USD apart from the $114,000 from USAID contribution.
