Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2021 Narrative:
UN Women conducted a Gender analysis of Liberia's COVID-19 Response Plan, Emergency Relief Fund (budget allocations and expenditure). The analysis helped to monitor the gender-responsive utilization of the COVID 19 Emergency Relief Fund to address the pandemic and as an advocacy tool for ensuring that the post-recovery effort strongly considers the needs of women and girls

In March 2021, WFP supported the conduct of the Food Security and Post-Harvest Assessment which revealed that the food security situation in Liberia is dire, with an estimated 2.4 million people moderately or severely food insecure (45 percent and 5 percent of the population, respectively), an increase of 50 percent since the last assessment in September 2020. In April of the same year, WFP conducted a livelihood assessment in concession areas in four counties (Grand Cape Mount, Nimba, Sinoe and Maryland). The assessment  revealed that 69 percent of residents in concession areas depend on their own production and sale of crops for income generation. The study also found that 52 percent of the respondent‚Äôs household heads have no formal school education and 75 percent of household heads‚Äô spouses have also never attended school. This lack of formal education makes it difficult to engage in formal employment, thus making agriculture the key livelihood source for many households engaged in the production of cassava, rubber, rice, vegetables, etc. WFP also conducted a market functionality index that revealed prevailing situations in 57 local markets in terms of price of commodities, accessibility, availability, etc.
A nationwide RAPID FOOD SECURITY NUTRITION, LIVELIHOODS  AND MARKETS ASSESSMENT (RFSNLMA 2022) was conducted by WFP, FAO, UNICEF and WHO in all 15 counties, 112 districts and Monrovia (urban Montserrado) with 4,160 randomly selected households interviewed, Middle Upper Arm Circumference of 1,213 children (6 to 59 months) measured and their mothers interviewed for morbidity 334 mothers with children 6 to 23 months interviewed for dietary diversity,  4131 women interviewed for dietary diversity FGDs in 34 markets and 383 traders interviewed. The assessment shows that on the average, 47% of the population of Liberia food insecure. Additionally, WFP conducted two other assessments (Value Chain assessment and Post-Harvest assessment) to help improve the agricultural sector and make communities more resilient.
2022 Narrative: UNFPA through the Ministry of Gender trained one hundred twenty six (126) SGBV service providers from across the 15 counties in the utilization of a digital data collection platform called Kobo Tool Box. This system is expected to temporarily resolve the challenge of data inaccuracy and delayed reporting by migrating the data from paper based system which have been used in the fifteen counties for the collection of Gender Based Violence data to a digital platform..
2023 Narrative: ILO: In collaboration with the UN Women, undertook a gender audit of Liberia's Labour Practices Law. The study comprehensively assessed and analyzed the policies, organizational processes, and structures of the Ministry of Labor (MoL). The goal of the audit is to identify existing gaps and recommend interventions to strengthen the ministry's commitment to enhancing capacities for gender mainstreaming at all levels, aligning with the Labour Laws of Liberia.  United Nations Population FundAs part of the 2022 LPHC, UNFPA supported LISGIS to produce national census thematic reports on gender, Children, Adolescents and YouthPeople with disabilities, elder people and special population,Migration and urbanization, Labor force and employment, agriculture, non monetary poverty, housing conditions and households facilities, mortality, fertility, population projections, education and literacy, health and sanitation, etc. This process is ongoing and the next step is the production of these reports at county level. UNFPA also supported the MFDP to produce the national report on the AADPD plus ten review. This report includes topics on dignity and equity (Human Rights, Poverty eradication, Gender equality and women empowerment, GBV/ harmful practices, Education of YP and girls, Youth employment), health (Universal access to SRH services (maternal health, skilled birth attendance, FP and unmet need, CSE, HIV and STI, Health system strengthening), place and mobility (Environment and UrbanizationMigration, including the integration and re-integration of migrants) Data and Statistics(Strengthening statistical capacity, CRVS, census, survey, administrative and other data for planning, monitoring and evaluation)UN Women: In partnership with the Ministry of Labor (MoL) and the Ministry of Gender, Children, and Social Protection, UN Women carried out a gender audit aimed at thoroughly evaluating and analyzing the MoL's policies, organizational processes, and structures. The goal was to pinpoint existing deficiencies and suggest measures to bolster the ministry's dedication to gender mainstreaming, in accordance with the Labour Laws of Liberia. The gender audit consultant examined key elements that support gender mainstreaming, including the effectiveness of leadership, the execution of the Gender and Social Inclusion Policy framework, the allocation of financial resources, and the technical expertise for gender analysis. A detailed report and policy brief were produced from the gender audit, outlining the findings and recommendations. This provided a summary of the audit's extent, methods, and proposed steps to amplify the MoL's ability to implement gender mainstreaming at every level.In addition, UN Women‚Äôs Digital Inclusion for Women‚Äôs Economic Empowerment (D4WEE) Project, assessed from October to December 2023, demonstrated strategic planning and partnerships, notably with the Orange Foundation and the Central Bank of Liberia, leading to sustainable empowerment. Despite delays in certain components, the project enhanced women‚Äôs market access and education, with the Buy from Women digital platform improving agricultural productivity. Preliminary work for digitalizing VSLAs and distributing solar products is underway.IFAD: One gender gap analysis assessment completed and recommendations therefrom informed a gender action plan that is being rolled out in IFAD projects. Financial inclusion outcome survey for one IFAD project was undertaken in 6 counties. IFAD projects further supported the Women Symposium on Agriculture. The symposium provided the platform to drive on agriculture development for the vulnerable population, especially women. There were 90 participants - 72 women and 18 men, from the project counties World Food Programe: Gender responsive assessments conducted for food and nutrition information, market information, post-harvest management and food supply chain information.
2024 Narrative: UN Women conducted a Women's Economic Empowerment (WEE) situational analysis in Liberia, which showed significant progress in advancing WEE, particularly in the areas of digital inclusion, political participation, and leadership. However, challenges persist, including limited access to credit, lack of training opportunities, and the need for a comprehensive WEE policy. Key Findings:Care Economy: Limited awareness and knowledge about the care economy. Lack of data and formal structures. Insufficient government intervention. Green and Blue Economies: Lack of training in understanding the green and blue economies. Limited awareness about the green and blue economies among women business leaders. Lack of special financing funds to support women's participation in the green and blue economies. Financial Inclusion, Entrepreneurship, and Trade: Limited credit facilities and high interest rates. Lack of property to guarantee loan payments and bureaucratic bottlenecks. Limited knowledge on AfCFTA and cross-border trade opportunities. Lack of women empowerment and entrepreneurship development policy. Recommendations:Develop a National Care Policy and establish a care taskforce. Conduct a time-use survey and develop a care roadmap. Reskill and upskill training for women's participation in the green and blue economies. Provide technical assistance for gender-responsive policies. Engage women in waste management and provide disaster resilience financial support. Organize a national women empowerment policy dialogue. Collaborate with CBL to provide support for WEE. Develop a Women Economic Empowerment Policy. Next Steps:Continue to advocate for increased government intervention in the care economy. Support the development of gender-responsive policies in the green and blue economies. Work with financial institutions to improve access to credit for women entrepreneurs. Facilitate training and awareness-raising on WEE, cross-border trade, and AfCFTA. Support the development of a comprehensive WEE policy.In Addition, the National Disaster Management Authority has been reviewing its gender policy and 2022-2024 Gender Action Plan, which UN Women helped develop. Their internal review process has considered the integration of gender considerations into disaster preparedness and response strategies. The Gender Unit has transitioned to a Gender Department, now led by a Gender Director and an Assistant Gender Director. The agency's Monitoring and Evaluation (ME) Unit is engaged in gender-responsive data collection, analysis, and reporting.UNDP: In 2024, conducted a successful Gender-Responsive Conflict Analysis (GRCA) pilot assessment in Nimba and Grand Cape Mount counties in collaboration with the European Union focused on land access and resource conflicts among women and youth. The recommendations from this assessment, once implemented, are expected to reduce gender disparities, particularly for women and youth, and contribute to sustainable peace. Next, inter-agency collaboration has been strengthened, facilitating the alignment of gender goals across national development strategies. This has contributed to increased advocacy for gender equality and has influenced positive shifts in national budget discussions. A notable outcome includes a measurable increase in gender-specific budget allocations in key sectors such as health, education, and social protection. Overall, the intervention has laid a solid foundation for sustained institutional commitment to gender equality and more inclusive governance at the national level.

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way

2024 Narrative: WFP‚Äôs school feeding programme significantly contributed to respond to food insecurity and improve education outcomes. Through daily onsite meals to children aged 3-12 years in pre-primary and primary education, WFP aimed to boost enrolment, improve retention, reduce dropout rates, and ultimately contribute to enhancing the quality of education.  Achievements are shown by the number of schools and people who benefited from the programme. Meals were delivered to 151,378 school-aged children across 421 schools. In addition, deworming tablets and vitamin A supplements were provided to 77,482 school children (including 32,866 boys and 44,616 girls) in 364 schools. As part of the school feeding programme, 1,440 cooks were provided cash and sensitised on hygiene practices. Moreover, 4,719 individuals (of which 2,226 women and 2,493 men) received diverse trainings, such as on social behavioural change, hygiene practices, and procurement, to achieve zero hunger goals.

Description: One of WFP‚Äôs most significant achievements was supporting the establishment and launch of the Scaling Up Nutrition Business Network (SBN). This initiative reinforced WFP‚Äôs role in facilitating private sector investments in nutritious food value chains. The SBN played a key role in consolidating initial investments in selected local rice millers to fortify rice, thereby enhancing the nutritional value of school meals. The SBN launch offered an opportunity for local food processors and small holder farmers to invest in the production of nutritious foods and be connected to potential markets through the SBN platforms to ensure equitable access to nutritious food, particularly in remote and underserved communities in Ghana.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK (2020-2025)
Strategic priority: Pillar 2: Sustainable Economic Development
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2024, Liberia has sustained, diversified and inclusive economic growth driven by investments in agriculture, food security and job creation and is resilient to climate change and natural disasters.
Output: OUTPUT 2.1: By 2024, targeted national institutions have the capacity to develop evidence-based cross-sectoral gender-responsive policy framework and accountability mechanisms that promote sustainable livelihoods, food security and resilience to climate change
Sub-Output: Support communities to increase productivity, enhance sustainable livelihoods, resilience capacities, social inclusion, food and nutrition security
Description:
13 women-based farming cooperatives are practicing climate-smart and nutrition-sensitive agriculture techniques. This is evidenced by the CSA techniques the women farmers are using in planting and growing rice, cassava, plantains, and maize (corn). The women are also practicing nutrition-sensitive agriculture demonstrated by their growing of different varieties of vegetables.  

WFP - 750 smallholder farmers received different training to enhance sustainable agriculture production and input support which helped them to adopt climate smart agriculture practices to increase production. Vulnerable farmer organizations resilience capacity strengthened through providing them with training, agricultural inputs, and machinery support to increase production and value addition.
Additionally, WFP created market access to smallholders farmer groups through purchase of locally grown food commodities (861.91 MT) at the value of US$1,900,000.00. This helped to boost agriculture production of smallholder farmers including increasing household incomes and improve food access for smallholder famers and families .

In 2025, UN Women is providing a total of 82,000 USD (Activity ID: 2.1.3) to support communities in Liberia to increase productivity, enhance sustainable livelihoods, resilience capacities, social inclusion, financial inclusion, and food and nutrition security. This support aligns with "Activity ID: 2.1.3: Support communities to increase productivity, enhance sustainable livelihoods, resilience capacities, social inclusion, financial inclusion, food and nutrition security, including the provision of agri-equipment, pre & post-harvest management training, etc" and encompasses several key initiatives.

Firstly, efforts to strengthen agricultural productivity and sustainability include Solar Power Agri-Equipment Support for Women Cooperatives, receiving two grants totaling 19,000 USD (14,000 USD from the UN Women HQ small grant and 5,000 USD from UN Women). This aims to enhance agricultural practices through the adoption of sustainable energy solutions. Secondly, promoting financial inclusion is addressed through Financial Inclusion Support for Women Cooperatives, allocated a budget of 20,000 USD from UN Women to improve women's access to formal financial services. A significant component focuses on Empowering Rural and Young Women through Capacity Building, with a budget of 25,000 USD from UN Women. This initiative targets women from UN Women-supported networks (e.g., NRWS, NaPHWoL, AWICBT, LMA, etc.) and will provide training in financial inclusion, green and blue economies, entrepreneurship and trade, care economy awareness and formalization, and digital literacy skills.

Furthermore, leveraging digital platforms and centers is a key strategy, with Scaling Up the Buy from Women Digital Platform and Establishing Digital Centers supported by a 10,000 USD budget from UN Women. This will enhance the digital platform and expand access to digital literacy and support centers. Building climate resilience and leadership is addressed through NDC 3.0 Training for Youth and Gender Climate Working Group, allocated 5,000 USD from UN Women for capacity building in climate action. Finally, Capacity Development on Organizational Development and Leadership Skills with AWICBT will receive 3,000 USD from UN Women to strengthen the organization.

These interconnected initiatives demonstrate UN Women's commitment in 2025 to fostering holistic and sustainable development for women in Liberia, aligning with the broader goals of increased productivity, enhanced livelihoods, and greater resilience.

WFP:
WFP is supporting 2,900 SHFs from 65 farmer groups in Grand Cape, Grand Bassa, Grand Gedeh, Bong, Nimba, Lofa, and Gbarpolu Counties. These farmers are receiving climate smart agriculture training, farmer tool and equipment (Power tillers, rice mills, cassava processors etc.), including storage and agri business facilities. WFP Liberia has linked these SHFs to its Home-Grown School Feeding Programme thus creating market access. The 2,900 SHFs received food assistance through value voucher redemption process from retailers. 300 hectares of lowland rice and vegetables are under cultivation.
Agency abbreviations: FAO; IFAD; ILO; UN Women; UNDP; UNHCR; UNIDO; WFP
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Fund for Agricultural Development; International Labour Organisation; UN Women; United Nations Development Programme; United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; United Nations Industrial Development Organization; United Nations World Food Programme

Implementation partners: Liberia Refugee Repatriation and Resettlement Commission; Liberian Forestry Development Authority; Liberian Ministry of Agriculture; Liberian Ministry of Commerce and Industries; Liberian Ministry of Gender, Children and Social Protection; Liberian Ministry of Internal Affairs; Liberian Ministry of Youths and Sports; National Fisheries and Acquacluture Authority
SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Geography: Montserrado; Nimba; Lofa; Grand Kru; Gbarpolu; Grand Gedeh; Grand Cape Mount; Grand Bassa; Bong; Bomi; Rivercess; River Gee; Maryland; Liberia; Sinoe; Margibi
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Support Functions
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2021 Narrative: UN Women has built the capacities of over 13 women-based farming cooperatives on climate-smart agriculture including for their women members' access to literacy, numeracy, and business skills classes. In addition, 40 Savings and Loan Associations have been supported with over 1,000 rural women farmers in Lofa, Bong, Nimba, Margibi, Grand Gedeh, and Grand Cape Mount Counties benefitting. FAO is empowering rural households under the United Arab Emirates funded project. This intervention is boosting the resilience of over 1500 rural women, 300 of a potential 720 hectares were cultivated for lowland rice and vegetable, using improved varieties of rice mainly NERICA-L19, and high value (tomatoes, cucumber, lettuce, water melon) and high-yielding vegetables. To reduce the burden of manual labor and increase food production and productivity, WFP procured and delivered various agricultural equipment including rice mills, cassava grinders and power tillers to the seven counties (Grand Bassa, Margibi, Maryland, River Gee, Sinoe, Cape Mount and Nimba) to 1,000 smallholder farmers (700 women; 300 men). Farmers were trained on the operation, maintenance and repairs of these equipment. ILO established and supported 7 youth-led agricultural cooperatives in Bong and Lofa Counties. This will ensure livelihood opportunities for the respective groups in these cooperatives. Entrepreneurial skills of over 100 youth were built on how to start and improve their business. Entrepreneurial skills of 108 vulnerable women and youth were built on how to start and improve their business. Over 700 targeted women and young women in from Lofa, Bong, Nimba, Margibi, and Grand Bassa counties are investing in nutrition-sensitive and climate-smart agriculture through capacity building support from UN Women and partners. FAO provided support to the Government of Liberia through the Ministry of Agriculture/Food Security and Nutrition Division and the Scaling Up Nutrition Movement Secretariat, to develop Liberia's First Nutrition Strategy titled the "Liberia Multi-Sectoral Nutrition Cost strategic Plan 2023-2027". The strategic plan incorporates sector-specific actions for reducing stunting among children 0-36 months and reducing all forms of malnutrition among women and children under five. In 2022, 681 (545f, 136m) smallholder farmers are supported by WFP through capacity strengthening activities in Grand Cape Mount, Nimba, Maryland and Grand Bassa Counties. Support provided to these farmers included, establishment of two cooperatives duly registered with the government of Liberia; provision of agricultural equipment; technical support on pre-harvest and harvest; food asset creation related activities to create irrigation system including field layout (63mt of assorted commodities was distributed to 450 smallholder farmers to create productive/community asset such as lowland development/rehabilitation, community bridge construction); support on storage, etc. Communities in Grand Cape County were supported on the production of improve and innovative charcoal for livelihoods and resilience. The capacity of the groups is reinforced so that they are able to sell their quality products directly to schools, securing a stable market for the farmers and a reliable source of fresh quality food for the school canteens, and other buyers. The existence of the associations replaces the sale through middle men, thereby ensuring full financial returns to the farmers‚Äô associations. UNHCR supported CRS, the livelihood partner to train selected host community members and refugees in small business development. After the training UNHCR provided grants to beneficiaries to start up their own business. Beneficiaries are growing their businesses rapidly.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, IFAD funded projects provided inputs and trainings on climate smart agricultural practices to 2400 cocoa farmers between Nimba and Lofa counties, to improve the quality and increase their cocoa production. Under the Smallholder Rural Transformation and Business Revitalization project, co-financed with the World Bank, around 2500 farmers in the rice, horticultural and palm oil value chain have benefited of matching grants on the basis of business plans aimed at improving their production activities or small processing businesses in rural areas.
2023 Narrative: UNHCR supported CRS, as the livelihood partner to train selected host community members and refugees in small business development. After the training UNHCR provided grants to beneficiaries to start up their own business. Beneficiaries are growing their businesses rapidly.ILO: The entrepreneurial skills of and livelihoods opportunities of 264 vulnerable groups including women, youth and persons living with disabilities have been built on business development and management at the community level. As a result of this intervention, all 264 (females: 158 and males: 106) of them are now involved in livelihood activities through business plans financing. This has led to resilience livelihood of these beneficiaries for sustainable and inclusive economic and human development. UN Women has made a significant impact on the lives of over 1,200 female farmers across Lofa, Bong, and Nimba Counties by providing them with the tools and knowledge necessary to enhance their productivity and ensure sustainable livelihoods. Through comprehensive capacity-building programs, these women have been educated in disaster risk reduction (DRR) strategies, resource governance, and environmental preservation, equipping them to better manage their resources and protect their local ecosystems.Moreover, UN Women‚Äôs financial inclusion initiatives have been instrumental in breaking down barriers to credit access for these female farmers. By enabling them to secure loans, these women have been able to make meaningful agricultural investments, which in turn has led to the establishment of thriving agri-businesses. This entrepreneurial leap has not only bolstered their economic stability but has also contributed to the overall prosperity of their communities.The specialized training provided by UN Women has empowered these women to launch and manage successful agri-businesses, fostering a sense of social inclusion and community spirit. The result is a more resilient community where food security is enhanced, and women are key drivers of economic growth and environmental stewardship. This holistic approach by UN Women has laid the foundation for a future where female farmers are not just participants but leaders in creating a more productive and sustainable agricultural sector.IFAD: In 2023, IFAD funded projects including TCEP, TCEP-II and BCRP supported 11,366 (TCEP=4,089, TCEP-II=5,333, BCRP=1,944)smallholder farmers in cocoa production, of which 9,422 benefitted from replacement program while 1,944 benefitted under the BCRP as new beneficiaries. Cumulatively , the IFAD funded projects have supported about 18,953 smallholder cocoa farmers, with female constituting 31% and youth 32% respectively.As a result of the project support to these farmers in 2023, about 5,197 hectares are under cultivation using climate resilience practices in cocoa production. To date, about 10483.88 hectares under cultivation for cocoa production under the three projects. For improved and climate resilience agriculture practices, trainings were conducted for Lead Farmers using the Farmers' Field School approach. To increase production, IFAD project distributed agricultural inputs to 5,627 smallholder farmers to enhance sustainable livelihoods and address food security concerns. The project also provided nutrition trainings to 95 farmers in project counties.World Food Programme: Capacity of eighty-nine smallholder farmer's groups enhanced to increase production and productivity and reduce food insecurity.FAOFAO provided support to the Government of Liberia through the Ministry of Agriculture/Nutrition Division and the Scaling Up Nutrition Movement Secretariat, developed Liberia's First Nutrition Strategy titled the "Liberia Multi-Sectoral Nutrition Cost Strategic Plan 2023-2027. The strategy plan incorporates sector-specific actions for stunting reduction among children 0-36 months and reduction of all forms of malnutrition among women and children under five.The Multi-Sectoral has been validated and launched.
2024 Narrative: An additional 1,750 ha, of land was cultivated for cocoa farmers. Additional 2,782 cocoa farmers were recruited under IFAD projects in 2024 bringing to a total 30,337 farming households supported under the Tree Crop and Climate resilient projects. The provision of improved hybrid cocoa seeds provides the foundation for improving productivity. In 2024, additional 2 ha were planted with 2,222 at the National Cocoa Seed Garden, bringing the total of 18 ha out of 19 ha currently being cultivated with about 19,998 cocoa trees planted. the National COcoa Seed Garden in Nimba will play a critical role of providing high yielding planting material for Liberian cocoa farmers. Productivity under the STAR Project has improved significantly with farmer groups of 4,620 smallholders cultiviting some 840ha of rice and achieving higher yields ranging from 3 to 4ton/ha. Under the Building Climate Resilience Project, about 4,120 rice farmers (1,257 male adults, 1,008 female adults, 934 male youth, and 921 female youth) have benefited from agro-inputs, development of lowlands, training on good agronomic practices and technical support and cultivate some 279 ha of Inland valley swampland (IVS). In addition to the development of IVS, the project has provided 25 sets of rice mills aimed at reducing post-harvest losses and decreasing manual labor. Additionally, 52 power tillers and other production inputs have been supplied, as well as technical training in rice production. IFAD projects also work with lead farmers to provide technical advisory services to farmers. In 2024 about 120 lead farmers were trained bringing to about 684 lead farmers trained trained and providing community level extension advisory services to farmers in their communities. WFP - 750 smallholder farmers received different training to enhance sustainable agriculture production and input support which helped them to adopt climate smart agriculture practices to increase production. Vulnerable farmer organizations resilience capacity strengthened through providing them with training, agricultural inputs, and machinery support to increase production and value addition. Additionally, WFP created market access to smallholders farmer groups through purchase of locally grown food commodities (861.91 MT) at the value of US$1,700,000.00. This helped to boost agriculture production of smallholder farmers including increase in household incomes and improve food access for smallholder famers and families .UN Women has focused on supporting rural communities in Liberia to increase productivity, enhance sustainable livelihoods and build resilience. Recognizing the disproportionate impact of economic shocks and natural disasters on women, interventions have included:Disaster Preparedness and Resilience: Training on risk management and access to early warning systems have been provided to enhance community resilience, with a particular focus on empowering women to take an active role in disaster preparedness and response.Improved Livelihoods and Productivity: The introduction of solar-powered equipment and clean cooking technologies has not only improved the quality of life for rural women by reducing time spent on domestic tasks and mitigating health risks associated with traditional cooking methods but also increased their productivity by enabling income-generating activities and supporting food security.These initiatives have contributed to broader efforts to promote social inclusion and ensure food and nutrition security within rural communities, ultimately empowering women and strengthening their ability to cope with economic and environmental challenges.UNDP: Inter-agency collaboration has been strengthened, facilitating the alignment of gender goals across national development strategies. This has contributed to increased advocacy for gender equality and has influenced positive shifts in national budget discussions. A notable outcome includes a measurable increase in gender-specific budget allocations in key sectors such as health, education, and social protection. Overall, the intervention has laid a solid foundation for sustained institutional commitment to gender equality and more inclusive governance at the national level.

2021 Narrative:
Organization: WFP
The multisectoral programme was delivered in ‚Äòat risk‚Äô zones identified in Yobe state informed by the high prevalence of stunting (60 %) and level of food insecurity. The project focused on a multisectoral approach with a particular emphasis on the integration of CBT for nutrition and livelihoods.  The integrated nutrition and livelihood programme targeted children 6-23 months and PLW. The integration, however, was implemented in only one of the 4 targeted wards of Bade LGA. As part of the enrolment process, it was ensured that the children possessed immunization cards and the pregnant women ANC card in other to enhance uptake of these services in the health facilities. The programme was planned to kickstart in April 2021 to March 2022. However, the actual cash transfers to beneficiaries commenced in July 2021. Beneficiaries registered in the programme received NGN7,000 in the form of e-vouchers on monthly basis.  The programme reached 36765 beneficiaries (46%) of the planned target of 80,000 (children an PLW).

Challenges 

Setting up nutrition e-voucher programme and identification of beneficiaries based on the targeting criteria contributed to the late start and lower than expected achievement.  

Lessons learnt 

--Timely start of similar integrated nutrition programme in the future.
2022 Narrative: UNWFP - To improve the therapeutic feeding for malnourished children, WFP in collaboration with the Nutrition sector and the State Ministry of Health undertook the expansion of nutrition treatment centres to more Health centres in Borno and Yobe States with support of funds from donors.

Description: UNIDO: The project addresses deficiencies in regard to the country‚Äôs standard-setting practices, its regulatory framework and the overall performance of Liberia‚Äôs food control system. They aim to enhance the national market surveillance system and its enforcement mechanism by establishing a coordinated risk-based inspection approach that is applied systematically. Furthermore, the project responds to the need to strengthen public-private dialogue and collaboration among all relevant actors. In this regard, the Liberian Task Force on Food Safety (LTFFS) will be established, with a particular focus on assuring the engagement of relevant private sector representatives and encouraging their active and voluntary contributions to the enhancement of the overall performance of the national food system.

Contributing partners: African Development Bank; Embassy of Norway; European Union; United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: South Sudan Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security; South Sudan National Bureau of Statistics

2023 Narrative: FAO:Between January and June 2023, FAO has continued to support the regular monitoring of various indicators that contribute towards foods security and nutrition analysis. This includes market prices, exchange rates, rainfall, crop performance, and livestock-related information, which is then uploaded onto the CLIMIS portal (www.climis-southsudan.org) that is developed and maintained by FAO on behalf of South Sudan's National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).The 29th round of the Food Security and Nutrition Monitoring SYstem (FSNMS) survey was conducted between July and August 2029 and its results used for the IPC analysis. The IPC analysis was conducted between 25 September and 07 October, with the findings released officially on 06 November 2023. The CFSAM report for the 2022 cropping season was released in June 2023, and the analysis workshop for the CFSAM report for the 2023 cropping season will be conducted in December 2023, with the report likely to be released in the 1st quarter of 2024.. All of these efforts are geared towards informing various food security and nutrition analysis processes that will then contribute towards ongoing efforts to enhance governance of the food security and nutrition sector.
2024 Narrative: FAO established a Food Security Information Systems (for improved food security and nutrition governance) and has continued to support the South Sudan National Bureau of Statistics and Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security in the monitoring of the food security and nutrition situation in South Sudan through regular (monthly) updates to the CLIMIS portal (http://www.climis-southsudan.org/) with data on market prices, exchange rates, rainfall, crop production, IPC data etc. Additionally, FAO in collaboration with UNICEF and WFP conducted capacity building  to ToTs and field-level enumerators for the annual Food Security and Nutrition Monitoring Survey (FSNMS)  for 40 counties; data collection commenced and ongoing as at the time of this report. The data will be used for the IPC analysis, monitoring of the food security and nutrition situation in South Sudan, resilience analysis as well as a key data source for the South Sudan HNO and HRP.

Description: UNIDO: Aiming at further strengthening the required enabling institutional environment, the meso-level interventions of the project are focusing on developing a voluntary national 3rd party food safety assurance (vTPA) scheme which is based on internationally existing basic food safety/hygiene principles and guidelines. Responding to the needs of the supported value chains, and the developed scheme in specific, national food testing laboratories and certification bodies will be upgraded towards accreditation. Additionally, the meso-level component of the project aims to strengthen the overall educational system at the university and vocational training centre level by introducing and/or upgrading existing food safety-related curricula. This will ensure the availability of a technically skilled workforce which is essential for advancing the country‚Äôs food safety agenda in both the medium and long-term.

Outcome: Outcome 2. Local economies are recovered and conditions and coping strategies are improved for vulnerable communities to end severe food insecurity.

Description: In kind food assistance and cash based transfers provided to households who participated in asset creation activities
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund; United Nations Office for Project Services; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Support Functions
2021 Narrative:
In 2021, WFP through its conditional food/cash assistance for assets program (FFA)provided food and cash assistance to 707,600 beneficiaries (306,300M,  404,300F) in 79 counties of the 10 states of South Sudan.  252,623 beneficiaries in Kuajok, Yambio, Aweil, Juba and Kapoeta who participated in creating various assets like crop and vegetable gardens, community access roads, dykes, fish/water ponds received cash while  457,977 FFA beneficiaries who participated in asset creation received in-kind assistance.

In 2021, UNICEF continued its efforts to support operationalizing and mainstreaming humanitarian cash 
programming. UNICEF concluded the implementation of the voucher project which focused on provision of hygiene 
materials in response to COVID-195,180 households received vouchers to access soap and a hand washing bucket in Aweil, Bor and Bentiu counties. In addition, 1106 extremely vulnerable households in Bor and Malakal received
unconditional cash assistance to cover their basic needs. The households for the unconditional cash support project were identified and registered by UNICEF through a collaborative effort with local partners and community leaders. A part of the WASH voucher pilot in the Juba Protection of Civilian (POC) site, 9,125 households were registered on the SCOPE platform who will be targeted to be assisted to access water through a voucher modality in collaboration with WFP. The greatest challenge in 2021 was the continued depreciation of the SSP against the dollar, resulting in the rising price of basic commodities and reduced purchasing power for vulnerable households targeted with cash programmes

During the reporting period, UNOPS  rehabilitated different infrastructures through cash for work to a tune of $3.5M.  30,600 vulnerable beneficiary households were identified and worked on the different subprojects, including rehabilitation and maintenance of 37 community access roads, 23 agricultural projects , 16 water drainage rehabilitation and general cleaning for 50. Altogether, 126 public works were completed
2022 Narrative: WFP supported 755,020 beneficiaries with approximately 15,284.611mt in form of in-kind food assistance and 41,48,947.96 $ in form of cash assistance. UNOPS through the World Bank Funded South Sudan Safety Net Project (SSSNP) supported 35,607 households. The households received cash transfers worth US$9,4 million for participating in (and completed) 369 public work projects. The public works consisted of road maintenance and/ rehabilitation (199), agriculture (31), general cleaning (106), drainage works (9), and facilities construction and/renovation (24) . The achievement across the sub-projects were 572 Km of road maintained and /rehabilited, 2390 acres planted yielding over 1300 tones of produce, 7063 acres of land cleared/cleaned, 82 Km of drainage created/rehabilitated, and 41,000 square meters of facilities constructed and or rehabilitated

Strategic priority: Strengthen inclusive access to services especially for those most left behind

Output: Inequalities in all sectors are addressed by equitable distribution and effective management of resources including through the use of innovation and technology
Sub-Output: School children benefit from enhanced school meals through fortification and consumption of locally available nutritious foods
Description:
WFP strengthened its work on the nutrition-climate nexus by partnering with local NGOs and the Ministry of Food and Agriculture. Through an integrated resilience (food-for-assets) intervention, nutritionally vulnerable households adopted climate-smart, nutrition-sensitive livelihoods. Key interventions included:
‚Ä¢	Establishing micro-irrigation systems to ensure vegetable availability during prolonged dry spells.
‚Ä¢	Providing farm inputs such as improved seedlings, fertilizers, irrigation tools, crop threshers, and hermetic silos to enhance productivity and minimize post-harvest losses.
‚Ä¢	Supporting diversified crop cultivation, including orange-fleshed sweet potatoes (OFSP), soybeans, and leafy green vegetables
‚Ä¢	Provision of value vouchers through the Ghana Health Service, prioritizing households under the Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP) programme
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ; DSM-Firmenich; Government of France; Government of Japan; United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: Ghana Health Service; Ghana Ministry of Food & Agriculture-Women in Agricultural Development Directorate

SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 3 Good Health and Well-being

2021 Narrative:
WFP through its food/cash assistance for assets program(FFA) supported over 707,600 beneficiaries in 79 counties of the ten States of South Sudan in 2021.The choice of food/cash assistance was determined through careful assessment of the market functionality/food security situation analysis as well as community consultation. WFP employed the three pronged approach of integrated context analysis, seasonal livelihoods programming and  community based participatory planning to design, plan and implement these resilience programs. Through the CBPP, the communities were able to lead the discussions in setting priorities tailored to their local context. The type of assets created include crop and vegetable gardens, community access roads, dykes, water ponds and fish ponds, drainage channels. In 2021, WFP also piloted the pastoral Food Assistance for Assets that targeted 40,816 beneficiaries in cattle camps in Terekeka, Awerial, Rumbek East and Awerial counties and assets created were specific to these cattle camps like cattle camp fencing, draining channels.
dykes, tukuls in Terekeka, Awerial, Kapoeta North, Rumbek East
2022 Narrative: WFP supported targeted communities in community asset creation such as: crop and vegetable farms, community access roads, swallow wells, drainage channels,flood protection dikes, community water ponds, tree seedlings etc. The asset creation activities were implemented in all the 10 states.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2024-2028)
Strategic priority: PROSPERITY
Outcome: By 2028, Mauritius has a resilient, sustainable, and inclusive economy that allows all people, especially youth, women and persons living with disability, to access sustainable livelihoods and food security.
Output: Food security is enhanced for all ‚Äì especially children, youth, women and other vulnerable groups ‚Äì ensuring the transition of food, water and energy systems towards sustainability.
Sub-Output: Implementation of food labelling and nutrient profiling
Description: WHO provided technical inputs in the review and finalization of the front food pack labelling regulations.  WHO shared best practices from other countries and international guidelines on regulation of food labelling to promote food safety and healthy eating in the population.  These new regulations will address unhealthy diets which is one of the main risk factors for Non-communicable Diseases and obesity in particular.  As regards to nutrient profiling, work has started with the adaptation of existing data collection tool for data collection.  WHO has already built capacity of two key local technical persons on the AFRO nutrient profiling model which will help in the adaption of the national nutrient profiling to restrict the marketing of unhealthy food to children.  This will help in addressing unhealthy diets at an early age and promotion of healthy foods in the population
Agencies: World Health Organization
Contributing partners: World Health Organization
Implementation partners: Mauritius Ministry of Agro-Industry and Food Security; Mauritius Ministry of Health and Wellness
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women's empowerment
Gender marker narrative: No indication of gender contribution
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: WHO provided technical assistance in the review of the draft front pack food labelling legislation developed by the Mauritius Food Standard Agency to ensure these are aligned with WHO global recommendations and guidelines to promote food safety. Best practices from other countries were also shared to the country with regards to the cuff-off points for sodium, fat and sugar levels. The front pack food labelling has been finalized and approved by the country. The front pack food labelling will provide consumers with more information on the salt, sugar and fat contents in food that are marketed in the country so they can make healthy food choices. It will contribute to the fight of noncommunicable diseases by address unhealthy diets, one of the main NCD risk factors.National Harmonization strategy developed by Min of Agro-Industry and Food Security, Ministry of Health and Wellness in joint collaboration with WHO in view of aligning national food laws to international standards (codex Alimentarius) to promote food safety. Prior to the development of the national strategy, 30 multi-sectoral stakeholders from key sectors including Academic and NGOs were trained on harmonization and following which, 20 e-working groups have been set up to work on reviewing of existing standards and development of new standards to promote food safety in the country. Work in progress. In the same vein, advocacy kit and communication materials have been developed and disseminated to promote the country‚Äôs participation in codex work at national, regional and global level, in addition of capacity building of local multisectoral stakeholders on the importance of Codex Alimentarius international standards to ensure food safety at all stages from farm to fork.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK (2020-2025)
Strategic priority: Pillar 2: Sustainable Economic Development
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2024, Liberia has sustained, diversified and inclusive economic growth driven by investments in agriculture, food security and job creation and is resilient to climate change and natural disasters.
Output: OUTPUT 2.3: By 2024, access, awareness and sustainable use of appropriate Resources, Assets,  Services and Markets by poor and rural producers, households, value-chain actors, and communities, including women and  youth improved.
Sub-Output: Provide rural women, smallholder farmers with access to finance around food value chains
Description:
Over 40 Savings and Loans Associations are:
Breaking down barriers to finance ‚Äì The associations are helping the women overcome common barriers, and access to finance has been one such barrier for many of them because there is a lack of limited or no formal financial institutions in their communities.
Empowering women to become changemakers ‚Äì The women in the associations are investing in CSA and vegetable production because of loans taken from their respective SLAs. They have been able to make a profit. Also, the SLAs are not just about increasing income or serving as a social protection fund, they have also empowered the women to become active players in their various communities.
Promoting solidarity and equality ‚Äì Being part of such successful community associations has led to inspiring gains in the women‚Äôs social status. They are starting their own businesses and are participating in community decision-making processes at the household and community levels. Being able to contribute financially within their families has even put the women on a more equal footing with their spouses.
Contributing to peace building ‚Äì financial freedom for women from a combination of the SLAs and other businesses is enabling women to support peacebuilding efforts at the community level. 

WFP:
WFP is providing 65 smallholder farmer groups access to micro finance through the VSLA activities under the Integrated Food Security and PBF-Projects. 

UNDP Accelerated Community Development Programme (ACDP) support rural women smallholder farmers with access to finance around food value chains.
Agency abbreviations: FAO; IFAD; ILO; UN Women; UNDP; WFP
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Fund for Agricultural Development; International Labour Organisation; UN Women; United Nations Development Programme; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: CHINA; Core Funding; Government of France; Government of Sweden; Government of United Arab Emirates; International Fund for Agricultural Development; Liberia Multi-Partner Trust Fd; Multi-Partner Trust Fund; Rural Women Economic Empowermt
Implementation partners: Liberian Ministry of Agriculture; Liberian Ministry of Commerce and Industries; Liberian Ministry of Finance and Development Planning; Liberian Ministry of Gender, Children and Social Protection
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.
Geography: River Gee; Rivercess; Sinoe; Maryland; Grand Cape Mount; Grand Gedeh; Gbarpolu; Bomi; Liberia; Montserrado; Lofa; Margibi; Grand Bassa; Bong; Nimba
QCPR function: Support Functions; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Normative Support; Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
40 Savings and Loan Associations have been established with over 1,000 rural women farmers in Lofa, Bong, Nimba, Margibi, Grand Gedeh, and Grand Cape Mount Counties for investing in climate-smart agriculture and agri-businesses. Over 700 women smallholder farmers from Lofa, Bong, Nimba, and Margibi Counties have access to sustainable rural credit to invest in agri-businesses through the establishment of 28 community-owned Village Savings and Loan Associations with support from UN Women and partners.

To reduce the burden of manual labor and increase food production and productivity, WFP procured and delivered various agricultural equipment including rice mills, cassava grinders and power tillers to the seven counties (Grand Bassa, Margibi, Maryland, River Gee, Sinoe, Cape Mount and Nimba) to 1,000 smallholder farmers (700 women; 300 men). Farmers were trained on the operation, maintenance and repairs of these equipment. 
Under the Rural Community Finance Project (IFAD-funded), 4,000 rural people benefited from an improved access to financial services through the Rural Community Financial Institutions supported by the project in Nimba, Lofa, Gbarpolu, Rivercess, Sinoe, River Ghee, Grand Kru and Margibi. 

FAO has strengthened the capacity of 50 VSLA groups to have improved their access to finance in six (6) of the fifteen (15) counties in Liberia. These groups have collected raised over 1 million Liberians. These women groups have developed leadership, and financial skills to keep records of their transactions while empowering each other to support their agricultural businesses. 

WFP provided in cash through bank accounts USD 30,000 (USD 20,000 for Wellekama group in Grand Bassa and 10,000 for Gbawenken Rural Women group in Maryland) as cash assistance in the form of revolving fund through VSLA to targeted rural women. The groups were supported to open bank accounts for financial inclusion, and trained on business and financial management.
2023 Narrative: FAO trained and coached 1,451 farmers comprising 975 women on village saving and loan (VSLA) methodology. The training led to the formation and establishment of fifty VSLA groups. The beneficiary farmers learned and implemented the principles and operational procedures of VSLA, including keeping records of transactions and reporting. The VSLA received savings metallic boxes and other relevant materials (saving books, ledgers, a mini tub, and a mat) for the start-up kit. The 1,451 beneficiaries (comprising 975 females) have had the opportunity to access credit through the 50 established Village Savings and Loans Associations (VSLAs) under the project. The availability of credit resulted in more women diversifying their source of livelihood. Most invested in expanded agriculture production activities, starting small businesses (petty trade), and paying their children's school fees. The access to cash has increased their purchasing power for improved household food and nutrition security. ILO: Towards the establishment of 17 women and youth-led agricultural cooperatives, the capacity of 25 Technicians including project beneficiaries has been built in Cooperative Development and Management through a Training of Trainers Workshop. The trained trainers will later cascade the training to 255 members of their agricultural cooperatives.IFAD: Under this activity, IFAD funded provided several supports to rural producers, service providers, increase access to market amongst others. Results obtained under this component include:Provision of digressive support to 8 Cooperatives in Nimba to enhance their purchase power for sustainable business operations. To date, about US$1920,000.00 have been provided to these cooperatives to facilitate the purchase of cocoa from their members including project beneficiaries. From the sales of these cocoa, the cooperative have increase their income to US$725,307.00. IFAD further supported rural women and smallholder farmers by providing agricultural inputs to 2,813 rural women in food value chains, such as rice, oil palm and horticulture and matching grants to farmers. World Food Programme: Capacity of 25 smallholder farmers groups enhanced in financial management through the provision of VSLA services procurement of locally produced food commodities through the Home-Grown School Feeding programme.
2024 Narrative: Under the Peace Dividend Initiative, FAO partnered with the Liberia Cocoa Cooperative (LCC) to support the Komassa Vornambeh Group, a women group of cocoa farmers in Lofa county, after assessing eight groups consisting of a total of 199 individuals (166 women and 33 men) in Montserrado and Lofa Counties. The main progress with this project has been achieving the organic certification of the group, developing a new chocolate brand owned by the Komassa group, producing the first batch of 300 chocolate bars, developing marketing and packaging materials, and launching the chocolate bars in the national market. UNDP, under the Accelerated Community Development Programme (ACDP) disbursed $153,810.00USD to 884 rural women through direct social cash transfers to enable these vulnerable women-headed farming households to set up their business ventures, invest in agricultural activities such as harvesting, transporting, and constructing storage for produce through kuu or local susu, purchase basic household assets, and cover urgent expenses such as school fees for children, medical bills, and other immediate financial obligationsUN Women has focused on providing rural women and smallholder farmers with access to finance around food value chains in Liberia. Key initiatives in 2024 included:Expanding Financial Inclusion: Recognizing access to finance as critical for women's economic empowerment, UN Women supported the establishment of Savings and Loan Associations (SLAs). These SLAs provide a safe and accessible platform for women to save, invest, and pursue entrepreneurial ventures within the food value chain.Strengthening Cooperatives: UN Women facilitated the formation and strengthening of cooperatives, enabling women to collectively participate in green and agricultural value chains. This has enhanced their access to resources, markets, and training opportunities, improving their livelihoods and strengthening their roles in food production and processing.Promoting Innovative Financial Services: Beyond traditional savings and loans, UN Women has promoted access to innovative financial services tailored to the needs of rural women and smallholder farmers. This includes exploring Orange Banking and other financial products that can help them manage risks, invest in their farms and businesses, and increase their income from food-related activities.These efforts demonstrate UN Women's commitment to empowering women in the agricultural sector by increasing their access to finance and supporting their full participation in food value chains.

Description: One of WFP‚Äôs most significant achievements was supporting the establishment and launch of the Scaling Up Nutrition Business Network (SBN). This initiative reinforced WFP‚Äôs role in facilitating private sector investments in nutritious food value chains. The SBN played a key role in consolidating initial investments in selected local rice millers to fortify rice, thereby enhancing the nutritional value of school meals. The SBN launch offered an opportunity for local food processors and small holder farmers to invest in the production of nutritious foods and be connected to potential markets through the SBN platforms to ensure equitable access to nutritious food, particularly in remote and underserved communities in Ghana.

Plan name: United Nations Development Assistance Framework 2017-2021
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2 - People
Outcome: Outcome 2.3 - Social Protection
Output: Output 2.3.3 - Enrollment in social protection programmes  improves the access of vulnerable groups (including vulnerable refugees and displaced people) to health, nutrition and education services
Sub-Output: 2.3.3.9 - Provision of Life-Saving Shelter and Food Assistance in Support of Cyclone and Flood Affected Communities in Cabo Delgado Province, Mozambique
Description: Tropical Cyclone Kenneth made landfall in Cabo Delgado province of northern Mozambique on 25 April with strong winds impacting several coastal areas. As of 28 April, 5 deaths and 11 injured have been reported, and 23,760 people have reportedly been displaced and are living in accommodation centers, according to the National Disaster Management Institute (INGC). At least 35,110 houses have been totally destroyed (3,805) or partially destroyed (31,305). The government reported that thousands of hectares of agricultural land have been destroyed, nearing and at harvest time, which will affect the food security in months to come. In responding to the impact of the floods and the urgent needs identified, IOM and WFP will seek to ensure affected populations in Cabo Delgado have access to lifesaving shelter and food assistance. An estimated 25,235 individuals will be reached under this action. In line with government priorities and request for assistance, the intervention will focus on the districts Macomia, Quissangua and Ibo, which have been severely impacted. Further government rapid assessments are underway, and geographical and beneficiary targeting might be adjusted as soon as more data becomes available. IOM will distribute Emergency Shelter Kits targeting the most vulnerable households of the affected population. IOM expects to reach 4,300 households with Emergency Shelter Assistance. WFP will implement as co-delegatee of IOM under this action. WFP, in collaboration with the authorities and food security cluster partners, will provide life-saving food assistance to populations in need. While the majority of life-saving food assistance will be provided through in-kind food assistance, in areas where markets will be proven to be functional and retailers will have sufficient capacity, WFP will make use of commodity vouchers to deliver food assistance. An estimated 5,047 households will be reached with food assistance.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration; United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: European Union
Implementation partners: Mozambique National Institute for Disaster Management
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

2024 Narrative: FAO: 461 farmer producer Groups have been formed across the country. The farmers groups were trained along different enterprises (seed production, crop production, vegetable production, tree planting and agro-forestry, and crop value addition) and provided with range of inputs such as crop and vegetable seed, hand tools (hoes, maloda, sickles) irrigation kits (watering cans, solar pumps), post harvest kits (hermetic bags, gunny bags, tarpaulins, moisture meter, weighing scales), and value addition machineries (solar drier, sorghum threshers, seed/grain cleaners, peanut butter machines. The groups have also been trained on financial literacies and provided with VSLA kits.

Sub-Output: Supporting farmers to increase food production and value addition
Description: UNDP/ACDP: Support to Ministry of Agriculture in the procurement of 16 YAMAHA motorbikes for use by agriculture extension staff of the MOA
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme; United Nations Industrial Development Organization
Contributing partners: Swedish International Development Agency
Implementation partners: Liberian Forestry Development Authority; Liberian Ministry of Agriculture
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: Empowering Farmers, Boosting Productivity - In six counties‚ÄîBomi, Bong, Gbarpolu, Lofa, Nimba, and Rivercess ‚ÄîUNDP through the ACDP is also revolutionizing and boosting agriculture. Fourteen farmers' cooperatives received tractors, improved rice seeds, fertilizers, technical training, and financial assistance. For many, this was their first opportunity to cultivate crops on a large scale. By the end of 2024, these cooperatives had harvested 4,742 bags of paddy rice (25kg each), benefiting 725 farmers, including 435 women. According to some beneficiaries in Gbedin Community in Nimba County, the project has been transformative and a game changer helping them to prepare their farm land for planting which has been traditionally exhausting and time-consuming. However, with the availability of tractors and other farming equipment, the farmers are now doing everything in one step, thereby saving time and energy. For example, in Nimba County alone, over 230 acres were cultivated with the help of the tractors and other farming equipment, thereby increasing food production, harvesting 1,750 bags of rice with limited labor. With the supply of the farming equipment, this community is now one of the leading supplier of seed rice for smallholder farmers across Liberia. To further enhance agricultural productivity, the ACDP procured and handed over 16 YAMAHA motorbikes to the Ministry of Agriculture. These motorbikes are enabling extension officers to reach remote farming communities, providing much-needed training, supervision, and technical support.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK (2020-2025)
Strategic priority: Pillar 2: Sustainable Economic Development
Outcome: Outcome 2: By 2024, Liberia has sustained, diversified and inclusive economic growth driven by investments in agriculture, food security and job creation and is resilient to climate change and natural disasters.
Output: OUTPUT 2.3: By 2024, access, awareness and sustainable use of appropriate Resources, Assets,  Services and Markets by poor and rural producers, households, value-chain actors, and communities, including women and  youth improved.
Sub-Output: Primary producers, processors and other relevant value chain actors supported to actively pursue conformity with national food safety schemes, and overall advancement of national food safety culture, leading to enhanced demand for and supply of safe food in Liberia.
Description: UNIDO: The project is addressing the need to enhance the implementation of safe food production practices by primary producers, processors, cooperatives and other relevant value chain actors. By supporting them to conform with the requirements of the developed national food safety scheme, with the ultimate goal of getting certified and hence recognized on the market for their performance upgrade, they will benefit from increased market access and integration. Additionally, interventions at this level aim to foster the overall food safety culture in the country, engaging all relevant stakeholders, including consumers and food business operators. In applying a demand-driven approach, increased awareness on the importance of food safety as well as knowledge on safe food handling practices and associated risks, will be essential to stimulate increased demand for, consumption and supply of safe, locally produced food in Liberia.
Agencies: United Nations Industrial Development Organization
Contributing partners: European Union
Implementation partners: Liberian Ministry of Agriculture; Liberian Ministry of Commerce and Industries; Liberian Ministry of Health; National Public Health Institute of Liberia

SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries

2021 Narrative:
As one of its flagship programmes,  FAO is  supporting the creation of the enabling environment for responsible investments in agriculture and food system, progress was made towards youth empowerment (CFS-RAI principle 4). Also, a multi-stakeholder platform was established to lead the mainstreaming of the CFS-RAI principles into the design, award, implementation, monitoring and assessment/evaluation of agriculture investments. 

FAO in partnership with the Government of Liberia has significant progress in establishing an enabling environment for responsible investment in agriculture and food systems. To achieve this, FAO has undertaken an intensive learning program to enhance the capacity of the policymakers, and technical government staff for screening responsible Private Investment in Agri-Food Systems in Liberia as well as creating awareness of the same for investors. Hence the following were implemented: 
1. Multi-stakeholder platform (MSP) involving policymakers and government technicians who screen investment proposals was established 
2. Awareness of RAI for private sector investors in agri-food systems was completed
3. An online blended learning program was implemented with 15 participants completing the training. 
4. RAI Workshops for MSP members and private sector investors. 
5. A working session to finalize the diagram positioning the MSP vis-√†-vis the screening process and review the learning program report
2023 Narrative: FAO in partnership with the Government of Liberia has significant progress in establishing an enabling environment for responsible investment in agriculture and food systems. To achieve this, FAO has undertaken an intensive learning program to enhance the capacity of the policymakers, and technical government staff for screening responsible Private Investment in Agri-Food Systems in Liberia as well as creating awareness of the same for investors. Hence the following were implemented: 1. Multi-stakeholder platform (MSP) involving policymakers and government technicians who screen investment proposals was established 2. Awareness of RAI for private sector investors in agri-food systems was completed3. An online blended learning program was implemented with 15 participants completing the training. 4. RAI Workshops for MSP members and private sector investors. 5. A working session to finalize the diagram positioning the MSP vis-√†-vis the screening process and review the learning program report
2024 Narrative: FAO facilitated the development of Liberia‚Äôs Multi-sectorial nutrition costed strategic plan, which was validated and launched. As co-chair of the UN Nutrition, I coordinated with other UN agencies and government counterparts to facilitate the passage of the Code of Marketing of Breast-Milk Substitute Bill by the 54th Legislature (House of Representatives) and 55th Legislature, pending concurrence by the Senate. Under the nutrition intervention, FAO supported the Scaling Up Nutrition movement to provide an opportunity to strengthen government leadership and management of nutrition programs and to raise awareness among key stakeholders of the importance of budgetary allocation for nutrition in the national budget.RAI investment and investor screening tool validated and finalized. Trained several government staff to apply the RAI investment and investor screening tool (IMTC representatives and technical staff in MACs)

2022 Narrative: WFP procured 517 mt of maize worth USD198,932 from 3,805 smallholders (2,550 men and 1,255 women) through the pro-smallholder food supply agreements. The maize was distributed in 46 schools where WFP was piloting home-grown school feeding programme. Overall,  27,515 school children, comprising of 13,867 boys and 13,648 girls were supported with the maize.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK 2020 - 2025
Strategic priority: SP 1 PEOPLE
Outcome: OUTCOME 1 All people in Ethiopia enjoy the rights and capabilities to realize their potential in equality and with dignity
Output: OUTPUT 1.3: Equitable access to basic social services is strengthened, benefitting vulnerable, marginalized and displacementaffected people.
Sub-Output: Shelter and Non-Food Items (NFI) assistance to populations affected by the Northern Ethiopia Crisis (SN.0151)
Description: The proposed intervention will provide lifesaving humanitarian assistance focusing on Shelter and NFI (S-NFI) interventions to targeted internally displaced persons (IDP) and vulnerable affected households (HH) in host communities. The proposed project intervention will target the affected population in cluster-identified priority locations of Tigray, Amhara and Afar regions in Ethiopia. Key activities include distribution of In-kind non-food items (NFI), and rehabilitation of unfinished buildings while also piloting a host community neighboring approach. The rehabilitation of unfinished buildings and host community neighboring approach will be coupled with Housing, Land, and Property (HLP) support ensuring that targeted beneficiaries are supported with a legal tenure documentation. Assistance will be provided in kind. To ensure a well-coordinated response, IOM works in collaboration with national and sub-national emergency shelter and NFI (ESNFI) cluster, Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) and protection clusters to ensure overall coordination and inclusive response. Under the proposed project, IOM will assist 4,760 HHs (24,800 individuals). Primary target locations for the proposed response as per the Shelter cluster priority allocation are four woredas under the Northwestern Zone and Mekelle of Tigray Region, as well as North Wello in Amhara region, and Wasi/Zone 5 in Afar region. IOM seeks to continue the provision of lifesaving and life-sustaining S-NFI services to individuals in prioritized communities in the targeted woredas.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: Ethiopia Humanitarian Fund
Implementation partners: Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia Disaster Risk Management Commission
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being; 6 Clean Water and Sanitation
Geography: Ethiopia; Zone 1 (Awsi Rasu); Mekele; Chifra; Raya Kobo; Eastern; Asgede; Dawe; Hawzen; Zana; Sheraro town; Telalek; Mekelle; Indasilassie town; North Wello; Zone 5 (Hari Rasu); North Western; Afar; Tigray; Amhara

2023 Narrative: UNICEF as part of the First Foods Initiative (FFI) has engaged some Small and Medium Enterprises (Yadent, premium foods, Chopbox express and Faustep) that are into commercial production of complementary foods to explore the opportunities to boost their production capacity and provide incentive to increase access nutritious foods across the country.  UNICEF also supported the Food and Drugs Authority to revamp Universal Salt Iodization programme in Ghana. In addition, UNICEF has procured consultancy services to develop business case models to support artisanal salt producers.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF engaged key stakeholders and introduced the First Foods Initiative to work with SMEs for increased production of nutritious, safe, affordable and sustainable complementary foods for young children.
