2023 Narrative: FAO assisted115,859 smallholder famers in Somali, Oromia, Tigray, Afar and SNNP with conditional and unconditional cash and disbursed 566,800,276 ETB. These households are crisis affected vulnerable small holder farmers including pastoral and agro pastoral households.‚Ä¢           In 2023, 5.5 million drought and conflict-affected people were assisted through relief food and cash assistance (134,749.99 mt food and almost USD 15.7 million for CBT) in Tigray, Afar, Amhara and Somali regions of which 350,886 were supported through CBT in Somali and Amhara regions.‚Ä¢           Food security situation worsened across the regions as per July 2023 food security outcome monitoring.‚Ä¢           On 4 May 2023, WFP and BHA have suspended food distribution in Tigray region following reports of high food sale in the region. The situation has called for a country wide pause of general food distribution while enhanced assurance measures and controls were established.‚Ä¢           The assurance measures aim at ensuring that WFP is targeting the people most in need of assistance and that sufficient assurance measures and controls are in place to ensure that only the intended beneficiaries receive the assistance. Targeting and digital registration process has been implemented in Tigray, Somali, Afar and Amhara regions since June to date.‚Ä¢           The Targeting and Registration process is progressing in the four relief response locations namely Afar, Amhara, Somali, and Tigray. In Tigray Region, the first cycle Food distribution testing has been completed in 9 Woredas, benefiting 788,723 beneficiaries based on the assurance and control measures put in place. For the second cycle in Tigray, the exercise has been completed in 11 relief Woredas, with digital registration of approximately 183,932 households.   In the Somali Region, household validation has been completed in several villages across different Woredas, with ongoing digital registration. In Amhara Region, household selection and validation have been completed in 50 Kebeles in Alamata corridor, with ongoing verification. In North Gonder Woredas, household validation has been completed in 205 out of 237 villages. In the Afar Region, household validation and verification have been completed in several Kebeles, with digital registration ongoing.‚Ä¢           WFP has also moved to working with non-governmental organizations to implement relief food assistance in the four regions. This is one of the key shifts under assurance project. Four non-governmental (two national and two international) cooperation partners have signed filed level agreement to implement the relief response including targeting and registration.
2024 Narrative: An estimated 15.8 million people required humanitarian assistance in 2024, reflecting a 20 percent decrease compared to 20.4 million in 2023. WFP prioritized food assistance for districts classified as severely food insecure (HEA Phases 4 and 5) according to Ethiopia‚Äôs Household Economy Analysis (HEA). Assistance was also extended to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in camps and camp-like settings. Furthermore, WFP continued assistance in North Gondar, Amhara, and contested areas between Amhara and Tigray, despite not being classified as HEA Phases 4 and 5, as conflict-related triggers of food insecurity warranted this support. In collaboration with INGO/NGO partners, WFP assisted 3.9 million crisis-affected people‚Äîincluding IDPs‚Äîacross Afar, Amhara, Tigray, and Somali regions. Building on the 2023 distribution reforms, WFP strengthened its assurance measures by implementing digital beneficiary identification, biometric registration for IDP camps etc

2023 Narrative: WFP assisted 823,086 refugees through monthly food and cash assistance out of which 160,036 of them are addressed through the hybrid food and cash transfer modality. WFP introduced ration cut starting May 2023 due to resource shortage availing only 60% of the standard recommended kilo calorie. From January to May 2023, WFP distributed 53,638.75mt of food and 2.5million USD through the General Food Distribution. The number of beneficiaries increased as a result of high influx of new arrivals from Somali Land and Sudan where 83,450 are settled in Doolo Zone in Somali region, 17,437 in Kumar ‚Äì Metema in Amhara region and 18,728 in Kurmuk in Benishangul Gumz region.
2024 Narrative: WFP, in collaboration with UNHCR and the Government of Ethiopia, provided food and nutrition assistance to 801,000 refugees, a slight reduction from 823,000 in 2023. Assistance was delivered through in-kind distributions, CBT, and hybrid models. Cumulatively, WFP distributed 76,000 metric tonnes of in-kind food assistance and disbursed USD 6 million in CBT, an increase from USD 2.3 million in 2023. WFP‚Äôs refugee response was resourced at 59 percent, with 19 percent carried over from 2023. Funding constraints, coupled with rising operational costs and higher food prices, impacted program implementation. WFP provided specialized nutritious foods for the treatment and prevention of acute malnutrition for 265,800 children aged 6-59 months and pregnant and breastfeeding women in refugee camps, achieving a 96 percent recovery rate, surpassing the SPHERE rate of 75 percent. Further, 95,640 (77,640 in 2023) school-aged children also benefitted from school meals in 2024.

Description: WFP provides children aged 6-23 months and pregnant and lactating women with restricted cash assistance to purchase nutrient-dense foods from local retailers.  WFP supports technical assistance for local production and marketing of specialized nutritious foods by the private sector, focusing on small and medium-sized enterprises and particularly those owned by women. Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective

Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: During the reporting period, 142,384 people in Amhara, Afara and Somali regions were provided a nutrient dense fresh food voucher worth 3,360,882 USD to be redeemed for fresh foods only. Social behavioral change communication was complemented with the voucher to create demands for consumption of fresh foods and to impart recommended maternal infant and young child nutrition practices. In doing so, 25,521 and 250,000 people were reached with interpersonal and media based SBCC messages respectively. WFP contracted retailers in the local markets to supply diversified and quality fresh foods with the daily market price to the beneficiaries. Market support teams were organized to support the retailers and beneficiaries in the marketplaces and to monitor the quality, diversity, price and assortment of the food. Post-distribution monitoring was conducted to review the progress and attainment of key outcome indicators, and the result revealed an improvement in dietary diversity. The minimum acceptable diet for children 6-23 months which assess proportion of children who consumed a minimum acceptable diet in terms of diet diversity and meal frequency during the previous day (24 hr recall) was 68.4%. The minimum dietary diversity of Women was 68.4. The assessment has shown that 99% of the eligible population target for the programme has taken part in the programme. The food consumption score Nutrition has improved that the proportion of households that never consumed hem iron rich foods and protein rich foods reduced from 96.1 % to 69.1% and from 21.3% to 3.1% respectively.
2024 Narrative: WFP partnered with a range of stakeholders, including the Federal Ministry of Health, Regional Health Bureaus, national NGOs, and the Ministries of Agriculture, Education, Trade, and Women and Social Affairs, as well as the private sector (financial service providers and traders), and Scaling Up Nutrition Initiative.  In 2024, WFP reached 126,892 pregnant and breastfeeding women and children under five with fresh food vouchers (FFVs) worth USD 3.95 million surpassing the 2024 target of 100,000 people in need. WFP continued to support the Government of Ethiopia in the development of creation of the district-level nutrition investment plans under the Seqota declaration integrating them into the regional and federal budgets.

Contributing partners: Government of Canada; Government of Denmark; Government of Finland; Government of Germany; Government of Sweden; Government of the United States of America; Pooled funds; United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development

SDG Targets: 17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: -         WFP provided institutional capacity strengthening to the Government of Ethiopia at both federal and regional levels in areas of early warning systems, emergency preparedness, social safety nets and supply chain management. -         WFP supported 18 capacity building initiatives to enhance Government capacity on supply chain management, early warning, and social safety net response. This involved the support of 14 federal and regional Government institutions through these systems-strengthening initiatives. WFP used internal expertise and engaged government to share costs to cover the additional requests.-         WFP collaborated with the Ministry of Agriculture (MoA) on the World Bank-financed Productive Safety Net Programme Five (PSNP V) to provide institutional capacity strengthening and resume the implementation of this major component of the national social protection programme that has been discontinued in Tigray due to conflict. -         WFP conducted a Capacity Needs Mapping (CNM) and an inventory of the available number of PSNP staff and their skillsets, damage to assets, Government and community infrastructures and functionality of taskforces essential for the resumption of PSNP. This mapping was used by WFP and stakeholders to develop a comprehensive capacity development action plan. Under this, WFP facilitated trainings for 1,500 PSNP staff (12 percent female) on retargeting, registration and enrolment, environmental and social management framework, monitoring and evaluation, grievance redress mechanism and resource management. WFP supported the Ministry of Women and Social Affairs (MoWSA) to conduct a National Social Protection Conference that enhanced awareness among parliamentarians, policy and law makers on the role of social protection towards building sustainable development and social cohesion. -         As part of the capacity strengthening initiatives, 464 government staff (13 percent female) were trained on technical areas of early warning including data management and reporting, Livelihood Early Assessment and Protection (LEAP) tool, LEAP integration with Satellite Assisted Pastoralist Resource Management (SAPRM), and Anticipatory Action (AA). Experts in regional and zonal Disaster Risk Management (DRM) in Afar, Amhara and Somali regions were able to use the satellite remote sensing data to generate early warning information for humanitarian action.-         WFP provided support to Ethiopia Disaster Risk Management Commission (EDRMC) to enhance the web-based Commodity Allocation and Tracking System (CATS) delivering practical training on CATS to 160 (12 percent female) EDRMC staff, enabling an efficient and transparent reporting and reconciliation system and upstream and downstream tracking of food commodities. WFP supported six Government institutions through secondment of high-level expertise to provide advisory support at both federal and regional level. This has resulted in enhanced coordination and planning of the food response in the country through EDMRC. At the MOA, WFP‚Äôs advisory support has contributed to the strengthening of the ministry‚Äôs capacity on the implementation of Shock Responsive Safety Nets.-         Seconded high level technical experts supported the Ministry of Transport and Logistics, the Ethiopian Maritime Authority (EMA) and the secretariat of the Ethio- Logistics Sectorial Association (ELSA) with the implementation of the National Logistics Strategy.
2024 Narrative: WFP's resources through country capacity strengthening were mainstreamed through strengthening national social protection systems, mostly through Ethiopia's Productive Safety Net Program (PSNP). With funding from the World Bank and in collaboration with the Government of Ethiopia (GoE), the Third party implementation (TPI) Shock-Responsive Safety Net project was successfully concluded in April 2024 supporting over 570,000 people in need in the targeted PSNP districts, and a total of 1.3 million people throughout the project period since mid-2023. WFP assisted the GoE in launching a digital national identity (ID) pilot project in the Somali region. Support was also provided to MOA to strengthen its DRM and EW system and institutionalize AA. Finally, WFP developed a Commodity Allocation and Tracking System tool for EDRMC to improve efficiency and transparency.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2024-2028)
Strategic priority: Entornos sostenibles y resilientes
Outcome: 4. Para 2028 el pa√≠s cuenta con entornos sostenibles y saludables protectores de la biodiversidad, resilientes al cambio clim√°tico y a los desastres naturales y sin deforestaci√≥n.
Output: 4.2 Se ha impulsado la transici√≥n hacia el uso de las energ√≠as alternativas y renovables accesibles especialmente para comunidades remotas que carecen de suministro el√©ctrico.
Sub-Output: Just Energy Transition in Equatorial Guinea: Enhancing Food Security and Livelihoods through Renewable Energy Solutions in Rural Communities
Description:
The project aims to address the severe socio-economic disparities in the rural areas of Punta Mbonda and Akurenam-Esacora by providing reliable solar-powered electricity and supporting agricultural value addition. The project will establish solar mini-grids and solar-powered food processing units, enabling better food preservation, reduced post-harvest losses, and increased income through value-added agricultural products.
Expected results include significantly improved access to clean and sustainable energy, enhanced food security through the development of local food processing capabilities, and the creation of sustainable livelihood opportunities by empowering local farmers and entrepreneurs. These outcomes will contribute directly to achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by accelerating transitions to affordable and clean energy (SDG 7), ending hunger through improved food security (SDG 2), and fostering decent work and economic growth (SDG 8).
By integrating renewable energy solutions with food security and economic empowerment strategies, this project acts as an engine room for SDG transitions, driving local development and creating a model for sustainable, inclusive growth in Equatorial Guinea's rural communities. The initiative's focus on capacity building, market development, and community resilience aligns with national priorities and the broader objectives of the SDGs, making a significant contribution to the country‚Äôs sustainable development efforts.
Agencies: United Nations Development Programme
Contributing partners: The Joint SDG Fund; United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: Government of Equatorial Guinea
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,7.1 By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 7 Affordable and Clean Energy; 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth

2022 Narrative: In the first 6 months of 20222, WFP supported smalllholder farmers across many initiatives and platforms, in order to strengthen farmers' abilities in aggregation, marketing, and decision-making, with a particular emphasis on women, while simultaneously enhancing their knowledge of nutrition, care techniques, and healthy diets. Through the‚ÄØvirtual farmers market project, WFP trained 7,997 smallholder farmers (42%‚ÄØwomen)‚ÄØon agricultural practices, financial literacy, and a balanced diet. In addition, WFP raised people's consciousness about the importance of eating healthy through social and behavior change communication programmes, reaching 2,947 local farmers (39% women).In an effort to reduce PHL, the WFP Zero loss Initiative (ZLI) was expanded to 24 districts. WFP began hosting roundtable discussions in many provinces to promote understanding of post-harvest losses and the value of hermetic technology in reducing these losses resulting, the capacity of 117 government employees were improved, allowing them to better train 8,282 smallholder farmers (54%‚ÄØwomen). Furthermore, 6,244 hermetic bags were provided to 3,122 smallholder farmers.Through AGROPONTO in Nampula, WFP aimed to facilitate smallholder famers‚Äô remote access to market. To implement the platforms, 6 government employees were trained and provided instruction to 800 lead farmers (34%‚ÄØwomen) and supplied 798 kits containing smartphones, solar chargers, and weighing scales to 400 additional farmers. Similarly, another digital platform called Farm2Go was launched in Tete as well and improved the capacity of 13 government employees, 6 purchasers, and 8 lead farmers to encourage smallholder farmers' engagement and usage of the platform.                                                                                           The second 6 months of 2022, WFP implemented our initiatives‚ÄØthat support‚ÄØfarm production and livelihoods‚ÄØunder the Beyond Cotton Project. A total of 131 smallholder farmers (38%‚ÄØwomen) and 24 technicians from the cooperating partners were involved. For the agricultural campaign of 2022/2023, agricultural kits‚ÄØwere acquired to assist 250 farmers.  Through our‚ÄØVirtual Farmers Project, 1,681 households were educated about NutriSIM, 12 communities (1 campaign per community) participated to improve nutritional intake. WFP used community radios‚ÄØto air 790 radio spots, 60 radio soap operas, and 12 debates, which emphasized the value of eating a diversified diet rich-in-nutrient. WFP signed contracts with 24 SDAEs‚ÄØas part of its ZLI, wherein 779 government workers had their post-harvest management skills improved. Throughout 266 workshops, WFP educated 7,597 smallholder farmers (38%‚ÄØwomen) on PHM and the use of hermetic technology. WFP sent out 1,2000 hermetic bags to 474 farmers(45% women) and signed a long-term deal with PLASTEX (a national supplier of hermetic silos).WFP gave 30 scales and 30 moisture meters to the selected farmers to serve as leaders, then capacitated‚ÄØ806 farmer organizations to reduce post-harvest losses and increase market access by working via lead farmers. WFP supported 2,774 farmers(41% women), use local procurement methods to sell their products. Further, WFP helped 4,433 smallholder farmers market 4,071.42 MT of agricultural crops, valued at USD 1,725,091.03 (50% women).  Finally, in response to‚ÄØthe armed‚ÄØconflict and weather shocks, WFP worked with BMZ to create customized early recovery packages for‚ÄØIDPs and host communities. About 75,000 people in Cabo Delgado and Nampula provinces, both affected by the violence, received packages tailored to their specific livelihoods.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, WFP prioritized treatment over prevention due to limited funding. Prevention was gradually scaled up in first half of 2023 targeting selected areas and then paused in most areas from September onwards.
2024 Narrative: WFP: WFP delivered life-saving nutrition treatment and prevention services targeting children under 5, pregnant and breastfeeding women, and people living with HIV/AIDS and Tuberculosis. The program focused on addressing Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) through treatment and prevention interventions such as Blanket Supplementary Feeding Programs (BSFP) and Maternal and Child Health Nutrition (MCHN), while strengthening supply chain controls and monitoring systems. In collaboration with the Ministry of Health (MOH), SUN Secretariat, and state-level counterparts, WFP integrated nutrition interventions with key sectors and built capacity for coordinated nutrition responses. The organization supported the IMAM taskforce in adopting revised WHO guidelines for preventing and treating wasting and worked with the Federal MOH to develop a roadmap for implementing these guidelines and revising national protocols. Additionally, WFP collaborated with UNICEF to enhance the continuum of care for acute malnutrition through integrated services and joint implementation plans, ensuring efficient and cost-effective delivery.

2021 Narrative:
WFP: WFP undertook studies to assess the efficacy, consumer acceptability and palatability of the nixtamalization process to mitigate and reduce mycotoxin contamination in maize. Results indicate an average 72% reduction in both total aflatoxin and aflatoxin B1, 91% reduction in fumonisin. The consumer acceptability was recorded as 92% through the palatability and sensory evaluation analysis. These studies have informed the scoping of nixtamalization activities in partnership with a milling group in Baringo County. The implementation of nixtamalization activities is expected to increase income and market opportunities for youth and women and in turn their livelihoods.
UNIDO supported KALRO to develop clean planting material for macadamia, groundnuts, mango and passion fruit.Pesticide Residue Monitoring Scheme and Plant Health Inspection System developed with KEPHIS.

2021 Narrative:
UN Women
A total of 1,240 000 women smallholder farmers enhanced their knowledge on  cooperative management and financial literacy. The women were grouped into 35 women-led farmers‚Äô cooperatives (with an average of 25 women per cooperative) which are now registered with relevant government agencies in the state. Additionally, linkages of the women farmers‚Äô cooperatives to financial institutions were facilitated to ensure financial inclusion.  The cooperatives have created an access to finance platform which allows them to build up petty trades. Women farmers have reported that the cooperative group helped them to become socially and economically empowered by supporting them to produce more as a group, diversify their businesses (especially in the agro-processing sector), earn better income, raise living standards, and contribute to food security of families and communities at large. Women farmers who have diversified their businesses to the level of agribusinesses were further capacitated on agribusiness strategies. Overall, through the establishment and trainings of women farmers‚Äô cooperatives, the project has created jobs and generated income for an estimated 1,380 women smallholder farmers by fostering their transition from less formal to decent and sustainable work. Majority of women participating in the project have reported increased access to opportunities that enhanced their economic and food security status in the context of conflict,  humanitarian crisis and climate change. The project also consolidated partnerships with relevant actors (including banks of agriculture) who contributed to creating an enabling environment for women economic empowerment, including through the facilitation of legal registration of women farmers‚Äô cooperatives . The opening of banks accounts for women farmers and their cooperatives contributed to bridging the wide gender gap that existed between men and women farmers, and promoted women smallholder farmers in terms of ability to access social security, financial schemes and other agriculture input/programmes. 

FAO
39,573 Households had their Food Security improved through access to improved crop inputs, fish processing facilities and irrigation infrastructure (water pumps and tube wells/wash boreholes) as well as livestock kits including goats and poultry. The beneficiaries were among the vulnerable households in 13 LGAs of Borno state who are mostly women households.The support was provided between January and December of 2021 across LGAs in Borno  state. FAO partnered with government through Borno ADP and NGOs in the delivery of the project activities. The target beneficiaries were vulnerable members of host community, IDPs and returnees and included men and women households. Assessment of impact on crop input beneficiaries indicates improvement in food security outcomes of the beneficiary households. Farmers were able to produce food that will last for an average of 4.2 months and significantly improves food consumption score. Over 3 quarter (77 percent) of the sampled beneficiaries have acceptable FCS.
Assessment of impact of livestock assistance show evidence of increased household income to the benefiting households and enabled them diversify their income source using proceeds from sales of livestock and products.

2024 Narrative: "The WFP nutrition programme continued to ensure the well-being of vulnerable groups in South Sudan through its three interventions: 1) the targeted supplementary feeding program (TSFP) which aims to treat moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) in children under 5 and pregnant and breastfeeding women and girls (PBWG). through this intervention; 665,419 and 416,151 children under five were reached in 2023 and Jan-Aug 2024, respectively. Moreover, 548,809 in 2023 and 333,678 PBWG were reached in of Aug 2024.2) the blanket supplementary feeding programme (BSFP) which aims to prevent the onset of acute malnutrition in children under 2 and PBWG. in 2023, 162,804 children and 85,833 PBWG were reached. in 2024, 198,981 children and 135,283 PBWG were reached as of Aug 2024.3) The institutional feeding programme (IFP) which supports the caregivers of children in stabilization centers, as well as inpatient and outpatient tuberculosis, HIV, and kala-azar patients and their caregivers. Around 23,458 and 16,107 beneficiaries were reached with IFP services in 2023 and 2024, respectively.In 2023, WFP distributed 17,288 MT of food in the three programms, and between January and August 2024, it distributed 9,873 MT. It is worth mentioning that due to funding constraints, the nutrition programme had to narrow its coverage and focus on priority counties."

2024 Narrative: In line with the Government‚Äôs objective to increase the coverage of school meals from 43 percent to 100 percent by 2030, WFP made significant progress in scaling up the HGSF programme in 2024. WFP extended its support to 200 additional schools across three new districts: Mzimba (North and South), Nkhatabay, and Rumphi. Furthermore, 34 schools in Chikwawa and Nsanje were added, and 78 Early Childhood Development (ECD) centres were included in the programme. This expansion brought the total number of primary schools supported to 778, up from 544 the previous year. A total of 837,026 primary school learners (426,127 girls and 410,899 boys) benefited from daily nutritious meals. These meals were made from a combination of staple foods, legumes, roots, tubers, vegetables, and fruits from the six food groups commonly found in Malawi. The schools that received support are in 11 districts, including Chikwawa, Dedza, Kasungu, Mangochi, Mzimba, Nkhatabay, Nsanje, Phalombe, Rumphi, Salima, and Zomba. In addition, 15,448 learners (8,438 girls and 7,010 boys) from 140 ECD centres in seven districts benefited from similar nutritious meals. ÔªøIn total, 24,405 smallholder farmers, organised in farmer groups, supplied food commodities to the schools, helping to create a stable market for their produce and improving the local economy. Additionally, 44,951 small holder farmers benefitted from the homegrown school feeding programme through various interventions including trainings on agricultural practices, including post-harvest loss mitigation and crop diversification. UNICEF Key Achievements: UNICEF scaled up high-impact, equitable nutrition interventions in Malawi by leveraging food, health, education, social protection, and WASH systems. Over 1.5 million children were screened for wasting, with 40,811 treated, while vitamin A and micronutrient supplementation improved child nutrition. Nutrition-sensitive social protection programs, such as cash transfers targeting households with children under two, and community-based Care Groups engaged local volunteers to promote health and nutrition practices. UNICEF enhanced dietary diversity through initiatives like distributing chickens, fruit trees, and supporting backyard gardens for over 90,000 households. Education systems were leveraged to deliver iron and folate supplements to adolescent girls and establish school health clubs addressing nutrition, hygiene, and gender-sensitive practices. WASH systems ensured access to safe water for 1.41 million people and improved sanitation for over 110,000 individuals, contributing to disease prevention. Through the First Foods Africa Initiative, nutrient-enriched crops, food processing training, and innovative supplements like fish powder were introduced to diversify diets. UNICEF‚Äôs efforts aligned with the national Nutrition-Sensitive Social Protection framework, promoting cross-sector collaboration for sustainable outcomes. These integrated interventions strengthened resilience and addressed malnutrition among vulnerable populations, demonstrating a holistic, multi-system approach to improving child nutrition and well-being.Challenges: Insufficient coverage of nutrition-sensitive interventions in remote areas.Opportunities: UNICEF considers leveraging on school systems and community networks to improve dietary practices and address malnutrition sustainably.WHO: WHO has contributed to the enhancement of the health systems capacity to improve the quality of inpatient care for children with severe malnutrition through the training and mentorship of over 60 health care workers from nutrition rehabilitation units in 15 districts worst affected by disasters on the management of children admitted with severe malnutrition and the provision of PED-SAM kits to 18 districts. Furthermore, WHO has supported the evaluation of the implementation of the Baby Friendly Hospital Initiave Ten Steps to Successful Breastfeeding who findings will inform national policy and programming to protect, promote and support breastfeeding.
2025 Narrative: In line with the Government‚Äôs objective to increase the coverage of school meals from 43 percent to 100 percent by 2030, WFP made significant progress in scaling up the HGSF programme in 2024. WFP extended its support to 200 additional schools across three new districts: Mzimba (North and South), Nkhatabay, and Rumphi. Furthermore, 34 schools in Chikwawa and Nsanje were added, and 78 Early Childhood Development (ECD) centres were included in the programme. This expansion brought the total number of primary schools supported to 778, up from 544 the previous year. A total of 837,026 primary school learners (426,127 girls and 410,899 boys) benefited from daily nutritious meals. These meals were made from a combination of staple foods, legumes, roots, tubers, vegetables, and fruits from the six food groups commonly found in Malawi. The schools that received support are in 11 districts, including Chikwawa, Dedza, Kasungu, Mangochi, Mzimba, Nkhatabay, Nsanje, Phalombe, Rumphi, Salima, and Zomba. In addition, 15,448 learners (8,438 girls and 7,010 boys) from 140 ECD centres in seven districts benefited from similar nutritious meals. ÔªøIn total, 24,405 smallholder farmers, organised in farmer groups, supplied food commodities to the schools, helping to create a stable market for their produce and improving the local economy. Additionally, 44,951 small holder farmers benefitted from the homegrown school feeding programme through various interventions including trainings on agricultural practices, including post-harvest loss mitigation and crop diversification. In 2024, WFP continued supporting the government in implementing nutrition-related activities in line with policy, strategic and operational guidance. Key achievements included assisting in finalising the National Multisectoral Nutrition Policy and Strategic Plan; supporting the review of critical policy tools such as the National Nutrition Strategic Plan and Community Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) guidelines, adapting them to the 2023 WHO guidelines for managing child wasting and oedema; supporting nutrition evidence generation by providing technical and financial support to the Standardised Monitoring and Assessment of Relief and Transitions (SMART) survey and Food and Nutrition security assessment for people living with HIV and tuberculosis (PLHIV/TB) to assess the nutrition situation of the various nutrition vulnerable groups following recurrent shocks particularly the 2024 El Ni√±o-induced drought, which worsened food insecurity and malnutrition.  In response to rising global acute malnutrition (from 2.2% in 2020 to 4.4% in 2024), WFP resumed its supplementary feeding programme in four priority districts of Machinga, Chikwawa, Nsanje and Blantyre, targeting children aged 6 to 59 months. Of the 23,000 children targeted from September 2024 to May 2025, over 11,000 were reached across 107 health facilities, with a cure rate of 84%, surpassing the 75% SPHERE standard. Additionally, with 46% food insecurity and 26% malnutrition among this group, WFP implemented an integrated Nutrition and HIV project in Chikwawa district, benefiting 2,400 individuals in 16 HIV support groups. This initiative provided training in nutrition, financial literacy, and livelihood skills and distributed agricultural resources to improve food security and livelihoods. Among the beneficiaries, 84% showed improved nutrition behaviours and knowledge in diet diversification, finance, and livestock management.  At the subnational level, WFP supported malnutrition prevention activities in Chikwawa, Nsanje, Phalombe, and Zomba districts. District councils and partners conducted 348 care group visits, disseminating essential nutrition information, reaching 38,447 households (76,894 people, 66% women). Through mass awareness campaigns and radio broadcasts, over 740,000 people (58% women) received nutrition social behaviour change messages. Beneficiaries also received assets to support dietary diversification and sanitation improvements. WFP supported district councils by enhancing facility- and community-level nutrition programming through regular coordination and review meetings.

2023 Narrative: UNHCR and its partners have continued with their efforts to maintain and improve access to primary health care services by ensuring improved clinical and preventive health services for more than 350,000 refugees and30 % of the surrounding host communities. (1)While negative public health trends were witnessed among Sudanese refugees, and returnees due to Sudan influx in in Ruweng/Unity, Upper Nile and Northern Barl Eh Ghazal States starting April 2023, UNHCR has contributed to the South Sudan national emergency response strategies to the Sudan crisis including availability primary health care services, supply and distribution of potable water, provision of lifesaving food assistance and nutrition support that led to a reversal of these negative trends. For cases that were not able to be treated at health facilities in the camps level, referrals were carried out to the county hospital or as a last result Juba referral teaching hospital. (2) Public health/nutrition programmes are implemented through Implementing partners (IPs), and some by direct implementation. Refugees in South Sudan continue to rely on the general food ration as their main source of food while a minority relies on own production/market. The general food ration assistance is being provided to all registered refugees in the camps (Maban, Jamjang, Gorom and Makpandu) and it was reduced at 50% ration which is negatively impacting on the nutrition and health wellbeing of refugees. The ration includes dry cereals (sorghum or maize), pulses, oil and salt. In addition, some cash for milling is also provided. The food basket does not reach 100% due to budget constraints where UNHCR has continued advocacy to increase assistance to person we serve. Despite limited budget, UNHCR and partners have continued to supply and distribute 15 to 20 litters of potable water to refugees and surrounding host communities in 8 refugees camps.

2021 Narrative: 2.	83,481 people across 4,910 households have been impacted by hazards during the rainy season mainly in URR and WCR. A total of 14,775 shelters were damaged leading to internal displacement of an estimated 17,314 people. A total of 949 sanitary facilities and 602 water points have been affected nationwide with WCR, URR, the North Bank Region and Kanifing Municipality being the hardest hit areas. As a response to this crisis -	Rehabilitation of clean water access points and safe sanitary facilities for 307 households were carried, D1,500 per month for 2 months to 1,243 households to enable the targeted households access food and acquire non- food items such mosquito nets, cooking utensils, soap etc. was executed and Financial support to 1,000 households (through vouchers) of D3,000 to access reconstruction materials was provided.

2021 Narrative: The Comprehensive Food Security and Vulnerability Analysis (CFSVA) is a study which seeks to generate evidence and comparable baseline information on food and nutrition security and the vulnerability of households and how they cope with in the context of food and nutrition crisis. The 2021 CFSVA analyzed the food security situation in the context of COVID-19 and provide analysis at the regional level. The CFSVA 2021 found that 13.4 percent of the population or 329,189 people are food insecure in the country. Among them, 1.8 percent are severely food insecure, while 11.6 percent moderately food insecure. Food insecurity increased from 5.6 percent in 2011 to 8 percent in 2016 and 13.4 percent in 2021.

2023 Narrative: A Smart-Solar powerd Irrigation scheme for forcibly displaced people was constructed in Baidoa- Barwaaqo IDP site. The project is due to be completed on 31 December 2023. So far the following features have been completed: 120 metre deep borehole, installation of solar panels to power the borehole and irrigation scheme, guard room, generator room, prayer room, ablution facilities, above ground water tank, underground tank, water kiosk for neighboring households and animal water troughs, drip irrigation scheme and fence. What remains is the procurement of farming implements, selection and training of beneficieries.

Plan name: UNSDCF 2022 - 2026
Strategic priority: INCLUSIVE, DIVERSIFIED AND CLIMATE RESILIENT ECONOMY
Outcome: By 2026, people in Eritrea, especially the disadvantaged population, have increased livelihood as economic growth becomes more inclusive and diversified
Output: Skills and capacity of people, especially women and youth, are improved for increased access to diversified livelihoods and employability
Sub-Output: Develop Recipes and complementary foods from aquatic foods
Description:
Initiatives are being launched to develop recipes and complementary foods derived from aquatic sources, enhancing nutritional options for communities. A Social Behavior Communication Change (SBCC) strategy is being crafted to encourage increased fish consumption among households and communities. As part of this effort, procurement of aquatic food packaging and labeling materials is essential to promote these products effectively. Nutrition materials and equipment are also being acquired to support these initiatives, alongside a comprehensive fish consumption survey to gather valuable data.

In addition, new parameters are being introduced for research, including analyzing shelf life, assessing seaweed, and cultivating various purpose-driven microbes. To improve local fish distribution, procurement of eight ready-made retail fish shops and five solar-powered refrigerated fish transporting trucks is underway. The construction of ten solar-powered ice-producing facilities will further enhance fish preservation and quality.

Moreover, the procurement of 20 long line drum haulers and complete long line fishing gear for artisanal boats will support local fishermen. Plans include establishing fish drying facilities and renovating existing fish processing facilities to improve operational efficiency. Additional procurement of fishing inputs, the erection of ice plants, and the acquisition of water trucks are all part of a comprehensive approach to enhance the fishing industry. Finally, hatcheries are being established to support sustainable fish production and resource management.
Agencies: International Fund for Agricultural Development
Contributing partners: German Funds; International Fund for Agricultural Development
Implementation partners: Ministry of Marine Resources Eritrea
SDG Targets: 14.2 By 2020, sustainably manage and protect marine and coastal ecosystems to avoid significant adverse impacts, including by strengthening their resilience, and take action for their restoration in order to achieve healthy and productive oceans.,14.4 By 2020, effectively regulate harvesting and end overfishing, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and destructive fishing practices and implement science-based management plans, in order to restore fish stocks in the shortest time feasible, at least to levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield as determined by their biological characteristics.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights

2021 Narrative: [UNDP]Nigeria achieved its first international benchmark towards meeting the net zero emission commitment of by 2060 commitment of Mr. President. with the development / launch of the Energy Transition Plan (ETP) to address energy poverty and climate crises. The $1.9 trillion plan will midwife energy sectors shift from dependence on fossil-based systems of consumption/ production to renewable energy sources through mobilization of new investments that will result in creation of new green jobs. The ETP demonstrates Nigeria‚Äôs commitments to ending energy poverty, that will lift 100 million people out of poverty and scale up in flow of modern energy services into the country. It has also catalyzed 10 African countries to engage through an inter-ministerial meeting, with a resultant high level political commitment to the prioritization of improved access to clean energy, especially to the underserved and scaling up private and public investment to USD 2 trillion in new generation, transmission and distribution infrastructure and new energy technologies and delivery systems (Indicator: Coverage of cost-efficient and sustainable energy).

2022 Narrative: UNFAOTwo rounds of data collection to better understand the impact of different shocks on agricultural livelihoods, food security and local value chains were conducted in 2022. Rounds 2 and 3 of the data collection series were completed in July and October and published in August and December 2022 respectively. The survey covered 5 states, Borno, Adamawa, Yobe, Katsina and Zamfara States and consisted of 1,703 and 1,398 randomly selected households in rounds 2 and 3 respectively. It is part of a larger monitoring project taking place in over 25 food crisis countries of the world.

The zero draft of the National School Feeding Policy was completed and is planned to go through a stakeholder review process in the first quarter of 2023. Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY 3: HUMAN WELLBEING AND RESILIENCE
Outcome: OUTCOME 3.1: By 2025, people, especially the vulnerable and marginalized, have equitable access to and utilization of quality basic social and protection services
Output: Output 3.1.1: Strengthened capacity of government and non-government institutions at national and sub national levels to effectively manage and deliver sustainable and inclusive quality social and protection services
Sub-Output: Refugees and other crisis affected people in Uganda have access to adequate nutritious food in times of crisis
Description: This focuses on providing critical food and nutrition assistance to refugees and food-insecure local populations in the Karamoja sub-region and Southwestern Uganda. Uganda experienced climatic shocks, and a continuous refugee influx, which contributed to increased needs. WFP partnered with stakeholders including the Government, UNHCR and cooperating partners, to improve food access, ensure that refugees receive adequate and nutritious food, and promote their financial inclusion. Additionally, food-insecure households in Karamoja benefited from early action interventions, providing both food assistance and nutrition support. WFP also extended food and cash assistance to communities affected by mudslides and floods in Kasese and Ntoroko districts.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: Alliance Forum for Development; Andrew Foods International; Cooperazione e Sviluppo; Hunger Fighters Uganda; Medical Teams International; World Vision Uganda

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 11 Output 3.1.2: People especially the vulnerable and marginalized are empowered to utilize quality basic social and protection services
2024 Narrative: WFP | Refugee ResponseWFP | The crises in neighboring countries caused a significant influx of refugees, raising Uganda's total refugee population to over 1.7 million by the end of 2024 (a 12 per cent increase compared to 2023). Amidst rising needs, funding constraints persisted in the refugee response, with 75 percent of the required funding received against the annual needs-based plan requirement, marking a slight improvement from the 71 percent funding levels in 2023.WFP | With these resources, WFP reached more than 1.39 million settlement-based refugees (56 percent females) with food assistance, a 2 percent increase from last year's 1.36 million refugees. Of those assisted, 27 percent received 33,739 mts of in-kind food assistance, and 73 percent were assisted through Cash Based Transfers (CBT) valued at USD 43.1 million.WFP | WFP continued to provide food assistance based on vulnerability to food insecurity. The most vulnerable refugees (Category 1), including new arrivals, received a 60 percent ration, while the moderately vulnerable refugees (Category 2), making up 82 percent of the population, received a 30 percent ration. The least vulnerable refugees (Category 3), comprising 4 percent of the population, no longer received food assistance, ensuring that resources were directed where they were most needed. WFP | Cash-based Transfers Scale-up and Digitization.WFP | To enhance operational efficiency, accountability, and empower refugees with control and flexibility to prioritize resources while boosting local markets, WFP continued to scale up CBT in its refugee response. By the end of 2024, 73 percent of refugee beneficiaries received assistance through CBT, an increase from 61 percent in 2023. CBT was delivered using three delivery mechanisms: cash in hand, mobile money, and agency banking. Of the 1,018,961 CBT beneficiaries, 132,003 (13 percent) received their assistance through mobile money.However, the refugee response was influenced by the confirmation of in-kind contributions during the second half of the year, which required adjustments to the programme. WFP received a larger proportion of resources as in-kind contributions, which meant that the initially planned scale-up of CBT to 81 percent by December 2024 could not be achieved as anticipated. WFP | Empowering refugees through Financial and Digital LiteracyWFP promoted digital and financial literacy education among refugees receiving CBT, aligning its efforts with government initiatives such as the Parish Development Model (PDM). WFP adopted the national financial literacy curriculum to support and strengthen government systems and trained 85,624 refugees (52 percent Female) transitioning from in-kind assistance to CBT across 12 refugee settlements. The training equipped refugees with knowledge and skills in managing their finances enhance their financial resilience and explore savings and investment opportunities. Impact stories indicated that trained refugees have initiated income-generating activities like poultry and retail shops significantly improved livelihoods.The use of CBT complemented by digital and financial literacy training has advanced refugees' financial inclusion, contributing to the development of a financial sector ecosystem that enables last-mile access to essential financial services and products. "From financial literacy training, I learnt that setting savings goals and saving with a purpose will help me avoid unnecessary expenditure and increase my savings in the group. I used my profits to expand into a bar business, and my operating capital now stands at USD 820."says Butare a financial literacy education beneficiary in Nakivale refugee settlement. WFP | Nutrition AssistanceWFP provided targeted nutrition assistance to prevent and manage acute malnutrition (AMN) among refugees and host communities. A total of 28,805 children and pregnant and breastfeeding women and girls (PBWGs) (90 percent planned) were reached in the management of AMN. Additionally, 250,535 children and PBWGs were reached (92 percent planned) under prevention through the Maternal and Child Health and Nutrition program (MCHN), helping to safeguard their nutritional well-being. In 2024, the proportion of all refugee children (under 5) meeting Minimum Acceptable Diet increased from 9.3 percent in 2023 to 20 percent in 2024 and dietary diversity for women improved from 17 to 19 percent. WFP | Assistance to Crisis- Affected Populations in KaramojaThe food security situation in Karamoja deteriorated in 2024 primarily due to climatic hazards leading to low levels of food production and 45 percent of the population facing high levels of food insecurity (IPC 3 plus). In response, WFP launched an early action response in May 2024 at the start of the lean season to support vulnerable households and protect children under-five, and pregnant and breastfeeding mothers from AMN. To this end, WFP provided cash assistance worth USD 339,241 to 4,275 households across three districts (Kotido, Nabilatuk, and Abim), enabling them to purchase food and seeds for fast-maturing vegetables.Additionally, WFP provided relief assistance to residents affected by severe floods and mudslides in Ntoroko and Kasese districts. A one-time CBT and hybrid (CBT and in-kind) assistance was extended to 17,125 and 5,385 individuals, respectively, who faced food insecurity due to displacement caused by floods and mudslides. In total, 200 mts of in-kind food and CBT worth USD 647,326.40 were distributed to the affected households.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY 2: SHARED PROSPERITY IN A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT
Outcome: OUTCOME 2.1: By 2025, people especially the marginalized and vulnerable, benefit from increased productivity, decent employment and equal rights to resources
Output: Output 2.1.2: People, especially women and youth, have improved access to and utilize innovative practices, technologies, finances, natural and productive resources for decent employment and livelihoods
Sub-Output: Food insecure populations in areas affected by recurring climate shocks have access to adequate and nutritious food all year
Description: WFP aims to ensure food-insecure populations in climate-affected areas have year-round access to adequate and nutritious food. Through its livelihood and resilience-building programme, WFP provided technical assistance to the Government and supported men and women to establish community assets while strengthening the national social protection system for livelihood and resilience programs. Under the school feeding programme, WFP provided nutritious school meals to improve education access, retention, and learning outcomes, while offering technical support to the Government to foster national ownership. These efforts align with Uganda‚Äôs Third National Development Plan (NDP III) and aim to establish a sustainable, government-led Home-Grown School Feeding (HGSF) model which focuses on procuring food locally from SHFs to enhance community resilience and support local food systems. (ACL/SRM & HGSFP)
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme; World Food Programme Multi-donor
Implementation partners: Hunger Fighters Uganda; World Vision Uganda
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Other (including coordination)
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: WFP | Asset Creation and Livelihoods (ACL)WFP reached 11,424 households (57,120 people), of whom 60 percent were women, through food/cash transfers or capacity strengthening under Asset Creation and Livelihoods (ACL) and Self-Reliance Model (SRM) in Karamoja, Southwest, and West Nile. This represents more than a threefold increase compared to last year (rising from 3,630 households to 11,424. The increase is attributed to the enrolment of new beneficiaries under the SRM in five refugee settlements.WFP | Various livelihood assets were established, rehabilitated, or maintained in Refugee Hosting Districts and the semi-arid Karamoja region. A total of 37 fishponds were established and stocked with 58,500 fish fingerlings enabling beneficiaries to improve their diets with 15.3 percent of women of reproductive age reporting consumption of more than five food across Karamoja. Additionally, 206 households engaged in fish farming generating approximately USD 10,300 as income from fish sales which supported other needs. The initial investment cost was USD25,514.WFP | Over 1,480 beehives were maintained while a honey mini value chain analysis of Karamoja honey production revealed that on average, participating households sold 20 liters (each liter sold at USD 26), generating USD 520 per household. The income supplemented household food needs.WFP | In Karamoja, beneficiaries expanded vegetable production on over 50 acres, while in the Southwest, beneficiaries trained used own resources to sustain vegetable farming using irrigation systems established three years ago. In Kyaka II settlement, beneficiaries continued investing in livelihood enterprises at the incubation hub, sustaining vegetable production, introducing piggery and fishponds, and identifying markets for their products. These practices were replicated at the household level, boosting vegetable and fish production. The establishment of irrigation systems enabled year-round production with improved productivity, supported by training in agronomic practices.WFP | In Karamoja, 4,140 beneficiaries (828 households) participated in Labour-Intensive Public Works, receiving USD 49,500 in cash assistance for their labour in expanding vegetable production, enhancing household food security and nutrition. In Karamoja, 80% of surveyed households reported benefiting from an enhanced livelihood asset base.WFP | To support production and consumption, WFP rehabilitated water facilities. Through a water assessment done by District Local Government and Ministry of Water and Environment, WFP repaired 45 hand pumped boreholes. Some of these boreholes were around schools, "We feel relived having water in school because learners no longer move out to fetch water. Instead, we now have members from the nearby communities coming to fetch water from our borehole," says Kizito Aleper a teacher at Daniel Comboni Secondary School in Karamoja.WFP | Working with the Uganda National Meteorological Authority (UNMA), WFP installed five automatic weather stations to enhance preparedness and response to address recurrent floods and mudslides in Kisoro, Ntoroko and Kasese districts, which have impacted livelihoods and increased food insecurity and malnutrition over the past three years.WFP | The Self Reliance ModelThe SRM aims to transition refugees from dependence on humanitarian aid to self-sustenance by building capacities and supporting market-oriented livelihood enterprises. In 2024, the SRM enrolled a first cohort of 7,372 refugees and 3,160 host communities in Nakivale, Oruchinga (Southwest), Rhino, Bidi Bidi and Lobule settlements (West Nile). WFP supported the Government in developing a self-reliance measurement framework which is now the benchmark for partners to assess the impact of their efforts in enhancing refugee livelihoods, resilience, and self-reliance. The tool was officially launched and rolled out across all 13 refugee settlements in Uganda by the Government, agencies, and development partners.Through the SRM, participants received social empowerment through coaching, mentorship, and community participatory planning. Half of the participants engaged in on-farm activities, benefiting from inputs, tools, and training in agronomic practices and animal husbandry. Together, they cultivated 3,718 acres of land, producing various crops at both household and group levels. Another 41 percent of the participants turned to off-farm activities, receiving training and support in business planning. The remaining 9 percent opted for non-farm livelihoods, enrolling in vocational training programs. The latter group was supported with startup grants of USD 550, enabling them to establish small-scale enterprises and contribute to local economies.The SRM also included Nutricash support, enrolling 2,000 pregnant and breastfeeding mothers who received USD 13 monthly to enhance their nutritional well-being. Additionally, 500 refugee aged 80 and above were provided with USD 6.80 monthly mirroring a government-led initiative and testing its scalability to the refugee population.WFP | School Based ProgrammesWFP continued to work closely with the Ministry of Education and Sports (MoES), District Local Governments (DLGs), and local communities to support the school feeding programme in Karamoja sub-region. The MoES provided technical leadership at national and sub-national levels, while local government education staff worked with WFP to ensure smooth operations in all supported schools. By end of 2024, the program had expanded to 320 schools (compared to 315 in 2023), including primary, secondary, and vocational schools. However, Karamoja continues to face significant challenges, with literacy rates at just 25 percent compared to the national average of 74 percent. Compounding vulnerabilities and persistent food insecurity is forcing many families to prioritize household responsibilities over education, particularly for girls. This has led to irregular attendance, high dropout rates, and poor academic performance.WFP provided hot meals to 255,000 learners (47percent female) across the 320 supported schools, an 18 percent increase from the 216,000 learners reached in 2023. Despite this progress, funding shortfalls led to maintaining ration size at 80 percent. Nevertheless, enrolment in WFP-assisted schools rose by 16 percent compared to 2023, with female enrolment increasing by 17 percent and male enrolment by 16 percent.WFP | To enhance nutrition and dietary diversity, WFP, working with the International Potato Centre and the National Agricultural Research Organization, promoted the integration of Orange-Fleshed Sweet Potatoes (OFSP) into school meals. In 2024, WFP supported 140 schools, up from 99 in 2023, with 83 actively planting OFSP. The initiative improved food security, nutrition, and incomes, as parents received OFSP vines to grow at home, generating income and boosting livelihoods. This also helped offset school ration cuts. Additionally, WFP worked with the government to develop a standardized School Feeding Menu, ensuring balanced, sustainable, and locally sourced meals that align with national nutrition goals and strengthen food systems.To promote clean cooking and improve fuel efficiency, WFP piloted energy-saving cooking stoves in 65 schools under the school meals programme in Karamoja. Under this initiative, WFP refurbished 55 kitchens, installed 65 institutional improved cookstoves, trained 300 school cooks, distributed 259 household improved cook stoves and supported establishment of 10 local energy access entrepreneurs. Preliminary data shows that the improved stoves have reduced wood consumption and cooking time by half. "Every month the school has been spending USD 80 on purchasing firewood and this is a huge expense," says Agnes Acayo, the Headteacher Looro Primary School. "With energy efficient kitchens, this monthly cost of firewood has reduced to about USD 27".To ensure transparency and accountability at the school level, WFP provided tablets to 315 supported schools. Therefore, schools can accurately track meal distribution, monitor nutritional standards, and prevent misuse of resources.To support the development of a national school feeding policy, WFP worked with MoES to conduct and finalize regional consultations across the country. Advocacy efforts led by WFP resulted in Uganda joining the School Meals Coalition, underscoring the government‚Äôs dedication to sustainable school feeding. This milestone also led to the formation of a multisectoral national working group to strengthen coordination at the national level. The membership of the Government to the School meals Coalition has raised the profile of Uganda‚Äôs school feeding programme. The Government of Uganda announced its commitment to contribute resources to school feeding under the Universal Primary Education Programme. This demonstrates Government‚Äôs recognition of school feeding as a critical investment in the health, education, and future of Uganda‚Äôs children.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY 3: HUMAN WELLBEING AND RESILIENCE
Outcome: OUTCOME 3.1: By 2025, people, especially the vulnerable and marginalized, have equitable access to and utilization of quality basic social and protection services
Output: Output 3.1.1: Strengthened capacity of government and non-government institutions at national and sub national levels to effectively manage and deliver sustainable and inclusive quality social and protection services
Sub-Output: National and subnational Institutions in Uganda have increased capacity to coordinate and manage food security and nutrition programmes by enhancing nutrition sensitive programming by 2030 (CSSP)
Description: Strengthen the capacity of national and subnational institutions in Uganda to effectively coordinate and manage food security and nutrition programmes and respond to shocks. WFP supports SDG targets 2.1-3 by enhancing nutrition, health, education outcomes, and livelihoods for individuals and households. The Child-Sensitive Social Protection Programme (CSSP) focuses on, enhancing social protection systems to deliver nutrition-sensitive interventions
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Government of Uganda
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Other (including coordination)
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 12 Output 3.1.3: Strengthened policy and regulatory environment to promote equitable access and utilization of rights based and gender responsive social and protection services that prevent, mitigate and respond to shocks and stress.; 11 Output 3.1.2: People especially the vulnerable and marginalized are empowered to utilize quality basic social and protection services
2024 Narrative: WFP collaborated with the Government to strengthen Uganda‚Äôs social protection policy framework. A key milestone was the launch of the National Social Protection Strategy (2024-2029). WFP also facilitated a Regulatory Impact Assessment in preparation for the policy review set for 2025/26. WFP contributed to the creation of essential social protection instruments, including the Shock Responsive Social Protection Framework, the Social Protection Communications and Advocacy Strategy, the Complaints and Grievance Management Guidelines, and a feasibility report for the National Social Registry under the World Bank-funded Fourth Northern Uganda Social Action Fund (NUSAF4) Project.WFP designed the NutriCash Management Information System (MIS) within government infrastructure that will host data for all nutrition sensitive Social Protection interventions, decentralizing the SAGE MIS to support on demand registration and exit of older persons, and expanding the National Single Registry, which now holds data on 2.6 million beneficiaries and 4.4 million applicants across ten programs.Advocacy efforts undertaken jointly with the Uganda Parliamentary Forum on Social Protection successfully secured increased funding for the Senior Citizens‚Äô Grant and reversed proposed 20 percent budget cuts for 2024/2025 as well as reduction of eligibility age for Older Persons with Disability from 80+ years to 75 years and above thus enhancing inclusivity and expanding the fiscal space for social protection.To build technical capacities on Social Protection (SP), WFP conducted 26 training initiatives for 374 government officials and 13,727 program participants. These efforts were complemented through learning visit to Kenya and Pakistan as part of WFP‚Äôs efforts to strengthen systems and south-to-south learning. The visit aimed to exchange knowledge, experiences, and lessons on the Benazir Income Support Programme and the National Database and Registration Authority. Insights gained from this visit will contribute to the development of Uganda's Dynamic Social Registry to enhance effective targeting and programme coordination. WFP | Nutrition-sensitive Social Protection ProgrammesWorking with the Ministry of Gender, Labour, and Social Development (MGLSD), the OPM, and DLGs, WFP reinforced the implementation of the NutriCash intervention across eight refugee-hosting districts in West Nile. This was aimed at supporting the nutrition needs of mothers and children within the first 1,000 days of life through a package of monthly cash transfers, SBCC messages, Financial Literacy and Backyard Gardening (BYG). WFP disbursed USD 1.4 million in monthly CBT to 13,000 pregnant and breastfeeding women and children under two, marking a 36 percent decline from 2023, when USD 2.2 million was distributed to 13,600 beneficiaries. The reduction was due to the exit of over 3,000 beneficiaries cumulatively from the CBT component as their babies made two years thus cupping the 1,000-day window. Despite this decline, 90 percent of recipients used the funds to purchase food, underscoring the intervention's critical role in improving household nutrition amidst resource limitations.WFP complemented CBT with SBCC where 13,301 programme participants and their spouses received training in care practices, while 15,102 benefited from financial literacy training. The initiative also established 48 regenerative backyard gardens to promote soil and water conservation, addressing drought challenges. Monitoring reports showed significant improvement in the Minimum Dietary Diversity Score for Women (MDD-W) from 28 percent to 38 percent and the percentage of children meeting minimum dietary diversity rose from 4 percent to 12 percent between 2023 and 2024.WFP expanded the NutriCash program to 3,500 beneficiaries in Karamoja and the Southwest under the resilience and SRM and is supporting its integration into the NUSAF-4 Project. WFP and MGLSD are piloting the Social Cash Transfer for Elderly Refugees, targeting 500 refugees to demonstrate the benefit of integrating refugees in national social protection programs.WFP supported targeted micro-projects across eight districts, tackling teenage pregnancy and child marriage, aligned to the national strategy. As a result, 1,444 teenage parents (96 percent female) were enrolled into 14 government-aided Vocational Training Institutions, coupled with the provision of startup kits to help further support their transition to self-reliance. These were dully graduated in December 2024 with commitment from the DLGs to link them to Government Programmes such as Generating Growth Opportunities and Productivity for Women Entrepreneurs, Parish Development Model and upcoming NUSAF4.Additionally, WFP invested USD 198,000 to bolster systems strengthening with the MGLSD using the Harmonized Approaches for Cash Transfers. This was focused on enhancing social protection data management and reporting systems, capacity building, cash transfer delivery and harmonizing complaints and Grievance redress mechanisms for effective implementation of social protection programs.

2023 Narrative: FAO continued to contribute for increased availability of information to enhance understanding of the impacts of multiple shocks on agricultural production, livelihoods, food security and agriculture markets by applying the Data in Emergencies Monitoring (DIEM) platform. The fifth round, with representativeness at admin 1 level and targeting 1,956 households across eleven provinces via telephone was conducted in the beginning of the year. The sixth round started at the end of 2023 and analysis will be finalized in February 2024. Additionally, through the DIEM impact module, FAO conducted a remote sensing assessment that was presented twice to the agricultural partners (AgRed) group during the first and second Freddy cyclones.

As of Sept 2021(To be updated) 3,220 ( M =1449, F = 1771) children were admitted in the SAM treatment program. 2012 were successfully cured and discharged from the program. The treatment results show a successful cure rate of 91.6%, more than the 75% target, thereby reducing deaths to 1.1% and the defaulter rate was 5.7%.

2021 Narrative:
This consists in promoting the production and consumption of bio fortified crops by training 200 people. however, the program was not implemented as a result of the GAFSP reappraisal. To be conducted in 2022.

In August 2021,FAO  in collaboration with FTS and School Agriculture and Food Management Unit (SAFMU) of the Ministry of Basic and Secondary Education (MoBSE) conducted cooking demonstrations for 60 school cooks in the project intervention areas. For visibility purposes, the project distributed branded T-shirts during the cooking demonstrations.
2022 Narrative: Supported 2 SME flour milling companies to produce locally made complementary feeding with biofortified crops. Over 15000 improved PVA maize seeds and 13000 orange flesh potatoes were distributed to 3000 farmers for multiplication and 750 livestock farmers benefitted from poultry schemes.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY 3: HUMAN WELLBEING AND RESILIENCE
Outcome: OUTCOME 3.1: By 2025, people, especially the vulnerable and marginalized, have equitable access to and utilization of quality basic social and protection services
Output: Output 3.1.1: Strengthened capacity of government and non-government institutions at national and sub national levels to effectively manage and deliver sustainable and inclusive quality social and protection services
Sub-Output: 3.1.1.1 Provide technical and financial support to government and non government actors to expand and sustainably provide  high impact food security and nutrition interventions for vulnerable and marginalised population especially adolescents and women of reproductive age in development and humanitarian situations
Description:
UNHCR
UNHCR
Achievements: The food security sector continues to contribute to Strategic Development Goal 2.1 by improving access to nutritious food among refugees and asylum seekers in the 13 refugee settlements in Uganda. Furthermore, the sector promotes the self-reliance of refugee communities through complimentary activities. The partners reached 1.39 million beneficiaries through the provision of in-kind food as well as cash-based transfers by the end of Q2. However, owing to the prioritization exercise conducted in July 2023, there was a reduction of 14% of beneficiaries who received in-kind assistance and 6% reduction in cash assistance. Additionally, the further reduction in in-kind rations in most refugee settlements due to limitations in funding increased cash enrolments since beneficiaries preferred cash to the reduced rations. Overall, the proportion of beneficiaries who received cash assistance increased from 60% to 63% from Q1 to Q4. 
Digital cash transfer mechanisms through agent banking continued to be scaled up, and cash beneficiaries owning bank accounts increased from 36 percent to 41 percent out of the overall total cash beneficiaries by the end of the year. To increase access to digital payment instruments, Mobile money will start in Kyangwali and Kiryandogo settlements. In addition to increasing access to digital payment instruments through agency banking, cash beneficiaries received financial literacy skills. A total of 2,954 beneficiaries were trained during the reporting period across all 13 settlements. Efforts to mitigate malnutrition continue to be strengthened through building the capacity of health workers, Village Health Teams (VHTs), and other community structures in providing Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF) knowledge to promote better household nutrition. Similarly, active case findings have supported in managing the nutrition situation in the settlements. Currently, the recovery rate remains above the threshold with an average of 93% discharged as cured from the programme within the reporting period.
Agency abbreviations: FAO; UN Women; UNFPA; UNHCR; UNICEF; WFP; WHO

Implementation partners: Africa Humanitarian Action; Baylor College of Medicine Children's Foundation Uganda; Delight Uganda Ltd.; Doctors with Africa CUAMM; Heifer International; International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; KadAfrica; Medical Teams International; Norwegian Refugee Council; Soroti Rural Development Agency (SORUDA); The International Rescue Committee; Uganda Ministry of Health; United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 3 Good Health and Well-being
Geography: Kampala; Moroto; Kikuube; Mbale; Madi Okollo; Koboko; Kotido; Mbarara; Soroti; Isingiro; Lira; Kiryandongo; Adjumani; Jinja; Karenga; Amudat; Sironko; Obongi; Uganda; Kamwenge; Nabilatuk; Nakapiripirit; Gulu; Northern; Lamwo; Kyegegwa; Abim; Kaabong; Western; Central; Eastern; Napak; Kayunga; Mubende; Yumbe; Arua
