Focal users: John Bosco Mbabazi; Sarah Rubereti; Aaron Arinaitwe; Nasan Natseri; Joseph Musasizi; Robert Kalyebara; Lilian Likicho
2022 Narrative: In partnership with World Vision Uganda (WVU), the UN provided unconditional cash assistance to 5,000 households, of whom 3,408 were headed by women (68 percent), approximately 32,357 people, in five districts of Karamoja (Abim, Kaabong, Kotido, Moroto and Napak). A total of USD 311,620 was distributed, with each household receiving a one‚Äëtime transfer of USD 62.20 (approximately UGX 238,390). Results from a monitoring study indicated that over 90 percent of beneficiaries accessed better quality meals, 52 percent consumed larger portions of meals, and 44 percent invested some of the cash in income generating activities. The UN supported the government of Uganda to respond to a worse drought in three years in Karamoja and provided food assistance to 1.36 million refugees in 2022. Coupled with refugee influxes, the government and UNICEF prioritized protecting and saving lives of children affected by malnutrition, which rose to critical levels in some districts.The 2022 Integrated Phase Classification (IPC) conducted with support from the UN classified all nine districts of Karamoja as Phase III (Crisis). Furthermore, the Food Security and Nutrition Assessment (FSNA) supported by the UN found a significant increase in GAM rates in 2022 over those recorded during the 2021 period. The UN supported Ministry of Health to develop the National Emergency Health and Nutrition Response plan for Karamoja and surrounding districts as well as the ME framework for nutrition response. Further support was provided to conduct a Health and Nutrition Service Assessment in 150 health facilities in 19 districts.The UN provided food and nutrition assistance was extended to 217,747 pregnant and lactating women and children. In addition, a total of 1,839 MT of specialized nutritious food was distributed to 15,591 beneficiaries. The UN supported the life-saving treatment services to 76,938 children, including the estimated 23,000 severe malnourished children in Karamoja and refugee children, and supported infants affected by Ebola. Protective food assistance worth USD188,756 was distributed to 30,548 households through in- kind and cash-based transfers. Furthermore 3,629MT of food was distributed to Karamoja through the Office of the Prime Minister as part of its emergency response in Karamoja. The food assistance represented a 17 percent increase in support in 2022 compared to those in 2021.The UN further provided two doses of 3,702,620 Vitamin A doses vitamin to 3,829,708 of children 6-59 months through the health system. As part of its support to community nutrition, 1,352,763 caregivers were reached with IYCF counselling services during ANC in 29 districts. The UN supported the roll out of the national nutrition platform. The UN supported the OPM to develop a comprehensive multi-sectoral workplan, together with 10 Ministries Agencies and Departments to strengthen nutrition governance and decision making through the National Nutrition Information Platform that was launched and roll out by the Prime Minister. The support enabled the UN to advocate for nutrition and children‚Äôs issues in the national food system transformation agenda for Uganda. Support enabled government to develop nutrition governance and ME framework. This strengthened the functionality of nutrition coordination mechanisms across the different coordination structures at both national and district levels.The UN in collaboration with nutrition implementing partners and district local governments, the UN supported implementation of community-based supplementary feeding Programmes in Karamoja in 126 health facilities and through 253 outreaches/outposts treating 63,374 children moderately acute malnourished reaching out to 30,966 pregnant and lactating women. Over 4.9 million people were reached and delivered key nutrition messages through different platforms like U-report and targeted radio campaigns during the World Breastfeeding Week alone. These efforts strengthened community mass screening, increased family led MUAC outreaches especially in Karamoja and refugee settlements with over 2,538 mothers reached with nutrition related services.The school feeding programme with the MOES and Karamoja district local governments with support from the UN provided 5,806 MT of food for one hot meals to 205,903 learners (97,793 females, 108,110 males) in 315 schools in all districts of Karamoja.The UN supported capacity building efforts on IMAM, basic skills in gender and integration of IMAM and nutrition programming to health workers to improve gender responsive and sensitive nutrition programming, improve nutrition screening and counselling, improve quality of education and real time data in support to education management system and digitization of data collection tools. This contributed to improved household access and nutritious food. This bolstered community capacity to cope with shocks in three regions of West Nile, Southwest and Karamoja and among nationals and refugee populations.Support provided enabled the rollout and implementation of maternal infant young child and adolescent nutrition (MIYCAN) strategy to prevent malnutrition, promoted and protected child and maternal optimal feeding practices through behavior change. Further support was provided in the implementation of anemia control and prevention priority actions, surveillance resulting in the reduction of the anemia prevalence among children in 11 of the 14 refugee locations. The UN support in anemia reduction and prevention priority including testing and treating, supplementation, deworming, and malaria control at both community and facility levels to over 146,000 new arrival person-in-need.The UN supported public health emergency programmes increasing government and health facility readiness and rapid deployment of health workers and 85 nutritionists (47 female) and 165 health workers (91 females), 171 health workers reinforcing TB management and prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse and gender mainstreaming. In 2022, WFP distributed 73,799 metric tonnes (mt) and USD 42 million to 1.36 million refugees spread across 13 settlements. The Orgnaization also scaled up the use of unrestricted cash transfers to all refugee settlements, reaching 56 percent of the total refugee population receiving general food assistance, with 36 percent of refugees assisted to open bank accounts. This was done in recognition of the benefits and inherent opportunities for both refugees and host communities, such as the multiplier effect of cash. Cash injections created additional economic value by stimulating economic activities, besides other benefits such as increased consumer choice, and digital financial inclusion. WFP partnered with Andre Foods International to implement Community Based Supplementary Feeding Programme in which 91 care groups were established and trained, and 2,203 village health teams received on-job mentorship to extend nutrition and health services at the community and household levels.
2023 Narrative: WFP: Assistance to Refugees With available resources, WFP assisted 1.36 million refugees across 13 refugee settlements with in-kind support and CBT. Quality assurance measures were embedded in programme implementation to ensure assistance reached the intended beneficiary households. WFP delivered 39,235 metric tons (MT) of food and USD 41.5 million in CBT. Results from the Refugee Food Security and Nutrition Assessment (FSNA)8 indicated a general deterioration in the food security situation with 68 percent of the targeted households classified as moderately and severely food insecure. This was demonstrated by an increase in the proportion of households reporting poor levels of food consumption from 9 percent in 2022 to 11 percent in 2023. There has also been an increase in the proportion of households employing crisis and emergency coping strategies from 37 percent in 2022 to 40 percent in 2023. In line with nutrition , the dietary diversity score and the minimum dietary diversity decreased. This is attributed to ration cuts which deepened acute food insecurity, increased market prices which affected household purchasing power, and other contributing factors that aggravated the situation such as climatic shocks and hazardsFood Assistance to Crisis-affected people in Uganda WFP provided food assistance to the Ugandan population affected by crisis to address alarming levels of food insecurity and malnutrition in Karamoja sub-region due to severe drought. During the lean season response, food and nutrition assistance was provided between October and December 2023 to address food insecurity, through cash-based 15 2023 | Uganda Annual Country Report transfers, reaching 18,539 people in two hot spot sub-counties of Kaabong and Kotido districts. The response was based on the findings of the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) analysis that indicated high Global Acute Malnutrition (GAM) rates above the emergency threshold of 15 percent.9 Additionally, WFP implemented a flood recovery response through a one-off cash assistance provided to 17,667 people in Kisoro district affected by floods and exposed to food insecurity. Efforts such as capacity strengthening, entrepreneurship training, expanding participation as mobile banking agents, and linkages to village savings and loans associations significantly enhanced the ability of refugees, particularly women, to utilize digital and financial services. These initiatives played a crucial role in empowering refugees by providing them with the necessary skills and resources to access and leverage financial services, thereby contributing to their economic independence and self-sufficiency. Similarly, mainstreaming gender responsive SBCC was provided to stimulate positive behaviour change in nutrition practices by engaging men and women to challenge social and cultural norms, stereotypes, and biases. SBCC contributed to male engagement on child and household nutrition. This was demonstrated by 41 father care groups (FCGs) formed.Promoting Digital Financial Inclusion for Refugees WFP promoted digital financial inclusion through enhancing access to digital payment instruments reaching 345,502 beneficiaries across all settlements. Similarly, financial literacy education was promoted, equipping 86,459 (57 percent female and 43 percent male) refugees with knowledge and skills to better manage their own finances. Gender-transformative approaches continued to be integrated into the refugee response to address the barriers that prevent women‚Äôs participation in the economy and enhance women‚Äôs empowerment through financial inclusion and literacy. A total of 49,282 women were trained on financial literacy. This has contributed to increased joint decision-making by women and men within the household on the use of cash transfers. In addition, 47 percent8 of households reported improved spending habits, an increase from 22 percent in 2022. Nutrition Response:To address high levels of acute malnutrition among children and pregnant and breastfeeding women in refugee and host communities, WFP implemented Targeted Supplementary Feeding (TSF) and Integrated Maternal Child Health and Nutrition (IMCHN) programmes. Due to funding shortfalls, WFP was not able to meet the requirements for specialized nutritious foods (SNFs) for these two activities, forcing WFP to prioritize rations for the TSF programme to ensure that treatment of moderate acute malnutrition was sustained. WFP reached 32,198 women and children with nutrition support to treat acute malnutrition, in the MCHN programme, MCHN rations were reduced by 50 percent reaching 99,768 women and childrenUNHCRAchievements: The food security sector continues to contribute to Strategic Development Goal 2.1 by improving access to nutritious food among refugees and asylum seekers in the 13 refugee settlements in Uganda. Furthermore, the sector promotes the self-reliance of refugee communities through complimentary activities. The partners reached 1.39 million beneficiaries through the provision of in-kind food as well as cash-based transfers. There was a 5% overall increase in cash beneficiaries in Quarter 2, compared to Quarter 1. The increment is attributed to continuous enrolment of beneficiaries from food to cash. Additionally, the further reduction in in-kind rations in most refugee settlements due to limitations in funding increased cash enrolments since beneficiaries preferred cash to the reduced rations. Digital cash transfer mechanisms through agent banking continued to be scaled up, and cash beneficiaries owning bank accounts increased from 36 percent to 41 percent out of the overall total cash beneficiaries by the end of the quarter. In order to increase access to digital payment instruments, Mobile money will start in Kyangwali and Kiryandogo settlements. In addition to increasing access to digital payment instruments through agency banking, cash beneficiaries received financial literacy skills. A total of 2,954 beneficiaries were trained during the reporting period across all 13 settlements. Efforts to mitigate malnutrition continue to be strengthened through building capacity of health workers, Village Health Teams (VHTs) and other community structures in providing Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF) knowledge to promote better household nutrition. Similarly, active case findings have supported in managing the nutrition situation in the settlements. Currently, the recovery rate remains above the threshold with an average of 93% discharged as cured from the programme within the reporting period.UNHCR in partnership with Ministry of Health (MoH), Ministry of Local Government (MoLG), Office of the Prime Minister (OPM), WFP, UNICEF, and NGOs delivered preventive and curative nutrition interventions and[EO1]  nutrition-sensitive food security interventions that are designed to contribute to refugee nutrition and food security. UNHCR supported the implementation of nutrition interventions as part of the broader primary health care services at both community and health facility levels and are inclusive of refugee and host communities. Curative interventions largely involved the early identification, referral, treatment, and follow-up of children and women with acute malnutrition using a community network of 2700 village health teams (VHTs). About 31,000 clients were reached with treatment services for acute malnutrition across all refugee settlements, 70% of whom were children below 5 years. Preventive interventions were largely centered on promoting optimal feeding practices of mothers and caregivers, infants, and children through behavior change strategies adapted to both emergency and non-emergency settings. UNHCR supported health facilities to provide complementary services like deworming, vitamin A supplementation, and immunization at the young child clinics and through the bi-annual MoH-led integrated child health days. Nutrition services were offered in refugee settlements, reception centers, and transit centers. UNHCR supported the implementation of nutrition surveillance and surveys to inform performance, resource mobilization, and to determine the situation on key indicators. The July 2023 Food Security and Nutrition Assessment (FSNA) is the main reference point for nutrition survey data needs in the refugee settlements and host districts. UNHCR worked in collaboration with WFP and NGOs to implement nutrition-sensitive food security services like backyard gardening through training, providing inputs, and providing key messages to ultimately improve household dietary diversity. This was done using a network of 769 care groups and 10,766 care group volunteers targeting around 107,660 households across all refugee locations. UNICEFBuilt the capacity of over 285 community development officers in nutrition reporting and provided 285 smart tablets to aid data collection improving electronic monitoring and supervision tools for the social development sectorWith UNICEF support the MoH implemented high-impact interventions including adaptation of the global and regional Maternal Nutrition Action framework and accelerating initiatives on egg consumption. Through these efforts, key maternal nutrition actions have been prioritized, aiming to enhance optimal maternal nutrition, fortify the pathway to ensure the birth of healthy children, and empower the health system to integrate the prevention of child wasting into new-born care services. Vitamin A was provided to 5,023,059 children aged 6-59 months thus contributing to a national coverage of 62.3% in the first semester. A total of 4,240,520 caregivers received IYCF counselling services during ANC services, and 978,592 pregnant women received IFA during their first ANC visit. Furthermore 8,846,353 and 5,323,722 children aged 12-59 months received deworming medication during the first and second semesters, respectively.Empowered communities and caregivers for the early identification of malnutrition, developed tools and disseminated data at all levels. Supported screening of 3,195,275 children through family MUAC to identify and refer cases of severe wasting for treatment. This enabled treatment of 58,252 children aged 6-59 months suffering from severe acute malnutrition. WHOIn strengthening the national nutrition information systems;‚Ä¢	Supported District led mentorship and supportive supervision on nutrition data management in 4 focus districts‚Ä¢	Supported the development and dissemination of nutrition reports (monthly, quarterly newsletters, and annual report for FY 2022/23)‚Ä¢	Regional nutrition performance review meeting for West Nile and Tooro regions‚Ä¢	Supported 1 annual nutrition symposium to review NIS and disseminate informationFAOFAO has supported access of short maturing assorted staple crops and vegetable crops seeds to 1,798 refugee and 1,367 host community households through an electronic value voucher of USD 20, by working with 4 local agro-input dealer shops in Kiryandongo refugee hosting district for these households to access seeds of their choice. The 3,165 households were also supported through capacity buidling on good agricultural practices to increase their production, post-harvest handling to reduce waste and market linkages for selling of surplus produce for additional income generation. Similarly, in Nakivale, 5,912 refugee households have been supported to access short maturing assorted staple crops and vegetable crops through an electronic value voucher of USD 16, by working with 8 local agro-inputs dealer shops in Nakivale for these households to choose their preferred seeds. The refugee households were provided with capacity building on basic good agricultural practices by the extension service at the district level.WFPWFP assisted 1.36 million refugees across 13 refugee settlements with in-kind support and CBT. Quality assurance measures were embedded in programme implementation to ensure assistance reached the intended beneficiary households. WFP delivered 39,235 metric tons (MT) of food and USD 41.5 million in CBT.To enhance operational efficiencies, WFP scaled up the use of CBT from 57 percent in 2022 to 61 per cent in 2023. This expansion included a 6 percent increase in beneficiaries receiving digital assistance through cash accounts, specifically agency banking and mobile money. A pilot on the use of mobile money was conducted in two refugee settlements (Kyangwali and Kiryandongo) with a total of 4,883 beneficiaries reached.CBT interventions are supported by market intelligence, including the Market Functionality Index (MFI) assessment and price monitoring, which provide a detailed understanding of target markets under all Area Offices. Trader capacity assessments contributed to the evidence base for the mobile money roll-out and are informing the design of retailmarket development activities. WFP continues to collaborate with mobile network operators to address key challenges identified such as low rate of mobile phone ownership, network connectivity, and inter-operability amongst financial service providers.WFP promoted digital financial inclusion through enhancing access to digital payment instruments reaching 345,502 beneficiaries across all settlements. Similarly, financial literacy education was promoted, equipping 86,459 (57 percent female and 43 percent male) refugees with knowledge and skills to better manage their own finances.A total of 49,282 women were trained on financial literacy. This has contributed to increased joint decision-making by women and men within the household on the use of cash transfers. In addition, 47 percent[2] of households reported improved spending habits, an increase from 22 percent in 2022.To address high levels of acute malnutrition among children and pregnant and breastfeeding women in refugee and host communities, WFP implemented Targeted Supplementary Feeding (TSF) and Integrated Maternal Child Health and Nutrition (IMCHN) programmes. However, due to funding shortfalls, WFP was not able to meet the requirements for specialized nutritious foods (SNFs) for these two activities, forcing WFP to prioritize rations for the TSF programme to ensure that treatment of moderate acute malnutrition was sustained, reaching 32,198 women and children. The IMCHN rations were reduced by 50 percent reaching 99,768 women and children.A total of 2,314 health workers and village health teams were trained and mentored.During the lean season response, food and nutrition assistance was provided between October and December 2023 to address food insecurity, through cash-based transfers, reaching 17,629 people (39 percent of planned beneficiaries) in two hot spot sub-counties of Kaabong and Kotido districts.Similarly, mainstreaming gender responsive SBCC was provided to stimulate positive behaviour change in nutrition practices by engaging men and women to challenge social and cultural norms,stereotypes, and biases. SBCC contributed to male engagement on child and household nutrition. This was demonstrated by 41 father care groups (FCGs) formed.WFP provided nutritious meals to 216,301 learners (47 percent girls and 53 percent boys) in 315 educational facilities (primary, secondary, and vocational). This is an increase of 5 percentcompared to 2022. School education outcomes indicated an increase in enrolment by 24 percent overall (27 percent for girls and 21 percent for boys) in 2023 compared to 2022 (20 percent). The attendance rate stood at 72 percent (72 percent girls and 72 percent boys).The Home-Grown School Feeding (HGSF) programme (HGSFP) was implemented in 315 schools to provide safe and nutritious school meals purchased from local smallholder farmers. The HGSF links contributed to the agricultural sector by strengthening the capacity of smallholder farmers in agriculture and creating predictable markets through local procurement from schools. Through the continued focus on HGSF, WFP registered a fivefold increase (from 414 in 2022 to 2,345 MTs in 2023) in the local procurement of food from smallholder farmers in Karamoja, which translated to an additional USD 1.9 million injection into the local economy.In addition, the establishment of Orange Fleshed Sweet Potato (OFSP) vine multiplication centres in Karamoja has increased the consumption of sweet potatoes in schools. A total of 80 schools complemented WFP meals with sweet potatoes. This helped mitigate the impact of ration cuts experienced towards the end of the year, as well as contributed to diversification of diets in schools. Furthermore, the establishment of sweet potato gardens promotes agricultural education and sustainability within the school curriculum.To reduce food losses and enhance storage in schools, WFP provided 3,000 silos to more than 200 schools, increasing storage capacity from 357 MT to 1,050 MT. In addition, WFP trained 2,094 individuals on school food management

2024 Narrative: WFP continued its support Burkinabe refugees at the Tarikom Settlement Centre and their five host communities in Upper East. In collaboration with GRB, UNHCR and World Vision Ghana, WFP provided unconditional cash assistance to 1,730 refugees (412 males, 1,318 females) and host community members (2,510 males , 1,495 females) through Absa Bank and MTN Mobile Money Limited. The refugees included pregnant and breastfeeding women, adolescent girls, children (6 -23 months). Priority was given to female-headed households, and persons living with disabilities (PLWD). This assistance enhanced their food and nutrition security need by enabling households to purchase nutritious foods, reduced risk of hunger, and improved dietary intake, particularly the vulnerable groups. It also promoted social cohesion between refugees and host communities

SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries,8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.4 Improve progressively, through 2030, global resource efficiency in consumption and production and endeavour to decouple economic growth from environmental degradation, in accordance with the 10-year framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production, with developed countries taking the lead.,9.2 Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry's share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.,9.a Facilitate sustainable and resilient infrastructure development in developing countries through enhanced financial, technological and technical support to African countries, least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and Small Island developing States.

2023 Narrative: FAO has provided guidelines to FGS MoAI on the development of seed frameworks. As a result, the FGS MoAI has engaged a consultant to facilitate the process of formulating seed regulations and standards, that drafting seed regulations will start early 2024 with key stakeholder engagement workshop.  The seed security assessment activity has been pushed to early 2024. During the last quarter of 2023, the MoAI technical staff have been undergoing introductory training on seed production and certification in preparation for a training on seed security assessment to carry out the assessment. FAO has enhanced the availability of early generation seed of sorghum and cowpea from KALRO and ICRIST.  1.	300 kg pre-basic seed of climate smart cowpea varieties have been procured from KALRO and supplied to a contracted seed company for multiplication and distribution to farmers. The seed crop was planted and is at vegetative stage. 2.	150kg pre-basic seed of climate sorghum has been sourced from KALRO and supplied to a contracted seed company (CSET) for further multiplication and distribution to farmers. The seed is yet to be planted; the delay has been caused by El-nino rains. 3.	ICRISAT has been engaged to produce 500kg breeder seed of two climate smart sorghum seed varieties for further multiplication next Gu 2024. The seed is expected to be delivered in January 2024. 4.	Amoud University from Somaliland has also selected to test cowpea and sorghum climate adaptability and suitability for further scale up in Somaliland.  In this reporting period 18 MoAI technical staff have given 5-day training on seed production and certification. They are now supervising and inspecting the seed production by the contracted seed company.

2022 Narrative: FAO strengthened national capacity to provide quality agriculture extension services for increased production and productivity through sustainable and climate-smart agricultural practices and improved knowledge on sustainable production, including agroforestry. In 2022, FAO established 252 and revitalized 22 farmer groups ‚Äì totaling 814 farmer and 20 pastoralist groups currently supported by FAO in the country (Nampula, Zamb√©zia, Sofala and Gaza provinces). FAO also trained 81 farmer facilitators (21 percent women), which in turn trained an additional 477 farmers (32 percent women) in Nampula and Zamb√©zia provinces. The trained facilitators are leading training on their respective groups and are focal points of the farmer group networks. There was a gender imbalance among the farmer facilitators trained due to the fact that community leaders are men, lack of support from husbands for their wives to be absent for five days in a row and the burden of irreplaceable responsibilities of women in their household ‚Äì such as childcare, elderly care, housework and animal care. FAO will continue working to reduce gender imbalances and adjust gender strategies, particularly in the communities. Nevertheless, through FAO support, over 21,000 smallholder producers (approximately 48 percent women) improved capacity on sustainable agriculture in Nampula, Zambezia, Sofala and Gaza provinces. Subjects included (i) good agriculture practices to improve production and productivity of market-oriented crop value chains: maize, rice, pigeon-pea, mung-bean, common-bean, sesame and soybean, (ii) application of climate smart agricultural practices (Polycropping, conservation agriculture, integration of crops and livestock production and agroforestry) for adaptation and mitigation of climate change, raising resilience at farm level and contributing to carbon sequestration; (iii) agroforestry models at farm level to: increase resilience, food and income diversification, biological balance and conservation of natural resources and environmental services (carbon sequestration for carbon credits trade); and (iv) use of integrated cashew management, including the adoption of Good Agriculture Practices (GAP), quality of cashew and renewal of unproductive trees to improve productivity and quality of cashew.Aiming to improve seed systems, FAO supported the establishment of 118 demo-plots by 62 farmers in Nampula and Zambezia provinces. The main objective of these demo-plots was to familiarize producers with the characteristics, productive potential and adaptability of crops to agro-ecological conditions, through engagement with the Agricultural Research Institute of Mozambique (IIAM), seed companies and agro dealers, thereby increasing the demand for quality seeds. To enhance farmers' access to seed markets, 20 extension agents and 20 local seed producers in Nampula and Zambezia provinces were trained on technicalities (good agricultural practices) and quality standards for certified seed production and agribusiness management. FAO facilitated trade in rural areas with (peri)-urban market actors by activating 10 farmer networks and aggregating over 183 farmer groups for commercial purposes. The farmer groups received training in agribusiness management and design based on the Farmer Business School (FBS) Methodology with a focus on enhancing market linkages, negotiation skills and business planning. Furthermore, FAO facilitated trade relations based on inclusive business models and fair-trading practices by organizing a business seminar and providing ad hoc supply chain matchmaking to different actors. The respective farmer groups submitted a total of 80 investment proposals to overcome hurdles in assets related to diversification of activities, facilitate market access or improve production. The matching grants for micro-projects within this FAo intervention ranged in value between 1,500 USD ‚Äì 15,000 USD, which will be funded in 2023.
2023 Narrative: National capacity to provide quality agriculture extension services was strengthened to increase production and productivity through sustainable and climate-smart agricultural practices and improve knowledge of sustainable production, including agroforestry.106 Farmer Facilitators and 26 local government extension officers (30.7 percent female) improved capacity on participatory extension techniques. 211 farmer groups were created and 111 revitalized . A total of 23,587 Small Holder farmers (SHF) (60 percent women) engaged in 919 farmer groups improved knowledge on good agriculture practices, post-harvest and marketing.Producers increased access to investment.50 producers were granted the opportunity to investment. Payments are outcome based and imply a matching (in kind or in cash) component of a minimum of 20 percent of the total investment volume. Currently, three financing windows are operationalized: scaling of agribusiness operations, diversification of marketing channels and value adding for products or processes. Beneficiaries of the grants modality face challenges in meeting the formal administrative requirements.

2024 Narrative: IOM and its implementing partners were able to reach a total of 10,075 households/69,987 individuals in Somali, Oromia and South Regions of Ethiopia through Multipurpose Cash responses for people in need. Through its direct implementation, IOM reached a total of 6,443 households (HHs), including 49,488 individuals. Among these, 25,705 are female, while the remaining 23,783 are male. There are also 841 People with Disabilities (PWD) reached in the response. The direct implementation of the MPC response was in three regional states Somali, Oromia and South Ethiopia. The woredas are Goro Baqaqsa and Gura Damole in Somali region, Taltale Woreda in the Oromia region, and Amaro Woreda in South Ethiopia Region (SER). The beneficiaries could meet a significant percentage of their basic needs using the cash assistance provided.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Resilience
Outcome: Outcome 4.2 - Refugees and Migrants
Output: Output 4.2.2 - Refugees assisted for voluntary repatriation or resettlement, in safety and dignity
Sub-Output: 4.2.2.2 - Support to Host Communities with focus on Food and Economic Security through Agriculture
Description:
In order to align with Government priorities around the Agricultural Sector Development Plan II (ASDP 2) and other current interventions in the Kigoma region, the Kigoma Joint Programme Agriculture theme (Outcome 6) adopts the partnership approach to address issues pertaining to smallholders farmers. _x000D_
_x000D_
FAO interventions under the programme,  focus on improving agricultural productivity through promoting Climate Smart Agriculture, creating access to knowledge on Good Agricultural Practices, access to high quality inputs that are adapted to local conditions such as climate conditions and pest and disease pressure, to increase the productivity of identified crops (Maize, Cassava and Beans)._x000D_
_x000D_
FAO continues to play a critical role in providing technical support through advocating for the implementation of the Tanzania Agriculture and Climate Resilience Plan (ACRP) and Climate Smart Agriculture Programme to mitigate risks, set priorities for action and investment and build a foundation for resilience in the agriculture sector especially for vulnerable communities. This reiterates the government‚Äôs commitment to make the agricultural sector climate-smart by 2030. _x000D_
_x000D_
A comprehensive training package on Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) emphasizing on Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) for crop production will entail on/off farm practices that address environmental, economic and social sustainability aspects along the supply chain, which results to safe and quality food and non-food products. This will enable farmers to become resilient to climate shock. Emphasis will also be placed on nutrition-sensitive agriculture to address the double burden of malnutrition in the region._x000D_
_x000D_
The CSA guideline will be used as an instructive tool for informing extension staff and farmers on mainstreaming climate change adaptation and mitigation co-beneficial objectives within agriculture development. More particularly, it will provide guidance on CSA practices and technologies best suited for Kigoma region and the agro-climatic zone. It will also target district development planners and extension agents to plan and budget for agricultural development, and to facilitate community level planning; and extension agents to sensitize, mobilize and train smallholder farmers to adopt agricultural practices considered climate-smart. _x000D_
_x000D_
Additionally, FAO will train smallholder farmers on improved beekeeping practices as an important livelihood strategy for income generating with very high potential for improving income, especially for communities living close to forests and woodlands.  Beekeeping development also has a potential of contributing to self-employment, enhancing agricultural production, promoting and the conservation of the environment._x000D_
_x000D_
FAO interventions will focus on the following outputs for the next four years: _x000D_
- Strengthening group cohesion and building producer organizations through Farmer Field Schools (FFS) and Junior Farmer Field Learning Schools (JFFLS)_x000D_
- Training on good agriculture practices and Climate Smart Agriculture practices for selected commodities including maize, beans, cassava and livestock production_x000D_
- Procurement and distribution of agricultural inputs (seeds and fertilizer, herbicides/pesticides, vaccines) and tools._x000D_
- Disseminate information about different and appropriate varieties of maize, beans and cassava and livestock through various channels including community radios, school JFFLS and FFS programmes._x000D_
- Promote and train Beekeeping as a viable enterprise (incl. dissemination of information via community radio)_x000D_
- Develop and implement integrated landscape management plans in the project area/ agricultural zone
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Geography: Tanzania, United Republic of; Tanzania, United Republic of;

Outcome: Outcome 4.3: Gender Equality & Human Rights of marginalized groups
Output: Output 4.3.1: Increased Meaningful Participation and Representation of Women, Youth, and Other Marginalised Groups in the Governance Process.
Sub-Output: 4.3.1.5 Increased participation and decision making of  women, men, or both women and men in food assistance and transfer modality
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United Nations World Food Programme
Implementation partners: Action Aid; Christian Aid; Goggoji Zumunchi Development Initiative; Nigeria Federal Ministry of Women Affairs and Social Development; Plan International
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life
QCPR function: Normative Support; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: WFP ensures gender cuts across all its activities and takes on a gender-transformative approach to women and men in the decision-making processes surrounding food assistance and transfer modalities.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Anchored in a rights-based approach, this activity supports equitable access to services and resources, reinforcing commitments under the SDGs and international human rights frameworks.
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
LNOB groups targeted: Persons With Disabilities; Women & Girls; Other; Youth
2023 Narrative: The World Food Programme (WFP) remains steadfast in its commitment to achieving gender equality and empowering women, recognizing its importance in achieving zero hunger. Central to this commitment is the recognition that the diverse needs of women, men, girls, and boys must be met.WFP is dedicated to challenging entrenched cultural norms that impede women's access to food resources, economic opportunities, and decision-making power within households and communities. WFP is equally committed to empowering both women and men, as well as girls and boys, by providing them with the necessary skills and resources to combat food insecurity effectively.Throughout the reporting year, WFP conducts community sensitization sessions and gender training for cooperating partners and staff. Additionally, WFP translated sensitization messaging into nine languages spoken in the Northeast region. WFP also ensured a balanced representation of women and men in its project management committees, while providing sensitizations and advocacy to community leaders, men and women on the importance of women's participation and decision-making in WFP programming. As a result of these efforts, there was a notable 20% increase in joint decision-making between women and men regarding household resources and involvement in WFP assistance, as reported in the October 2023 Food Security Outcome Monitoring Report. Reports from cooperating partners further indicate a significant rise in women's participation in decision-making within project management committees, underscoring WFP's commitment to enhancing women's involvement at both household and community levels.Despite persistent cultural barriers, which include entrenched gender roles, WFP continues to address these issues diligently and ensure women's meaningful participation in its programmes
2024 Narrative: Through community-based structures, there was enhanced participation of women, men, and persons with disabilities in food assistance programs. Through gender-sensitive training and inclusive initiatives, diverse voices were involved in decision-making. This commitment to empowerment has helped beneficiaries, especially women and persons with disabilities take ownership, making interventions more responsive to community needs for sustainable outcomes.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK 2020 - 2025
Strategic priority: SP 1 PEOPLE
Outcome: OUTCOME 1 All people in Ethiopia enjoy the rights and capabilities to realize their potential in equality and with dignity
Output: OUTPUT 1.3: Equitable access to basic social services is strengthened, benefitting vulnerable, marginalized and displacementaffected people.
Sub-Output: Camp Coordination and Camp Management and Emergency Shelter and Non-Food items (NFI) assistance for conflict affected populations in Northern Ethiopia(CC.0053)
Description: The conflict in northern Ethiopia which began in November 2020 has spread from Tigray to Amhara and Afar regions resulting in the displacement of over two million people and the destruction of houses and household items (source: IOM Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) August 2021).1 The displacement context in Ethiopia remains fluid as the country continues to experience conflict and natural disaster driven displacements. As the conflict spreads and deepens, it is expected to affect more people and cause further sporadic displacement and increase needs particularly in northern Ethiopia. As a result of increased displacement, the needs under the Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Items (ES/NFI) and Camp Coordination and Camp management (CCCM) sectors in northern Ethiopia are immense. While most internally displaced persons (IDPs) (62% approx.) are seeking shelter with relatives and friends, many of the displaced (77% approx.) are living in crowded locations and sub-standard collective centers. Proposed interventions under this project address urgent gaps and needs identified through multi-sector assessments in Tigray and Amhara regions. IOM‚Äôs response under this project will include: 1) CCCM interventions and 2) provision of Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Items (NFIs).
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: Central Emergency Response Fund
Implementation partners: International Organization for Migration
SDG Targets: 11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.,11.c Support least developed countries, including through financial and technical assistance, in building sustainable and resilient buildings utilizing local materials.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2024-2028)
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: PEOPLE - HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT
Outcome: By 2028 more people, especially women, youth and the most vulnerable, use and have equitable access to quality social services delivered by effective institutions.
Output: The Government and stakeholders have strengthened capacity to generate evidence and implement policy and programmes to advance food security.
Sub-Output: National Institutions in Angola have strengthened capacity to implement programs to improve food security and nutrition
Description:
Vulnerability analysis and mapping

WFP collaborated with the Government of Angola and other key stakeholders to train 102 technical staff at both central and local levels in food and nutrition security data collection and analysis using the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC). These trained officials conducted a post-harvest food security and nutrition assessment and analysis in December 2024 aimed at understanding the impact of the El Ni√±o-induced drought. The assessment included a household survey in the most affected rural areas of Benguela, Hu√≠la, Namibe, Cunene, Moxico, and Cuando Cubango provinces. The data collected informed the IPC analysis, which will guide decision-making and support emergency response while also shaping medium- and long-term food security and nutrition policies and programmes. The exercise was supported by the IPC Global Support Unit (IPC GSU), the European Union's Strengthening Resilience, Food Security and Nutrition Programme (FRESAN), the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO), and other partners. WFP also assisted the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry in preparing the final IPC report, which is expected to be published in early 2025.

In response to the El Ni√±o-induced drought, WFP conducted assessment missions with the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the United States Agency for International Development's Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance (USAID/BHA), and the Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET) to assess the impact on food security, nutrition, and market conditions during the lean season.

WFP further supported the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry in revising the Second National Strategy for Food Security and Nutrition (ENSAN-II) and the National Council for Food Security and Nutrition (CONSAN). The approval of ENSAN-II is a critical step in ensuring that the strategy addresses the current food security and nutrition challenges comprehensively and is aligned with the National Development Plan (PDN) 2023-2027.

Additionally, WFP trained 23 government staff from Malanje and Cuanza Norte provinces on data collection and monitoring of food and agriculture input prices. This training is part of WFP's capacity strengthening efforts, aimed at improving the capabilities of the Institute of Agrarian Development (IDA) to inform food security trend analysis and the design of future programmes. 

Nutrition and food fortification

WFP continued to support the Ministry of Health in strengthening governance, leadership, and management of the National Nutrition Programme. As part of this effort, WFP trained 92 health facility staff in Lunda Norte and Moxico provinces on managing acute malnutrition, including screening, case finding, treatment, counselling, and stock management. Additionally, WFP co-chaired the nutrition partners working group alongside the Ministry of Health and UNICEF. WFP and UNICEF also supported the adaptation of the Global Action Plan (GAP) on Child Wasting to the Angolan context, providing a framework to accelerate progress in preventing and managing child wasting in alignment with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

WFP also played a pivotal role in supporting Angola's membership in the Global Alliance Against Hunger and Poverty. The Global Alliance aims to align domestic and international efforts to reduce hunger and poverty through effective programs and policies. The Government also adhered to the 2030 Sprint on maternal and early childhood support. Through this initiative, spearheaded by Brazil's G20 Presidency, the Government of Angola committed to doubling the number of children receiving nutrition support through the maternal and child health improvement and child rights protection and promotion programmes. In 2025, WFP will work with relevant government entities to operationalise these commitments.

Further, WFP worked with the Government of Angola to create an enabling environment for mandatory food fortification, a strategy aiming to address micronutrient deficiencies and improve health outcomes. Recognising the importance of multi-sectoral partnerships, WFP strengthened collaborations with key government entities, United Nations (UN) agencies, and the private sector. WFP was also invited by the Resident Coordinator‚Äôs Office to join an expert panel on enhancing private sector involvement in strategic value chains for food security, nutrition, and fortified food production. This underscores WFP‚Äôs role as a key partner in shaping Angola‚Äôs food fortification agenda. In collaboration with the Ministry of Health and UNICEF, WFP facilitated a mission from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the Food Fortification Initiative (FFI) to validate the landscape analysis report on food fortification in Angola. The next step will involve finalising the national food fortification strategy and presenting it to the Council of Ministers for validation.

WFP has also provided technical assistance to IDA in implementing the nutrition component of a large-scale project funded by the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). The aim was to improve nutrition outcomes by enhancing knowledge on infant and young child nutrition, dietary diversification, food processing, conservation, storage, and water, sanitation, and hygiene practices. WFP, IDA, and IFAD are also exploring opportunities to expand technical assistance in projects aimed at increasing agricultural productivity, reducing post-harvest losses, improving smallholder farmers' market access, and reducing the prevalence of acute malnutrition.

School feeding

WFP remained a key development partner to the Government of Angola, providing policy support, technical assistance, and expertise to enhance the sustainability and scale of the national school feeding programme. In collaboration with an interministerial committee ‚Äîincluding representatives from the Ministries of Finance, Planning, Education, Agriculture and Forestry, Health, and Social Affairs, Family and Women's Promotion ‚Äî, WFP supported the redesign of the school feeding programme, which was approved by the Council of Ministers in January 2025. This effort aligns with Angola‚Äôs commitments under the School Meals Coalition to expand access to nutritious meals for all children by 2030.

WFP also advocated for Angola‚Äôs participation in the 2030 Sprint for School Meals, launched as part of the Global Alliance Against Hunger and Poverty. This would support the scale-up and strengthening of the national school feeding programme through access to a global network of partners.

In 2025, WFP, in collaboration with the Ministries of Education and Planning and the WFP Centre of Excellence Against Hunger, will facilitate a high-level exchange visit to Brazil. Building on successful South-South Cooperation between Angola and Brazil, this visit will showcase Brazil‚Äôs experience in managing its national school feeding programme, with a focus on monitoring, evaluation, accountability, and smallholder market support.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Angola Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: Government of Angola
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Other (including coordination); Policy Advice and Thought Leadership; Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women's empowerment in a limited way

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2024-2028)
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: PEOPLE - HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT
Outcome: By 2028 more people, especially women, youth and the most vulnerable, use and have equitable access to quality social services delivered by effective institutions.
Output: The social protection system is strengthened to address vulnerabilities faced by Angolans across the life cycle and provide income security, particularly for children, women, persons with disabilities, persons in active age who are unable to earn sufficient income and older persons.
Sub-Output: Provide food transfers to refugees
Description:
WFP, in collaboration with the Government of Angola and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), provided unconditional food transfers to 5,600 refugees (51 percent women and girls) from the Democratic Republic of Congo living in the L√≥vua settlement in Lunda Norte province. This included 200 unregistered refugees who received assistance through the exceptional ration programme. WFP continued to provide reduced rations, meeting only 75 percent of the daily kilocalorie requirements due to persistent funding challenges. To mitigate supply chain disruptions caused by procurement delays, WFP increased efforts to source commodities locally.

WFP accompanied the food transfers with nutrition education to improve the knowledge about nutritious foods and support healthy behaviours. WFP, UNHCR, and partners also ensured ongoing nutrition screening, referrals, treatment, and follow-up for children diagnosed with acute malnutrition.
Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: World Vision International

2022 Narrative: ‚Ä¢ Provided strong, stable and predictable leadership and strengthened the timely and appropriate food security and livelihoods response through an inclusive common coordination platform for over 150 humanitarian actors in Somalia‚Ä¢ Collected, analyzed and shared information important for cluster partners, stakeholders and the wider humanitarian community to make informed, evidence-based and strategic decisions, to better serve affected and vulnerable populations efficiently and effectively.‚Ä¢ Enabled humanitarian actors to prioritize their interventions, improve targeting, adhere to minimum standards of assistance, and use resources in more efficient and effective ways through more coordinated actions‚Ä¢ Provided leadership at national and subnational levels, including supporting humanitarian technical and strategic coordination fora (ICCG, HCT) ‚Ä¢ Increased the efficiency and effectiveness of the food security and livelihoods humanitarian response by conducting cluster meetings at the national and sub national levels co-chaired with the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation (MOAI), the Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs and Disaster Management (MoHADM) and the Ministry of Livestock, Forestry and Range (MoLFR) ‚Ä¢ Enhanced inter-sectoral coordination and collaboration with Nutrition, WASH, Health, Protection, Shelter/NFI, and CCCM clusters to lay out common strategies and referral pathways for populations at risk of Famine .‚Ä¢ Provided support to the Cash Working Group in the development of a joint guidance on the Minimum Food Expenditure Basket (MEB) and Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance transfer values‚Ä¢ Led partners in the development of a food security strategic response, including objectives, output indicators and impact indicators, which directly supported the realization of the HCT strategic priorities and fed into the HNO and HRP‚Ä¢ Advocated for food security and livelihoods prioritization and allocation of USD $26 million in the 2022 Somalia Humanitarian Fund CERF, Standard and reserve allocations.   The focus was integrated interventions aimed at drought and Famine prevention actions for areas risk of Famine‚Ä¢ Conducted the 2021 annual Country Cluster Performance Monitoring (CCPM) based on the IASC standards. The survey results rated the FSC as Good in its core functions indicating that partners were satisfied with the cluster with a few areas needing minor improvements. The findings informed actions to improve performance as part of the cluster‚Äôs strategy ‚Ä¢ Contributed humanitarian response data for the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) Post-Gu, Post - Deyr and risk of Famine analyses, which were crucial in supporting cluster partners, stakeholders, and the larger humanitarian community in making informed, evidence-based, and strategic decisions that would better serve affected and vulnerable people ‚Ä¢ Guided partners planning and response, enabling them to better target their programmes, creating synergies and avoiding duplication of assistance through a robust and effective information management system that allows for enhanced receipt and organization of information, and display to partners in an accessible manner (interactive and static dashboards)‚Ä¢ Strengthened the emergency preparedness and response capacity of partners, communities, and authorities through capacity-building activities to UN agencies, NGOs, and relevant technical line ministries. Partners and key technical line ministries increased their performance and ability to function and stay relevant in a quickly changing and dynamic humanitarian context as a result of needs-based training and capacity-building activities

Sub-Output: 2024:3.2.1.7 : Build seed security assessment (SSA) capacity and support establishment of national seed security assement committee to oversee and support implementation of SSA recommendations; build capacity of the public sectors in formulation and implementation of seed regulatory frameworks, and support development of national seed regulations; enhance technical capacity of public and private sectors in promoting the quality and availability of foundation seeds at national and state levels with focus on drought tolerant staple food and fodder crop species
Description: The project‚Äôs focus is on strengthening national and regional capacities to enhance quality and availability of early generation seeds of selected climate smart staple-food and fodder crop species and varieties. 7500 farmers and 2 private sectors (seed companies) will be supported to increase availability of quality foundation/early generation seeds through supervision of MoAI to boost national food production and incomes. The project will identify and source most ASAL adapted dual purpose varieties of Sorghum and Cowpea from KALRO, ICRISAT, other CG centers and regional research organizations for trials, farmer demonstrations, adaptability trials, multiplication and conservation of foundation seeds for further improved seed production. Support MoAI and SARIS in developing close collaboration, partnership and networks with leading agricultural research organizations in the region for continued technical backstopping and access to superior crop germplasm.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: African Development Bank
Implementation partners: Somalia Federal Member States; Somalia Ministry of Agriculture and Irigations
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries,8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.4 Improve progressively, through 2030, global resource efficiency in consumption and production and endeavour to decouple economic growth from environmental degradation, in accordance with the 10-year framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production, with developed countries taking the lead.,9.2 Promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and, by 2030, significantly raise industry's share of employment and gross domestic product, in line with national circumstances, and double its share in least developed countries.,9.a Facilitate sustainable and resilient infrastructure development in developing countries through enhanced financial, technological and technical support to African countries, least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and Small Island developing States.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: Availability of quality seeds improved through successful testing, adaptation, official registration and multiplication within Somalia of several high-performing crop varieties including Gadam, CR:35:5, and IESV 92043 sorghum, as well as Kunde Tamu, Kunde Tumaini, K80, and M66 cowpeas from KALRO, alongside KK and Kunde Mboga varieties from Kenya Seed. To date Gadam sorghum and M66 cowpea passed all tests and were officially registered on Somalia‚Äôs national varieties list, marking a significant achievement in improving seed quality and availability. This development strengthens formal seed production systems, advances national breeding efforts, and supports agricultural productivity, food security, and farmers‚Äô livelihoods in Somalia.

MoAI will be capacitated technically and supported to supervise 7500 farmers and 2 private sectors to produce 156 tonnes of quality sorghum and cowpea foundation/early generation seed. This is expected to increase availability of foundation/early generation seeds and a boost in national food production and incomes.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: The effectiveness of the Somalia's seed regulatory framework was reinforced through a dedicated focus on early-generation seeds (EGS) for drought-tolerant staple crops like sorghum and cowpea. This initiative involved key actors such as Federal and State Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation (MoAI), Somalia Agriculture Regulatory and Inspection Service (SARIS), FAO, regional institutions (IGAD, EAC, COMESA), CGIAR centers, the African Seed Access Index (TASIA), the African Agricultural Technology Foundation (AATF), and TAAT (Technologies for African Agricultural Transformation).Notably, the Somalia‚Äôs national seed frameworks was extensively reviewed and aligning with regional protocols. This work contributed to the creation of the National Seed Council and the National Variety Release Committee (NVRC), which are responsible for overseeing seed sector regulation and variety release.A strategic roadmap for aligning national policies with regional standards was also developed, alongside efforts to strengthen seed security assessments. These actions are designed to improve seed availability, agricultural productivity, food security, and resilience, while ensuring Somalia‚Äôs seed sector is harmonized with regional protocols to enhance trade and sustainability.

(Project: TCP/SOM/3902) (Description: The Hand-in-Hand Initiative (HiH) is a flagship initiative of the FAO Director-General to bring together major partners to support accelerated, scaled-up action to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The Initiative targets the poorest ‚Äì the poorest people in the poorest countries and in countries with large poor populations, as well as countries in food crisis. Its specific focus is to work with FAO Member Nations to provide data and analysis to identify inclusive and sustainable agri-food systems to eradicate poverty and malnutrition and reduce inequality within and among nations.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Somalia Ministry of Agriculture and Irigations
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,10.1 By 2030, progressively achieve and sustain income growth of the bottom 40 per cent of the population at a rate higher than the national average.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty; 2 Zero Hunger; 10 Reduced Inequalities
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: Sesame production in Lower Juba and maize value chain development in Lower Shabelle are driving agricultural transformation by enhancing productivity, create jobs, and strengthen food securitythrough the support of FAO's Hand-in-Hand initiative in collaboration with Somalia's Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation (MoAI). The sesame program is projected to expand to over 100,000 hectares, benefiting 200,000 farmers, with an expected 30% Internal Rate of Return (IRR), generating $15 million in revenue, and creating 200 permanent and 31,000 temporary jobs. The maize program will establish a flour processing factory and improve production practices, benefiting 200,000 farmers, generating an IRR of 11%, and creating 125 permanent jobs with an additional $7.4 million in tax revenue. Both initiatives will be presented at investment forums to secure financial backing and partnerships.

2021 Narrative: FAO supported the targeted vulnerable farming households to continue production through the provision of a risk-reduction farming package. A total of 6.5 tonnes of maize seed, 15 tonnes of harricot bean and 50 tonnes of fertilizer were procured and distributed to 1 000 households in Meiso woreda in Oromia region. Oromia region was prioritized following the severity of the damage caused by desert locusts on the croplands. FAO used this project to conduct a voucher feasibility assessment and to set up a voucher system. Under these activities, FAO recruited technical personnel, identified agro dealers for both crop and livestock inputs, conducted capacity building of selected stakeholders including suppliers and partners and purchased and installed the facial recognition license ‚Äì an essential tool in implementing the system in the future. However, having gone through the assessment phase, the agro dealers never met the additional requirements for engaging on time in the distribution of the assistance package, which forced FAO to directly procure and deliver the inputsto the affected households in order to provide them within the very limited planting window. This method of assistance had cost implications leading to the full utilization of the resourcesfor the project‚Äôs crop production component; the originally-targeted livestock beneficiaries were assisted through a similar FAO project under the overall desert locust programme and where the voucher approach is being successfully implemented. Despite the need to use direct procurement and distribution of livelihoods inputs, the project had a significant positive impact on restoring the productive capacities of assisted households. Through targeted distributions of seeds and fertilizer, 1 000 beneficiary households received 6.5 kg of maize seeds, 15 kgs of vegetable seeds, and a 50 kg bag of fertilizer, which increased their ability to meet their basic food needs through their own production and reduced their reliance on emergency food assistance. Agricultural livelihoods packages were designed in consultation with feedback from beneficiary communities to ensure that the assistance provided was context-appropriate and reflected local needs and priorities. The project also prioritized assisting female-headed households (40 percent of the total beneficiary target), recognizing that these households often face reduced access to agricultural inputs and support services, placing them at greater risk of further food security and livelihoods due to the impact of desert locust upsurge. In total, inputs provided by the project allowed communities in Oromia to produce an estimated 750 metric tonnes of maize and 225 metric tonnes of haricot beans.

2021 Narrative: UNEP's interventions focused on ensuring the National Organic Agriculture Policy (NOAP) was disseminated to different regional stakeholders in Uganda. At the moment, the collection of organic agriculture statistics is ongoing, coupled with support for the drafting of the organic agriculture bill that is also ongoing.
2022 Narrative: ¬∑      The UN supported the Government of Uganda through the Ministry of Health to initiate development of Food-Based Dietary Guidelines to guide the country on healthy food choices and healthy food environment. As part of a consultation process a national stakeholders meeting and a workshop which attracted consumer protection champions from the GoU, Private Sector and CSOs have helped to increase awareness on food safety issues and identified gaps and weaknesses in Food Safety and Quality Assurance systems in Uganda¬∑      In collaboration with the European Union and CIRAD, a Rapid Food Systems Assessment (RAFSA) helped identify key challenges, strengths and trade-off s in agrifood systems. The assessment led to the development of a Food Systems Profile for Uganda¬∑      The UN also helped the Uganda Parliamentary Alliance for Food and Nutrition Security (UPA-FNS) to prepare a strategic plan to support legislative advocacy
2023 Narrative: WFP:WFP provided training to the district extension staff on WFP‚Äôs smallholder training modules to contribute to standardizing the country‚Äôs training resources used to build the capacity of smallholder farmers especially women on post-harvest management and market access. Supported the production and dissemination of the ordinances in two districts to stakeholders in Isingiro and Kyegegwa districts on managing the grain quality. UNCDF Supported the government of Uganda, civil society organizations and private sectors in supporting the last mile people to deepen the inclusive digital economy.   Over 50,000 beneficiaries have been supported technically and financially in enhancing digital skills both, this has equipped the vulnerable groups with digital skills using the digital services to carry out transactions, select the Value chain actors and Agri input service providers, making orders of the improved agricultural inputs, gaining knowledge and skills through e- learning for sustainable agriculture. 35,090 (female 9,388, male 5,950, Youth19,752 Refugees 883) trained on the digital literacy  50 value chain actors have been selected to support the agricultural advisory services and provision of improved agricultural inputs.  400 VHTs have been supported in digitizing the reporting templates and data collection forms in Maracha Nebbi, Koboko and lira, this has helped them to reach a bigger number of community members and effective reporting using the digital platforms as a way of strengthening the institution in their reporting strategy. This initiative has attracted other donors, and the government has received more funds to scale up the electronic information system implemented by the Ministry of Health  25 health centers have been supported in digital stock/ Inventory management to strengthen the development and implementation of the digital platform's strategy.  The ministry of health has been suported in the use of medical drones to overcome geographical constraints in providing last mile health emergency response to the Covid-19 pandemic and other infectious diseases. Fully set up 11 hubs out of five (5) target drone hubs (health facilities).  Added two (2) new local languages out of two (2) target languages in Madi and Lugbara to CFL-HIV instance.  The IVR technology sent out 235,477 vs 56,000 target calls to HIV clients, clients diagnosed with Tuberculosis and contacts of positive Covid-19 cases. Lessons Learnt:  Digital literacy, access to devices continue to be key barriers to scaling digital solutions in rural Uganda. Efforts to fast track these cannot be overstressed. While new payment plan models for phones are picking up on the market, providing digital literacy remains more challenging since it is hard to come up with a business model around it.   Challenges: High expenses on connectivity.

2020 Narrative: FAO targeted 15 000 households were supported with assorted cereal and vegetable seeds except mung bean; no good quality mung bean seeds could be sourced from the market. All the cereal seeds were distributed for the registered farming households by end of May 2021 and the vegetable seeds by mid-June 2021.A few beneficiaries (360 households in Dollo Ado woreda of Somali region) were able to receive their vegetable kits by week1 August. This was largely because of the delayed clearance following the changes in the import clearance process in the country. ÔÇ∑ About 675 hectares of land in Somali region could not be planted due to complete failure or below normal Gu rain in some of the targeted areas. This also affected the expected crop yields in these locations. In addition, 750 hectares of land in SNNP could not be planted due to the unavailability of good quality mung bean seed in the market. ÔÇ∑ Identification and selection process for the financial service providers (unexpectedly) took longer than planned. Hence, completion of cash distribution delayed to August 2021.

2021 Narrative: Initially, procurement and quality clearances of the inputs (supplementary feed) took longer than expected due to unforeseen national shortage of molasses (the main raw material for production of Multi-Nutrient Blocks). The shortage slowed production and delivery of the feed as it prompted change of feed type to Total Mixed Rations (TMR), (which does not require the molasses) and search for new suppliers. ÔÇ∑ FAO had to reject significant quantities (from the first batches of TMR produced by the suppliers) due to substandard quality; high levels of aflatoxin, among other quality parameters. It took the suppliers quite some time to replace the rejected feed lots because of the scarcity of raw materials coupled with high inflation in the country. ÔÇ∑ The situation was exacerbated by the additional demand for the commodity (animal feed) following the drought situation in Southern Ethiopia. Despite their limited capacity, the suppliers have been struggling to cope or (also) supply the feed to drought affected locations. This delayed (beyond March 31) the delivery of the remaining 47 percent of the feed as originally planned; but it is estimated that delivery and distributions of the late batches will be complete within April and May. However, unconditional cash was successfully distributed to all the registered feed beneficiaries. ÔÇ∑ The End line Survey (covering the areas under AA tranche 2) was deliberately delayed pending completion of activities. However, OCHA is currently coordinating a survey in some of these project areas. It is therefore assumed that achievement in outcome indicators (above) will be estimated by the findings. Otherwise FAO plans to undertake an end line survey in May 2022

Agencies: United Nations World Food Programme
Contributing partners: Government of Austria; Government of Denmark; Government of Germany; Government of Malta; Government of Poland; Government of Sweden; Government of Switzerland; Government of the United Kingdom; Italian Agency for Development Cooperation ; Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Private Donors; Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation; United Nations World Food Programme; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: Libya Ministry of Social Affairs; Non Governmental Organizations
