QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery; Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: WFP reached 46,681non-displaced food-insecure population in Libya in 2023 through general food assistance (GFA) and cash-based transfers (CBTs) in the form of value vouchers through pre-paid cards. Between April and August, WFP implemented a geographic prioritization approach to assist vulnerable Libyans drawing upon data from the 2022 Food Security Outcome Monitoring and the 2021 Food Security and Nutrition Assessment.
2024 Narrative: Under the 2024 Libya Flood Flash Appeal which concluded in July 2024 [1], WFP reached 44,355 flood-affected people across eight flood-affected cities in the eastern part of Libya (Derna, Benghazi, Tobruk, Al Bayada, Al Ghubbah, Al Sahel, Al Abyar, Ajdabiya) with a total of 490 mt of in-kind food assistance.  Moreover, In areas where markets are functional, WFP, in partnership with the Libyan Humanitarian Relief Agency (LibAid), disbursed USD 2.7 million in value vouchers via pre-paid cards to 27,109 people across six redemption points in 15 cities in northeastern Libya. Cash assistance reduced logistical costs associated with food transport and storage, ensuring faster and more cost-effective response.   Overall, at the forefront of the UN floods emergency response, WFP has reached a total of 230,000 flood-affected Libyans between mid-September 2023 ‚Äì July 2024 through its flood emergency recovery response in Derna and surrounding areas. In August, WFP was on the ground in Al Kufra (south) within hours of heavy rains and flash floods, airlifting 484 emergency food rations through its local cooperating partner, LibAid, to meet the immediate food needs of nearly 3,000 people displaced from Benghazi [2].  In response to the floods in the Ghat region, WFP provided a total of USD 77,916 in CBTs to support 475 affected households (2,375 individuals) in Ghat, Tahala and Alberket. Each household received two months of unrestricted cash assistance through prepaid cards with a transfer value of USD 21 per person per month. The assistance was provided as a double ration in a single distribution cycle, ensuring that beneficiaries were able to meet their urgent food and non-food needs during the crisis.  In December when Adjdabiya was hit by heavy rains, WFP, in close coordination with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and local cooperating partner LibAid, responded to urgent needs and delivered a total of 21.1 mt of food assistance to support 700 households (3,500 individuals). Under the revised 2024 June Sudan Regional Response Plan [5], WFP ramped up its emergency food assistance and reached more than 81,721 Sudanese refugee women and men with over 500 mt in-kind assistance and disbursed USD 40,425 to 3,600 Libyan host communities across 11 locations in the country. The assistance was informed by a needs assessment of the Sudanese refugee‚Äôs situation in Al Kufra in August, mapping critical needs and locations. The food basket for Sudanese refugees contained Tuna fish, fortified biscuits, date bars, and vegetable oil.
2025 Narrative: Activity 1 (general food assistance) is continuing throughout 2025.

2022 Narrative: o protect livestock from endemic and Transboundary Animal Diseases (TADs), FAO improved access to animal health services, particularly for the prevention and control of frequent diseases such as Newcastle, foot and mouth, Theileriosis, bovine tuberculosis, bovine brucellosis, tick borne and black leg. Under the tick control programme, acaricides (Amitraz 12.5 percent) were provided for each pastoralist group with an average of 1,060 heads of cattle dipped twice per month. FAO is currently supporting a Newcastle disease vaccination campaign for chickens in 32 villages. In July 2022, approximately 30,000 chickens were vaccinated in 989 households (65 percent women). For this purpose, 36 community vaccinators (36 percent women) in each village were trained and equipped with t-shirts, caps, cooler boxes and a vaccinator notebook. There has been no record of disease outbreaks in all villages covered by the vaccinations since the campaigns began. FAO also supported government-led cattle vaccination campaigns against foot-and-mouth disease, lump skin disease and black leg by providing 40 cooler boxes to transport and store vaccines in two districts of Guij√° and Mabalane provinces and supported the cold chain by providing two fridges and 40 cooler boxes to conserve and transport vaccines for cattle.FAO and WFP conducted two trainings for 24 technicians (seven women) and 541 farmers (399 women) on the use of the Participatory Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (PICSA) methodology to support decision-making to prepare and implement the agrarian campaign. As a result, farmer/ pastoralist groups in Mabalane and Guij√° districts in Gaza Province are utilizing the methodology in planning and decision-making processes. In addition, FAO and WFP disseminated information on measures related to the sowing season, use of river and flood-prone areas and determination of crop type. FAO implemented a local seed production programme to establish community seed banks and connect farmers with quality seed aftershocks such as floods or drought. This activity involved 77 farmers (87 percent women) and resulted in the production of 28 tons of certified seed and 15 tons of stored seed that will cover 600 hectares to cope with the next agricultural season. To address constraints on the availability and nutritional quality of pasture during the dry season, FAO improved animal husbandry and feeding for pastoral communities by expanding options for supplementing forage for livestock. For feed supplementation, 250 mineral blocks and 800 bales (8 tons) of hay were produced and hay trestles were constructed in 18 pastoralist groups, improving their resilience in the targeted areas.
2023 Narrative: 20 improved Gorongosa model silos (10 in each district) with a capacity of 1500kg/each were built. Additionally, one irrigation scheme was reconstructed in Guij√° district, Gaza Province and 31 people (20 community facilitators) and 11 technicians (6 from Guij√° and 5 from Mabalane) were trained on irrigation scheme management. The system will irrigate 450 hectares belonging to the community and two FFS groups with 70 members that exploit about 50 hectares. About 450 households benefit from the system to produce crops with an emphasis on cereals, legumes and vegetables and will contribute to improved and stable production and yields throughout the year.

2020 Narrative: FAO supported the targeted vulnerable farming households to continue production through the provision of a risk reduction farming package. A total of 120.76 tonnes of assorted seeds (31.5 tonnes of teff, 31.88 tonnes of sorghum, 39.38 tonnes of haricot bean, 7 tonnes of maize and 11 tonnes of vegetable seeds) were procured and delivered to project areas. The inputs were distributed in Harbu, Raya Kobo, Tehuledere and Worebabo woredas to the benefit of 47 000 farming households. Amhara Region was prioritized following the severity of the damage caused by desert locusts on cropland. Overall, the provided livelihood packages had a positive impact on the lives and livelihoods of the targeted 235 000 people. The support resulted in an estimated yield of 38 880 tonnes of assorted food, enabling beneficiaries to meet their immediate household needs during the Meher lean season and at the same time cushioned them from the economic pressures caused by COVID-19 and conflict, thereby averting the possible adoption of negative coping mechanisms. 5 Activities that led to the successful achievement of these results included stakeholder inception workshops, community mobilization and sensitization, beneficiary selection and registration, verification and extension advice prior to the distribution of the inputs.

2021 Narrative: Following a first successful year of the initiative of the German Federal Foreign Office (GFFO) and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the second year has been marked by critical advancements in achieving the objectives. This was possible also through the continued presence of the AA technical focal points who were hired under this initiative at country, regional and global levels . Despite the fact that the COVID-19 pandemic continued to pose challenges, in 2021 priority countries and regions under this project managed to develop, test and calibrate risk monitoring and AA trigger mechanisms for priority hazards, implement AA, advocate for a scale-up of AA, and strengthen coordination and partnerships with key actors. Below are first some global updates, which are followed by selected regional and country-level highlights: - Country-level AA systems: Building upon initial foundations from 2020, most countries now have anticipatory action systems in place, which are currently being tested and calibrated. The systems were developed in close coordination with partners and governments. Priority countries that finalised drought AA systems by 2021 include Ethiopia, Niger, Madagascar, Malawi, the Philippines and Zimbabwe. The frequency, accuracy, timeliness and coverage of risk analyses have improved in several priority countries, although additional efforts are needed to further improve and sustain the relevant capacities and tools. - OCHA AA inter-agency frameworks: In some of the countries prioritized under this project, AA systems were established through inter-agency processes facilitated by OCHA, with substantial technical and operational advice provided by FAO. This was the case of Niger, Chad, Malawi, Ethiopia, South Sudan and the Philippines. Niger and Chad now have a finalised AA framework for drought, Malawi for dry spells, the Philippines for typhoons, while the framework for South Sudan might be established in 2022. - SFERA activations: In 2021, GFFO‚Äôs contribution proved to be highly valuable to protect the lives and livelihoods of vulnerable rural households ahead of forecast shocks. Thanks to the contribution to the SFERA-AA fund, three AA activations could be carried out. When the political crisis started in Myanmar, the distribution of vegetable kits, poultry feed, rice seeds and fertilizers helped boost local food production in rural areas before the arrival of a large number of migrants from towns, thus preventing food security deterioration. In Syria, vulnerable farmers received drought-tolerant wheat seeds and training on climate smart agriculture practices ahead of La Ni√±a-induced dry conditions. The timely anticipatory action intervention allowed farmers to get immediate support to address challenges during the wheat growing season and likely prevented farmers from abandoning their lands. In Madagascar, the forecast outbreak of migratory locusts triggered FAO‚Äôs largest SFERA allocation for AA so far (about USD 1 million) to mitigate crop damages through surveillance ,and control operations ahead of the main agricultural planting season. As a result of the capacity building, timely surveillance and control, a severe deterioration of the locust situation has been prevented. - Capacity building: The first e-learning course on the topic ‚ÄúDeveloping an Anticipatory Action System‚Äù, which was developed under the GFFO initiative last year, was put into practice during several trainings in 2021. In Southern Africa, FAO facilitated an extensive training, for internal staff as well as partner organizations and representatives of governments and regional institutions (e.g. SADC). In Asia, internal training was provided to 11 FAO country offices, and a separate external training was organized for representatives of ASEAN member states. - Normative guidance: The development of guidelines and tools in support of effective anticipatory action programming for the agriculture and food security sectors has progressed in 2021. For example, the review of existing trigger systems and guidelines for drought trigger development has been finalised. Consultations have been conducted with experts in early warning and trigger mechanisms for anticipatory action, as well as experts in community engagement. As a result, the EWEA/AA country toolkit is being revised, and several publications are currently in review/finalization stages, including (1) a review of AA trigger mechanisms for drought; (2) guidelines on establishing triggers for AA; (3) a FAO position paper on AA for slow onset hazards; (4) a note on community engagement in AA; (5) a note on analyzing the effectiveness of AA, among others. Advancements have been also made for linking analytical tools and exploiting complementarities and synergies among them. For instance, country case studies are underway to understand data/information needs to strengthen the linkages between IPC acute food insecurity projections and AA, and to produce concrete recommendations. These activities might also lead to the development of a guidance on the use of IPC projections to trigger AA. - Support institutionalisation of AA: With the support of this initiative with GFFO support, FAO and partners were able to work closely with regional and national decision-makers to support the uptake and institutionalisation of AA. This process is critical to ensure continuous monitoring and sustainability of the AA systems within countries and supports the scale-up of the AA approach. Further work is still required, but some successful examples include the inclusion of the AA concept in the ASEAN AADMER Work Programme 2021-2025, and FAO‚Äôs support to the ‚ÄúASEAN AA Framework in Disaster Management‚Äù in 2021. The Framework aims to harmonize definitions, and encourage the uptake of the approach in the region. It will outline actions on how to move forwards and provide guidance on how to scale up and link the approach to existing gains enhancing disaster management in the region. Similarly, in East Africa IGAD is guiding the development of a roadmap on AA, in close coordination with FAO and other organizations. In Niger technical support was initiated to include AA into the new 2021/25 strategy of the Directorate for Food Crisis Prevention and Management (DNPGCA). - New partnerships and complementary finance: Thanks to the increasing capacities and evidence generation funded by GFFO during recent years, FAO was able to further expand strategic partnerships and the coverage of its AA programme. For example, the pilot programmatic partnership (PPP) between FAO and DG ECHO officially began in August 2021, for a period of 3 years. The theme is scaling up anticipatory action, including through social protection. The target countries for year 1 are Pakistan, Bangladesh, Lao P.D.R., Viet Nam and the Philippines, with a view to further increasing geographical and financial coverage from Year 2. - Events, advocacy and commitments to bring AA to scale: In 2021, anticipatory action was high on the international agenda. It featured prominently in several major global events, such as the G7 Famine Prevention and Humanitarian Crises Compact; the High-Level HumanitarianEvent on Anticipatory Action; the High-Level Brussels Dialogue High-level Brussels Dialogue - From reaction to prevention: anticipatory action against food crises; and COP26, among others. Coordinated advocacy efforts, especially in the framework of the Anticipatory Action Task Force (AATF), helped mobilize commitments to scale-up anticipatory action in the face of unsustainable increases in humanitarian needs and costs. At the High-Level HumanitarianEvent, FAO committed to dedicate up to 20 percent of emergency and resilience financing towards anticipatory action over the next five years, with the help of partners‚Äô contributions. Further relevant events are highlighted in section 9. Furthermore, FAO actively contributed to exchanges of good practices and harmonization of methodologies for Monitoring, Evaluation, Accountability and Learning (MEAL) of AA (e.g. through participation in meetings and initiatives of the AA MEAL Practitioners group)

2024 Narrative: About 2,000 persons in the in 36 villages in the Okavango District have been supported with food packages to relieve them from the harsh effects of drought. 4 Cluster Garden Farms (in Sekondomboro, Ngarange, Ukusi and Qangwa) supported with 50m by 50m Netshading to reduce impact of heat and improve yield. Collectively these Cluster Garden Farms currently have 23 beneficiaries, whom are all women and youth. 6 walk behind tractors are being procured for 3 Cluster Farms (in Ngarange, Mohembo East, Etsha 8). That is 2 tractors per cluster, collectively these Cluster Farms have more than 300 members. Through practice, the aim is to show the small-scale farmers the benefits of investing in mechanized farm practices to take advantage of shorter ploughing and harvesting periods due to climate change, and how mechanization improves production and efficiency.

2022 Narrative: Improving access to quality agriculture inputs and markets through electronic voucher (e-voucher): FAO through the e-voucher, worked with a network of 25 agro-dealers and retailers who facilitated access to quality agricultural inputs (cereal, oilseeds and pulse seeds, fertilizers, tools) to 11,839 farmers (38 percent female), during the main agricultural season in 2021/22. Over the fresh season in 2022 ‚Äì 12,052 farmers (39.5 percent female) also accessed quality inputs (horticulture seeds, tools, fertilizers and herbicides). Additionally, 88 agro-dealers were trained or received refresher training in view of the agriculture season 2022-23. Within the scope of this FAo intervention, in close coordination with TechnoServe, the Deutsche Gesellschaft f√ºr Internationale Zusammenarbeit GmbH (GIZ), the Nuts Institute of Mozambique (IAM) ‚Äì FAO conducted an e-voucher pilot as a mechanism to facilitate access of 1,490 (22 percent female) farmers to tools and chemicals for cashew tree maintenance in two districts of Nampula Province (Angoche and Mogovolas). FAO activated 10 farmer netwok and activated an additional 20 farmer networks in Nampula and Zambezia provinces - covering in total 508 farmer groups. Through the networks, farmers gather twice a year (March and August) to discuss problems, solutions and opportunities, follow-up on operational plans and exchange experiences.
2023 Narrative: 30 066 Small Holder Farmers (SHF) increased access to quality inputs through e-voucher.26 396 SHF redeemed inputs to agriculture (seeds, tools, fertilizers, etc) under different levels of co-payment and according to project context and objectives aiming at increased productivity and production for self-consumption and market. As part of the e-voucher pilot for expansion of cashew tree treatment, 3 670 cashew producers redeemed pesticides and farm tools in Meconta, Angoche, Mogovolas districts of Nampula Province. The pilot is implemented in coordination with the government through the Mozambique Institute of Nuts (IAM) and GIZ and Techno Serve (private sector), aiming at gradually reducing the current system of IAM subsidies and to promote the inclusion of the private sector in direct sale and distribution of agrochemicals (agrodealers, spraying service providers and producers). The ultimate goal of this initiative is to improve coverage and sustainability of cashew treatment, which is key to increase the productivity and quality of cashews.Availability of seed at community level increased.Approximately 300 tonnes of seed (maize, rice, groundnut, cowpea, sesame, sorghum, pigeon peas, holoco beans, andoya) were produced by 170 local seed multipliers (in 290 hectares) in 10 in Nampula and Zambezia provinces. The seed was produced following all correct/standard production steps with FAO and Government support. About 91 percent of the farmers commercialized their seed through agro-dealer networks engaged in the FAO e-voucher scheme, while the remaining 9 percent of farmers sold directly to community members. FAO also mobilized, trained and engaged 26 seed multipliers from 3 districts in Sofala province.Farmers' awareness of available seed varieties improved.A total of 111 demonstration plots of seed varieties (maize, rice, sorghum, soybean, sesame, cowpea, common beans, rice and pigeon pea) were established in 10 districts of Nampula and Zambezia provinces and seven field days and seed fairs were held. This improved producers' familiarity with the seed varieties characteristics, productive potential, adaptability to agro-ecological conditions in the various climactic zones, organoleptic qualities, among other aspects. It is to note that FAO promotes climate adapted and high nutrition value varieties.Availability of seed varieties in the country improved.Seven wheat genotypes were selected for Mozambique‚Äôs agro-ecological zones and two of the varieties have been released for registration in the seed varieties system. Additionally, 12 cassava clones were selected as tolerant and/or resistant to Cassava Brown Streak (CBSD) and Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD) and were planted on two hectares in Angoche and Gil√© districts, in Nampula and Zambezia provinces, respectively.Communities improved opportunities for knowledge and experiences sharing.Ten farmer networks, covering a total of 200 farmer groups were initiated for commercial purposes. The networks provide a platform for market aggregation and structuring by clustering independent farmers with relatively low market volumes that are in geographical proximity. As the groups receive capacity training on agribusiness management and design, the establishment of geo-clusters is facilitated, ensuring that the groups organize their farms as businesses, resulting in steady ‚Äì consistent supply of quality production in the volumes required to successfully enter markets. This enhances market access and inclusion in commercially driven off-taker supply chains. Effective geo-clustering is further facilitated and supported through the Agricultural Market Information System (SIMA), which was created with FAO support.

2022 Narrative: ¬∑      IOM procured 5,000 toolkits that were distributed to 25,000 persons based on an estimated household (HHs) size of fiver persons per household (1 toolkit per HHs), allowing the beneficiaries in the Northern region to construct their own shelters with technical support and guidance of the shelter partners. ¬∑      Beneficiaries were able to utilise these toolkits to upgrade, improve, or repair shelters during the rainy season or after cyclones such as in Nampula where cyclone Gombe made landfall in March 2022. Overall, the project complemented shelter and non-food item activities funded by other donors (i.e., in-kind contributions of stock and funding towards emergency response activities) and added great value as the project ] focused not only on stock replenishment but also on tools and support for the CP system managed by IOM. A well-functioning warehouse and IOM CP system ensured reducing the procurement lead time and release of items to the shelter partners. For instance, the lead time for international procurement of stock was reduced by four-to-five months, hence speeding up recovery. This level of detail should be under the relevant output ‚Äì kindly stick to the results achieved.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) 2022-2026
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY AREA¬† 3: CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABLE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2026, more people, especially the most vulnerable, are resilient to climate change and disasters, and benefit from more sustainable management of environment and natural resources and resilient infrastructures and human settlements, with positive effects on national GDP.
Output: Output 3.3: Governmental and non-governmental organizations have effective and inclusive tools to enhance productivity and revenues through improved sustainable management of environment and natural resources, climate and disaster resilience, and value chains for environmental and natural resources, goods and services;
Sub-Output: Provision of immediate lifesaving emergency shelter and non-food item (NFI) assistance for cyclone and flood affected populations in Central and Northern Mozambique
Description:
Since the first and second landfall of Tropical Cyclone Freddy, Mozambique has experienced devasting floods, destruction, and death. Damage assessments are ongoing but early reports from the National Institute of Disaster Management (INGD) show that more than 102,000 houses and homes have been damaged, destroyed, or flooded, leading to the displacement of an estimated 64,418 individuals sheltered in 164 accommodation centers across Niassa, Zambezia, Tete, Manica, Sofala and Inhambane (as of 16 March 2023). Roads and bridges have been swept away cutting off communities from much-needed support.

With the CERF RR allocation, IOM will immediately kick-start the provision of Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Item (NFI) assistance to more than 5,350 families (26,750 individuals) across the affected provinces of Zambezia, Tete, Sofala and Inhambane, in coordination with the government and partners, while also strengthening the capacities of other Shelter and NFI partners to respond to the emergency situation. The shelter interventions that will be undertaken through this allocation in Shelter sector, will include:

- Support in strengthening partner coordination and improving their capacity to respond to the immediate shelter NFI needs of an estimated 22,250 vulnerable individuals (4,450 families), by facilitating their access to, and transportation of basic shelter NFIs supplies to the mostly affected districts.

- Construction of 900 temporary emergency shelters in the relocation sites identified within Sofala and Zambezia provinces, for estimated 4,500 vulnerable individuals including consultation and technical advice on safe construction.
Agencies: International Organization for Migration
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: Government of Mozambique
SDG Targets: 10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
